V.	Untruthfulness; and 
W.	Violating any of the rules and regulations governing the department or any administrative rule or regulation promulgated by the public safety committee or the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 835, Art. VI § 3, 1964) 
2.32.150 - Responsibility to note charges. 
    When charges are made against a member of the police department, the chief of police is to add to such charges reference to any prior charges against the accused and what disposition was made of them. 
(Ord. 835, Art. VI § 4, 1964) 
Chapter 2.33 - POLICE DEPARTMENT DRUG TESTING POLICY 
Sections: 

2.33.010 - Statement. 
    In September, 1998, the state of New Jersey Attorney General adopted revised guidelines with respect to testing law enforcement applicants, law enforcement trainees and sworn law enforcement officers for the use of controlled dangerous substances. The most significant change of the guidelines establishes random drug testing of sworn law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. 1324 § 2 (part), 1999) 
2.33.020 - Procedure. 
    The procedures hereinafter set forth in this chapter, relating directly to the Attorney General's Law Enforcement Drug Testing Policy, will be the policy of the Glen Ridge police department. All police personnel will comply with these procedures and any and all additional addendums set by the Attorney General, Essex County prosecutor's office or the Glen Ridge chief of police. As per the office of the Essex County prosecutor (Essex County Prosecutor Memorandum #45-98, December 17, 1998), the borough of Glen Ridge hereafter institutes the following random drug-testing program for the police department of the borough of Glen Ridge. 
(Ord. 1324 § 2 (part), 1999) 
2.33.030 - Order of random drug testing-Sworn law enforcement officers. 
A.	The random drug testing of sworn officers of the Glen Ridge police department will include all members, regardless of rank or assignment. 
B.	1.	The police commissioner (a non-sworn official) will randomly announce to the chief of police the date the selection process will be. 
2.	The selection process will be conducted randomly twice a year. 
3.	The chief of police will notify the appropriate witnesses for the selection. 
4.	The selection process will be conducted at the office of the chief of police. 
C.	Present for the drawing of names will be the following witnesses: 
1.	Chief of police; 
2.	Lieutenant or sergeant; 
3.	Internal affairs officer; and 
4.	PBA representative. 
D.	1.	Four officers will be randomly selected, each time a selection takes place. 
2.	The name of every sworn officer will be printed on a separate three inch by five inch card. 
3.	The names/cards will be verified by the witnesses. 
E.	1.	The names/cards of every sworn officer will be placed in a hat, for every selection. 
2.	The names/cards will be mixed prior to selection. 
3.	Four names/cards will be drawn from the hat by picking at random. 
4.	Each witness shall pick one card. 
F.	1.	The collection of urine specimens from selected officers will be prompt, efficient and confidential. 
2.	The internal affairs officer is responsible for the collection and record of urine samples, as outlined in the Attorney General's Guidelines. 
3.	Following the selection process, the officers named will be contacted by the internal affairs officer at the first opportunity, upon reporting to work. 
G.	Any member of the police department who discloses the identity of an officer selected for random testing or the fact that a random selection is scheduled to take place prior to the collection of urine specimens shall be subject to discipline. 
H.	Officers who refuse to submit to a drug test when randomly selected are subject to the same penalties as those officers who test positive for the illegal use of drugs. See Attorney General's Law Enforcement Drug Testing Policy. 
(Ord. 1324 § 2 (part), 1999) 
2.33.040 - Special considerations. 
A.	An administrative decision to eliminate an officer selected is permissible if: 
1.	The officer is not available; 
2.	The officer is on extended leave. 
B.	The decision will be documented by the internal affairs officer and made a permanent record of the testing process. 
(Ord. 1324 § 2 (part), 1999) 
2.33.050 - Applicability of other laws. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the power of the borough of Glen Ridge or any officer or department to enforce any provisions of its charter, or any other provisions of its code or regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to prevent or punish violations thereof, and the powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the borough by any other law or provision of the Glen Ridge Code. 
(Ord. 1324 § 2 (part), 1999) 
2.33.060 - Severability. 
    If any clause, sentence, subdivision, paragraph, section or part of the ordinance codified in this chapter be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder thereof, but shall be confined in its operation to the clause, sentence, subdivision, paragraph, section, or part thereof, directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered. 
(Ord. 1324 § 2 (part), 1999) 
Chapter 2.36 - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.36.010 - Establishing regulations. 
    The regulations of the fire department referred to elsewhere in this chapter as the regulations shall be those made and established by the chief with the approval of the public safety committee of the mayor and council and may be amended in like manner. All the regulations made in pursuance hereof shall be in writing and signed by the chairperson of the public safety committee and by the chief of the fire department and shall be filed in the office of the borough clerk and posted in the fire station(s) and shall be binding on all members of the department after such filing and posting. 
(Ord. 828, Art. I § 3, 1964) 
2.36.020 - Chief-Control over department-Acting chief. 
    The chief shall exercise sole and complete control over the entire department, both paid and volunteer members, subject only to the borough council and the public safety committee. The mayor and council or the public safety committee may designate a paid member of the department to serve as acting chief during the absence or disability of the chief. 
(Ord. 828, Art. II § 1, 1964) 
2.36.030 - Chief-Duties generally. 
    The chief shall be the fire marshal and fire inspector of the borough. The chief shall cause all appropriate measures to be taken for the saving of life, limb and property from loss or damage by fire and the hazards thereof. The chief shall see that all laws and ordinances effective in the borough relating to the prevention of fire are enforced. The chief shall be responsible for the enforcement of the fire regulations and all special orders of the mayor and council or its public safety committee. Whenever possible the chief shall take command at every fire and direct the members of the department under him/her in the discharge of their duties. The chief shall by order detail the tours and nature of duty of the members of the department under him/her, with such special instructions as he/she may deem proper. All details of members of the department for any special or particular duty or service shall be made by the chief or pursuant to his/her order. 
(Ord. 828, Art. II § 2, 1964) 
2.36.040 - Purchases. 
    The chief shall check or cause to be checked all materials and supplies purchased for the department to see that they are of the quality and quantity desired and shall check all invoices to be paid out of the department funds to be sure that the service or goods to be paid for were received and were in accordance with the purchase orders or requests made by him/her or pursuant his/her order. 
(Ord. 828, Art. II § 3, 1964) 
2.36.050 - Chief-Reports. 
    The chief shall keep a service record of each member of the department, including therein a record of any violation of the regulations and any commendation or citation for excellent work or exceptional bravery. In case of the occurrence of any vacancy in the department for any cause the chief shall notify the public safety committee at once of such fact. The chief shall keep a full record of all fire calls and all particulars relating thereto including the time and place, the type of fire and amount of loss. The chief shall also keep a record of any other functions of the department. The chief shall prepare and present promptly to the mayor and council monthly and annual reports of the operation of the department including the number and character of the alarms received and responded to, the number of members of the department and equipment responding, the location of each fire or cause of alarm, and such other particulars in relation thereto as he/she or the public safety committee may deem necessary or proper. 
(Ord. 828, Art. II § 4, 1964) 
2.36.060 - Other officers. 
    The other officers of the department shall perform the duties prescribed by the regulations or assigned by the chief. 
(Ord. 828, Art. II § 5, 1964) 
2.36.070 - Surgeon. 
    In case of the unavailability of the police and fire surgeon a reputable physician of the borough may be designated to act in place by the chief, acting chief or the public safety committee. 
(Ord. 828, Art. II § 6, 1964) 
2.36.080 - Member qualifications. 
    Before any person can hereafter be appointed a paid probationary member of the department, he or she shall fulfill the following qualifications for membership: 
A.	Be able to read and write the English language; 
B.	Meet the residence requirements specified by state law; 
C.	Be a legally qualified voter of the state of New Jersey; 
D.	Never have been convicted of crime involving moral turpitude; 
E.	Meet the age requirements specified by state law; 
F.	Be able to present a satisfactory medical certificate; 
G.	Meet the qualifications necessary for membership in the Police and Fireman's Retirement System of New Jersey; 
H.	Satisfactorily pass all applicable examinations written and oral that may be deemed necessary by the public safety committee; and 
I.	Be licensed by the state of New Jersey to operate motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 1, 1964) 
2.36.090 - Applicants-Physical examination. 
    No person shall hereafter be appointed a paid member of the department who shall fail to pass the physical examination by the police and fire surgeon of the borough or who, in the written opinion of an examining physician designated by the public safety committee for such purpose, appears from such physical examination incapable of performing appropriate duties in the department with efficiency and safety. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 2, 1964) 
2.36.100 - Applicants-Examination. 
    Any examinations, written, oral and physical, prescribed by the public safety committee, where more than one candidate applies for appointment at the same time, shall be competitive as between the candidates, and appointment shall be made from among those who have passed the examinations. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 3, 1964) 
2.36.110 - Probation period. 
    Each applicant to be selected as aforesaid shall be required to serve for a probationary period of one year. During such period he or she shall be assigned to regular duty in the department. If the mayor and council during such period shall determine in its discretion that he or she does not possess the ability and character for regular membership in the department, or the necessity of his/her employment no longer exists, he or she shall be dismissed. Such dismissal shall completely terminate his/her services. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 4, 1964) 
2.36.120 - Grades-Salaries. 
    The grades, salaries and compensation of the paid members of the department shall be fixed and determined by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 5, 1964) 
2.36.130 - Tenure of office-Removal from office-Reduction of personnel. 
    The paid officers and paid fire fighters employed in the department shall severally hold their respective offices and continue in their respective employments during good behavior and efficiency, and no person shall be removed from office or employment in the paid department for any cause other than incapacity, misconduct, or disobedience of the regulations of the department which may be established from time to time as provided in Section 2.36.010 for the regulation of the department; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent the reduction in personnel of the department when the mayor and council shall determine that the public welfare so requires. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 6, 1964) 
2.36.140 - Chief may suspend from duty. 
    The chief shall have the authority to suspend from duty pending a final hearing of charges any member of the department for incapacity, misconduct or disobedience of the regulations of the department. Any member so suspended from duty shall not return to duty until directed by the mayor and council or the public safety committee thereof. The chief shall immediately prepare and present charges as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 7, 1964) 
2.36.150 - Procedure for suspending, removing, fining, reducing in office or grade. 
    No member of the department shall be suspended, removed, fined or reduced in grade until: 
A.	Written charge of the cause of complaint shall have been preferred against a member of the department signed by the person making the charge and filed in the office of the borough clerk and a copy thereof served upon such person within fifteen days after the filing thereof and 
B.	The charge has been publicly examined by the public safety committee and by the mayor and council upon reasonable notice to the person charged, which examination shall commence not less than fifteen days nor more than thirty days after such copy of charges has been served, then any member of the department may be suspended, removed, fined or reduced in his or her office or in his or her grade if such charges are substantiated. However for any dereliction of duty for which a penalty less than suspension, removal, fine or reduction in office or in grade may be appropriate, the chief may impose an appropriate penalty. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 8, 1964) 
2.36.160 - Special services. 
    All applications for special services must be referred to the chief. No special duty shall be performed by paid employees of the department without direct authority in each instance from the chief. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 9, 1964) 
2.36.170 - Outside jobs-Absence from duty. 
    The paid members of the department shall not engage in any business or occupation that interferes with their attention to their duties in the department or handicaps them in the performance of their duties in the department, and no member of the department shall absent himself from duty without the permission of the chief. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 10, 1964) 
2.36.180 - Political activities. 
    No paid member of the department shall actively engage in electioneering or other proceedings of a political or party nature; nor shall he or she be present at the polls of any election, except such reasonable time as may be required by him or her for the purpose of voting or unless he or she shall be directed by the chief to be present for purposes of fire prevention. 
(Ord. 828, Art. III § 11, 1964) 
2.36.190 - Volunteers-Application for appointment. 
    Any person desiring appointment as a volunteer fire fighter shall make written application therefor to the chief. 
(Ord. 828, Art. IV § 1, 1964) 
2.36.200 - Volunteers-Appointment-Dismissal. 
    On the recommendation of the chief, volunteer fire fighters may be appointed to the department by the mayor and council and shall hold office until they resign or are discharged, with or without cause, by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 828, Art. IV § 2, 1964) 
2.36.210 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.	No person shall raise, create or continue a false alarm of fire under penalty, upon conviction of a fine not to exceed twenty-five dollars for each offense, or of imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed thirty days. 
B.	No person shall drive any vehicle over any hose or other fire apparatus under penalty, upon conviction, of a fine not to exceed twenty-five dollars for each offense, or of imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed thirty days. 
(Ord. 828, Art. V § 1, 1964) 
2.36.220 - Protection of property-Use of fire hydrants. 
A.	In case of a fire occurring in any dwelling, house or other building within the limits of the borough, the fire department shall have full charge of the extinguishing of such fire on arrival at the scene thereof, and no person shall in any way interfere with or attempt to serve in any capacity in the matter of extinguishing such fire except under the authority and control and subject to the orders of the officers of the fire department. 
B.	No person other than those specifically authorized and empowered by the mayor and council of the borough, either individually or as officers or members of an authorized fire company or organization, shall in any way open, close or interfere with any one of the public fire hydrants within the limits of the borough. 
C.	The constables and marshals of the borough shall be authorized and directed in case of fire occurring within the limits of the borough to man and take charge of fire hydrants in the vicinity of the fire, and to prevent the interference by any unauthorized person or persons with such fire hydrants. 
D.	In case of fire occurring within the limits of the borough, no person other than those authorized as a fire fighter in accordance with this section shall come within the space of one hundred feet of the building in which the fire may occur, or such other limits as may be fixed by the proper officers of the duly authorized fire company or organization. 
E.	Any person, persons or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be liable to a penalty of five dollars for each offense. 
(Ord. 370 § 1, 1924; Ord. 48 §§ 1-5, 1899) 
Chapter 2.40 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY 
Sections: 

2.40.010 - Established-Powers and duties. 
    There is established a public safety committee consisting of three members of the borough council. They shall be appointed annually by the mayor who shall designate one of their members chairperson. This committee shall have among other powers and duties the following: 
A.	Administrative control of the department of public safety. 
B.	Enforcement of ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to the department of public safety and its divisions. 
C.	Promulgation and enforcement of such administrative rules as in its judgment may from time to time be necessary for the efficient operation and management of the department of public safety. 
D.	Reporting to the mayor and council from time to time such matters having to do with the department of public safety as may require the action of the mayor and council with the recommendations of the public safety committee thereon, and performing such other acts in connection therewith as may be prescribed by the mayor and council. 
E.	Consistent with state law, providing rules governing the promotion and hiring of members of the department of public safety. 
F.	Examination of all applicants for positions in the department of public safety and recommendations to the mayor and council of such persons as they may deem suited for such positions. 
(Ord. 1063 § 1, 1982) 
2.40.020 - Organization. 
A.	Purpose. It is the belief of the mayor and members of the council that creation of a department of public safety will: 
1.	Permit more effective leadership and administration; 
2.	Establish a single point of responsibility which will improve relationship with the borough council through better communications; 
3.	Increase flexibility in assigning tasks to public safety personnel; 
4.	Eliminate duplicative functions and enable consolidation of duties to achieve greater efficiency and economy in the public safety area; 
5.	Improve relationship between all members of the police and fire divisions of the department of public safety. 
    It is in the best interest of the residents and government of the borough. 
B.	Establishment. There is created the department of public safety which shall consist of: 
1.	Police uniform division; 
2.	Detective division; 
3.	Fire division; 
4.	Administrative service division. 
C.	Office of Director of Public Safety. There is created the office of director of public safety. 
D.	The director of public safety, appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council, shall be the chief administrative officer responsible and accountable for all aspects of public safety in the borough. The director shall have such authority as is necessary to carry out the purpose of the department subject to the public safety committee supervision, including the authority to: 
1.	Promulgate rules, regulations and operating procedures, subject to approval of the public safety committee, for all divisions of the department; 
2.	Supervise the implementation of work schedules of all personnel of the department; 
3.	Prepare necessary budgets for all divisions of the department and be responsible for all financial matters pertaining to the department; 
4.	Assume responsibility for all personnel matters of the department including supervision of training, establishing employment standards, enforcement of discipline, maintenance of personnel records of all department employees; 
5.	Provide such technical and other assistance as is necessary to the divisions for their proper functions. 
(Ord. 1063 § 2, 1982) 
2.40.030 - Police uniform division. 
    The police uniform division shall be headed by a superior police officer of the police division(s) appointed by the mayor with the approval of the borough council. The division shall consist of such additional officers and patrol officers as may be necessary as determined by the director of public safety upon the recommendations of the chief, if any, and the approval of the mayor and council, to efficiently fulfill the duties assigned to the division. This division will be responsible for the conduct and operation of the main police desk. 
(Ord. 1063 § 3, 1982) 
2.40.040 - Detective division. 
A.	The detective division shall be headed by a superior officer of the police division(s) appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council. The division shall consist of such additional officers and patrol officers as may be necessary, as determined by the director of public safety, upon the recommendations of the chief, if any, and the approval of the mayor and council to efficiently fulfill the duties assigned to the division. The officer in charge shall receive the salary designated by ordinance for his or her rank. 
B.	The officer in charge of the detective division is particularly charged with the prevention of crime and required investigation of criminal offenses in the borough, the detection and arrest of criminal offenders, the locating of missing persons, the recovery of lost or stolen property, proper cooperation with other law enforcement agencies, the proper conduct of fugitive requisition proceedings, the responsibility of giving and providing vigilant scrutiny to, and taking proper cognizance of, all conditions relating to or tending toward the fostering of crime, including gambling in any form, and any other matter which the director of public safety shall determine are the special duties of the detective bureau. Any other officer or patrol officer assigned to the bureau shall assist the officer in charge in all matters. 
C.	The grade of detective shall be of a temporary nature and shall apply to patrol officers when assigned by the director of public safety to the detective bureau of the division. 
(Ord. 1063 § 4, 1982) 
2.40.050 - Administrative services division. 
    The administrative services division shall be headed by a superior officer of the police division(s) appointed by the mayor with the approval of the borough council. The division shall consist of such additional officers and patrol officers as may be necessary as determined by the director of public safety upon the recommendations of the chief, if any, and the approval of the mayor and borough council, to efficiently fulfill the duties assigned to the division. This division shall include a unit for keeping records and evidence. The school crossing guards and community service officers shall be a part of this division. 
(Ord. 1092 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1063 § 5, 1982) 
2.40.060 - Officer in charge-Police division(s). 
    The mayor with the advice and consent of the council may appoint a chief of police who shall be the officer in charge, subject to the public safety director, of the police uniform division, the detective division and the administrative services division. The chief of police may be the director of public safety, if he or she meets the statutory requirements, or such other superior officer of the division(s) as may be selected. 
(Ord. 1063 § 6, 1982) 
2.40.070 - Members-Police division(s). 
    The members of the police uniform division, the detective division and the administrative services division may consist of one chief, up to one captain, up to three patrol lieutenants, up to five sergeants, a seventeen patrol officers and up to two provisional officers, as the mayor and borough council may appoint. 
(Ord. 1444 § 1, 2006) 
2.40.080 - Duties and responsibilities-Police division(s). 
    The duties and responsibilities of the members of the police division(s) shall be as follows: 
A.	Chief. The chief, if any, shall be the officer in charge of the police uniform division, the detective division and of the administrative services division and perform all of the functions and duties assigned to the chief of police under Section 2.32.040 which provisions are incorporated in this chapter by reference and as provided by statute and regulation subject to and limited by the duties and responsibilities delegated to the director of public safety by this chapter and as hereafter determined by the committee of public safety, with the approval of the mayor and council. 
B.	Lieutenants. A lieutenant shall be assigned such duty as the director of public safety, or chief, may direct. A lieutenant shall promptly obey orders of the director of public safety and chief and shall assist and cooperate with them in every way in the performance of his or her duty. When on desk duty, the lieutenants shall conform to all rules and regulations governing the actions of a desk officer. 
C.	Sergeants. Sergeants in the police division(s) shall rank next below the lieutenants. Their duties and responsibilities are as contained in Section 2.32.050 which provisions are incorporated herein by reference. 
D.	Detectives. Detectives in the police division(s) shall rank next below the sergeants. 
E.	Desk Officer. The duties and responsibilities of the desk officer of the police division(s) are contained in Section 2.32.060 which provisions are incorporated herein by reference, except that any reference in that section to the chief of police shall be amended and construed to refer to the director of public safety. 
(Ord. 1063 § 8, 1982) 
2.40.090 - Fire division. 
    The borough fire division shall consist of a uniformed force of paid fire fighters and such volunteer fire fighters as may be required, subject to such rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the public safety committee, upon recommendation of the director of public safety and the chief, if any, and approved by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 1063 § 9, 1982) 
2.40.100 - Officer in charge-Fire division. 
    The mayor with the advice and consent of the council may appoint one of the members of the fire division as a chief who shall be the officer in charge, subject to the public safety director, of the fire division. The fire chief may be the director of public safety, if he or she meets the statutory requirements, or such other superior officer of the division as may be selected. 
(Ord. 1063 § 10, 1982) 
2.40.110 - Members-Fire division. 
    The uniformed paid members of the fire division may consist of a chief and such number of lieutenants and other officers, fire fighters, probationary fire fighters and relief fire fighters as the mayor and council may appoint. 
(Ord. 1063 § 11, 1982) 
2.40.120 - Duties and responsibilities-Fire division. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the members of the fire division shall be as follows: 
A.	Chief. The chief, if any, shall be the officer in charge of the fire division and perform all of the functions and duties assigned to the chief of fire under Sections 2.36.020 through 2.36.050 of the borough which provisions are herein incorporated by reference and provided by statute and regulation subject to and limited by the duties and responsibilities delegated to the director of public safety by this chapter and as hereafter determined by the committee of public safety, with the approval of the mayor and council. 
B.	Other Officers. The other officers of the department shall perform the duties prescribed by the regulations promulgated by the public safety committee, upon the recommendation of the director of public safety and chief, if any, and approved by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 1063 § 12, 1982) 
2.40.130 - Ordinance enforcement officer and parking enforcement officer. 
A.	It has been determined by the mayor and the borough council that there is a need for an ordinance enforcement officer and a parking enforcement officer in the Borough of Glen Ridge, county of Essex and state of New Jersey. 
B.	There is created the titles of ordinance enforcement officer and parking enforcement officer in the department of public safety of the Borough of Glen Ridge. 
C.	The individual(s) holding these titles shall report to the director of public safety or his designee. They shall be responsible to perform the duties as contained in the job descriptions entitled "Ordinance Enforcement Officer and Parking Enforcement Officer." 
D.	The salaries for these titles shall be as adopted in the salary ordinance of the Borough of Glen Ridge and the annual salary resolution, as adopted, by the borough council. 
(Ord. 1291, §§ 1-3, 1997) 
2.40.140 - Designation of the national incident management system (NIMS) as the basis for all critical incident management in the borough of Glen Ridge, county of Essex. 
A.	The President of the United States, in Homeland Security Presidential Directive (HSPD)-5, directed the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to develop and administer a national incident management system (NIMS), which would provide consistent nationwide approach for federal, state, local and tribal governments to work together more effectively and efficiently to prevent, prepare for, respond to and answer from domestic incidents, regardless of cause, size or complexity. 
B.	Richard J. Cody, acting governor of the state of New Jersey, in Executive Order 50, ordered and directed that there is established an incident management system in New Jersey, which shall be the national management system (NIMS) and that NIMS shall be the state standard for incident management and it shall be used for all emergencies incidents in the state and all first responders shall complete the NIMS awareness course, national incident management system, (NIMS). 
C.	Executive Order 50 additionally ordered and directed all county and municipal offices of emergency management to incorporate the NIMS into county and/or municipal emergency operations plan (EOP) during the next update to said EOP pursuant to N.J.S.A. APP.A: 9-43.2, and all responses conducted pursuant to the state EOP, or any county or municipal EOP, shall be conducted in accordance with the NIMS and all first responders shall annually participate in multi-discipline exercises and drills that utilize NIMS. 
D.	The collective input and guidance from federal, state, local and tribal homeland security partners has been and will continue to be, vital to the development, effective implementation and utilization of a comprehensive NIMS. 
E.	It is necessary and desirable that all federal, state, local and tribal emergencies agencies and personnel coordinate their efforts to effectively and efficiently provide the highest levels of incident management. 
F.	To facilitate the most efficient and effective incident management, it is critical that federal, state, local and tribal organizations utilize standardized terminology, standardized organizational structures, interoperability communications, consolidation action plans, unified command structures, uniform personnel qualifications standards, uniform standards for planning, training and exercising, comprehensive resource management and designated incident facilities during emergencies or disasters. 
G.	The NIMS standardize procedures for managing personnel, communications, facilities and resources will improve the state's and the county of Essex ability to utilize federal funding to enhance local and state readiness, maintain first responder safety, and streamline incident management process. 
H.	The incident command system components of NIMS are already an integral part of various management activities throughout the state, including current emergency management training programs. 
I.	The National Commission on Terrorist Attacks (9-11 Commission) recommended adoption of a standardized incident command system. 
J.	Be it resolved, by the mayor and the borough council of the borough of Glen Ridge, in the county of Essex, in the state of New Jersey that the national incident management system (NIMS) be and adopted and established as the standard for all incident management in the borough of Glen Ridge, county of Essex and in the state of New Jersey and shall be utilized for all emergencies incidents. 
(Ord. 1484, 2007) 
Chapter 2.44 - PLANNING BOARD 
Sections: 

2.44.010 - Definitions. 
    Whenever a term is used in this chapter which is defined in N.J.S.A. 40:55D-1 et seq., such term is intended to have the meaning set forth in the definitions of such term found in said statute, unless a contrary intention is clearly expressed from the context of this chapter. 
(Ord. 990 § 3.100, 1976) 
2.44.020 - Establishment. 
    There is established pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:55D-23 in the borough a planning board of nine members. 
(Ord. 990 § 1.100, 1976) 
2.44.030 - Alternate members. 
    The governing body may, pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:55D-23.1, appoint to the planning board not more than two alternate members. 
(Ord. 1084 § 1, 1984) 
2.44.040 - Minor subdivisions. 
    The planning board is empowered to consider and pass upon applications for minor subdivisions. A minor subdivision shall be a subdivision of ten or fewer lots. 
(Ord. 996 § 1 (part), 1977) 
2.44.050 - Waiver of notice. 
    The planning board is authorized pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:55D-47 to waive notice and public hearing on an application for a minor subdivision. 
(Ord. 996 § 1 (part), 1977) 
2.44.060 - Notice of hearings and decisions. 
    A brief notice of every hearing and final decision of the planning board or board of adjustment shall be published in the official newspaper of the municipality by the secretary of the board. 
(Ord. 1012 § 1, 1978) 
2.44.070 - Fees. 
    Fees for applications or for the rendering of any service by the planning board or zoning board of adjustment or any member of their administrative staffs which is not otherwise provided by ordinance may be provided for and adopted as part of the rules of the board and copies of said rules or of the separate fee schedule shall be available to the public. 
(Ord. 1012 § 2, 1978) 
2.44.080 - Payment of taxes. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:55 D-39 and N.J.S.A. 40:55D-65, every application for development submitted to the planning board or to the zoning board of adjustment shall be accompanied by proof that no taxes or assessments for local improvements are due or delinquent on the property which is the subject of such applications; or, if it is shown that taxes or assessments are delinquent on said property, any approvals or other relief granted by either board shall be conditioned upon either the prompt payment of such taxes or assessments, or the making of adequate provision for the payment thereof in such manner that the municipality will be adequately protected. 
(Ord. 990 § 2.110, 1976) 
2.44.090 - Board of adjustment-Fees. 
    The following fees shall be assessed for the filing of an application for a variance to the zoning ordinance of the borough: 
A.	For an application relative to an alteration to a single-family dwelling, a garage on a single-family lot, a fence or other variances requested relating to residential properties, a filing fee of thirty-five dollars shall be paid by the applicant. 
B.	For an application relative to business and commercial properties, residential properties and apartments where an estimated cost of construction will not exceed five hundred thousand dollars, a filing fee of seventy-five dollars shall be paid by the applicant. 
C.	When an estimated cost of construction will exceed five hundred thousand dollars, a filing fee of one hundred dollars shall be paid by all applicants. 
(Ord. 1012 § 3, 1978) 
Chapter 2.52 - BOARD OF HEALTH 
Sections: 

2.52.010 - Appointment. 
    At the first meeting after the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter, or as soon thereafter as possible, the mayor and council shall appoint a board of health consisting of seven members. In each succeeding year thereafter the mayor and council shall in the same manner appoint successors to the members whose terms expire but in such case such appointments shall be for the term of two years only. 
(Ord. 1 § 1, 1895) 
(Ord. No. 1525, § 1, 9-14-2009) 
2.52.020 - Terms. 
    The term of office of members appointed in accordance with Section 2.52.010 shall begin at noon on the first day of January and continue for two years, or until their successors have been appointed and have qualified. 
(Ord. 249 § 1, 1915: Ord. 1 § 2, 1895) 
2.52.030 - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the board to enact and to put in operation ordinances or a code for the preservation of the public health in accordance with the laws of the state, and said board shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as are conferred or devolved upon it by the laws of this state. 
(Ord. 1 § 3, 1895) 
2.52.040 - Vacancies. 
    The mayor and council shall have power to fill vacancies in such board for whatever cause arising, but in that event for the unexpired term only. 
(Ord. 1 § 4, 1895) 
Chapter 2.56 - MUNICIPAL COURT 
Sections: 

2.56.010 - Established. 
    A municipal court for Glen Ridge is established as of January 1, 1949, pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 264 of the Laws of 1948, as amended and supplemented. 
(Ord. 648 § 1, 1948) 
2.56.020 - Name. 
    The name of the municipal court shall be "Municipal Court of Glen Ridge." 
(Ord. 648 § 2, 1948) 
2.56.030 - Seal. 
    The municipal court shall have a seal which shall bear the impress of the name of the court. 
(Ord. 648 § 3, 1948) 
2.56.040 - Magistrate-Appointment and term. 
    There shall be a municipal magistrate of the municipal court who shall have the qualifications required by law and rules of court, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council and who shall serve for a term of three years from the date of his or her appointment and until a successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. 648 § 4, 1948) 
2.56.050 - Magistrate-Salary. 
    The municipal magistrate shall receive an annual salary to be established by ordinance, to be paid in the same manner as the salaries of other municipal officers are paid, and which shall be in lieu of all fees, costs, and other allowances whatsoever. 
(Ord. 648 § 5, 1948) 
2.56.060 - Magistrate-Powers and duties. 
    The municipal court and the municipal magistrate thereof shall have, possess and exercise all the functions, powers, duties and jurisdiction conferred by the provisions of Chapter 264 of the Laws of 1948, as amended and supplemented, or by any other law. 
(Ord. 648 § 6, 1948) 
2.56.070 - Location. 
    The municipal court shall be held in the courtroom at Police Headquarters, Municipal Building. 
(Ord. 648 § 7, 1948) 
Chapter 2.60 - MUNICIPAL LIBRARY 
Sections: 

2.60.010 - Rules and regulations. 
    The library board shall adopt and post in a conspicuous place in the free public library building, rules, regulations and procedures governing the borrowing of books, periodicals, pamphlets, or any other item or article which may be available for such borrowing to the public. 
(Ord. 1072 § 3, 1983) 
2.60.020 - Returning overdue materials. 
    No person shall detain or fail to return any book, periodical, pamphlet, artistic reproduction, phonograph recording, audio visual material or any other article borrowed from the free public library after thirty days have elapsed from the date of posting by certified mail, return receipt requested or a notice demanding the return thereof, addressed to said person at the last address furnished. 
(Ord. 1072 § 1, 1983) 
2.60.030 - Damaging materials prohibited. 
    No person shall cut, tear, deface, disfigure, damage or destroy any book, periodical, pamphlet, artistic reproduction, phonograph recording, audio visual material or other article, or any part thereof, which is borrowed from, owned by or is in the custody of such library. 
(Ord. 1072 § 2, 1983) 
2.60.040 - Removal of materials-Regulations. 
    No person shall remove any book, periodical, pamphlet, artistic reproduction, phonograph recording, audio visual material or any other item or article from the free public library building without complying with the rules, regulations and procedures of the library for borrowing such items or articles. 
(Ord. 1072 § 4, 1983) 
2.60.050 - Overdue material-Filing complaint. 
    The library director is authorized to file a complaint in the municipal court under the following conditions: 
A.	A certified letter, return receipt requested, shall be sent by the library administration after six weeks, informing the person that the book or material is overdue and that he/she is subject to prosecution pursuant to this chapter. 
B.	In the case of a minor, the letter shall be sent to the parents of the minor involved. 
C.	The book, material or article shall be overdue for at least two months. 
(Ord. 1072 § 5, 1983) 
2.60.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates or refuses to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed fifty dollars or twice the cost of the book, whichever is greater, and a penalty of not more than one hundred dollars for the second and each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. 1072 § 6, 1983) 
Chapter 2.64 - PERSONNEL REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

2.64.010 - Paid holidays-Established. 
    The employees of the borough, except for the members of the police and fire departments, are granted twelve paid holidays in each year. Said paid holidays shall be established by resolution of the mayor and council at the annual meeting on January 1st of each year. 
(Ord. 976 § 1, 1975: Ord. 827 § 1, 1964) 
2.64.020 - Vacation entitlements. 
    The following vacation entitlement schedules are adopted for full-time borough employees. Vacation entitlement means the number of days a full-time borough employee shall be allowed during a calendar year. Accumulation of vacation time shall not be permitted except as set forth in Section 2.64.040 of this chapter: 
A.	In the first year of full-time employment, one day for each month of employment, not to exceed ten days. No vacation time shall be granted until the employee has completed six months of satisfactory service unless the needs of the borough require a deviation from this rule. 
B.	Commencing the first full year of employment and each year thereafter through the tenth year of employment, ten days per year. 
C.	Commencing with the eleventh year of employment and each year thereafter through the fifteenth year of employment, thirteen days per year. 
D.	Commencing with the sixteenth year of employment and each year thereafter through the twentieth year of employment, eighteen days per year. 
E.	Commencing with the twenty-first year of employment and each year thereafter twenty days per year. 
F.	The head of one or more department shall be entitled to five vacation days in addition to the number of days to which he or she would otherwise be entitled in accordance with the foregoing schedule. 
G.	The employee's anniversary date of employment must fall on or before June 30th of each year to be eligible for the number of vacation days at each level. If said anniversary date falls on or after July 1st, the additional vacation entitlement becomes effective in the next ensuing calendar year. 
(Ord. 1024 § 1, 1978: Ord. 827 § 3, 1964) 
2.64.030 - Police and fire department vacation days. 
    Members of the paid police and fire departments shall be granted twelve working days off in each year in addition to the vacation days set forth in Section 2.64.020. Such days need not be granted by the chiefs of the departments in conjunction with the regular vacation days set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 827 § 2, 1964) 
2.64.040 - Vacation schedules-Arrangement. 
    Vacation schedules shall be arranged by the head of each department, subject to the approval of the borough administrator having due regard to the needs of the borough, seniority of the employee, and, as far as possible, the wishes of the employee. For the efficient operation of the borough, vacation days may be scheduled on Mondays and Fridays no more than once per calendar month and no more than six times in any one calendar year. Each Monday or Friday taken shall count as one time for the purpose of aggregation of time. Where in any calendar year the vacation or any part thereof is not granted by reason of pressure of borough affairs, and with the approval of the borough administrator prior to the close of the calendar year in which the vacation time was not utilized, such vacation period or part thereof not granted shall accumulate and shall be granted during the succeeding year. Failure to use the accumulated vacation time in the succeeding calendar year will result in the loss of the accumulated time by the employee. Department heads shall be responsible for reporting vacation schedules to the borough clerk as soon as possible after approval of same by the borough administrator as aforementioned. 
(Ord. 1277, 1996: Ord. 1024 § 3, 1978: Ord. 827 § 5, 1964) 
2.64.050 - Sick leave policy. 
A.	1.	As used in this section, "sick leave" means paid leave that may be granted to each full-time borough employee who through sickness or injury becomes incapacitated to a degree that makes it impossible for him or her to perform the duties of his or her position or who is quarantined by a physician because he or she has been exposed to a contagious disease. Part-time and full-time temporary employees are not eligible for sick leave. 
2.	A certificate from the borough physician or the employee's own physician may be required as sufficient proof of the need for sick leave. In case of sick leave due to a contagious disease or exposure to same, a certificate from the department of health shall be required. 
3.	Commencing January 1, 1978 for existing employees and with the date of employment of each new employee, employees shall accumulate sick leave at the rate of one and one-quarter days per month for full-time employees. 
4.	Sick leave can be accumulated to a maximum of two hundred days commencing with January 1, 1978. 
5.	Extension of sick leave beyond the maximum days allowed by this section may be allowed by resolution of the borough council. 
6.	Accumulated sick leave may be used by an employee for personal illness, illness in the employee's immediate family which requires the employee's attendance upon the ill person, quarantine restrictions, pregnancy or disabling injuries. The term "immediate family" for the purposes of this subparagraph shall mean and refer only to the employee's spouse, child, parent or unmarried brother or unmarried sister. 
7.	All absences on account of illness or disability shall be reported immediately by, or for, the employee to the employee's immediate supervisor. If the supervisor cannot be reached promptly, the report should then be made to the office of the borough clerk without further delay. Every absence on account of illness or disability in excess of three days must be certified by a written statement from the attending physician if requested by the employee's department head or the borough council. 
8.	Sick leave with pay will not be allowed under the following conditions: 
a.	If the employee, when under medical care, fails to carry out the orders of the attending physician. 
b.	If, in the opinion of the borough physician, the employee is ill or disabled because of self-imposed contributory causes or actions occasioned by bad habits. 
c.	If, in the opinion of the borough physician, the disability or illness is not of sufficient severity to justify the employee's absence from duty. 
9.	Sick leave cannot be allowed for ordinary dental care, nor for the services of an oculist for normal eye care. 
10.	Upon retirement, terminal leave shall be granted for a total number of weeks or parts thereof equal to the then unused accumulated days of sick leave divided by five. 
B.	1.	When a full-time borough employee is injured in the line of duty, the borough council may, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:11-8 and 9, pass a resolution giving the employee up to one year's leave of absence with pay. When such action is taken, the employee shall not be charged any sick leave time for time lost due to such particular injury. 
2.	Any employee who has been granted a leave of absence with pay as a result of injury in the line of duty and qualifies for payments under workmen's compensation weekly benefits shall during the period the employee is receiving such weekly benefits be entitled only to the difference between his or her regular salary and the workmen's compensation payments. 
C.	1.	In the event of a death in the employee's immediate family (as defined in Section 2.64.050(A)(6)), the department head may grant the employee three days leave of absence, with pay, if deemed necessary. 
2.	Deviation from the foregoing may be granted by a member of the council under special circumstances. 
D.	An employee, upon retirement from employment by reason of age, length of service or disability, as permitted and described under the laws of the state of New Jersey regarding the various employee retirement systems, shall be permitted compensatory time off to one-half of any unused sick leave accumulated during the employee's service to the borough, to a maximum of one hundred days. 
E.	A separate "time record" file shall be kept on each employee of the borough. Each department head shall submit a weekly report to the borough clerk regarding every employee in the clerk's department. This report shall contain the following data: present or absent, sick, holidays, vacation or overtime. 
(Ord. 1016 §§ 1, 2, 1978; Ord. 992 § 1, 1977; Ord. 964 §§ 1, 2, 1974; Ord. 888 § 1, 1968; Ord. 886 §§ 1-3, 1968) 
2.64.060 - Overtime compensation. 
A.	Officers of the police department through the rank of sergeant, officers assigned to the detective bureau excluded; every member of the paid fire department through the rank of lieutenant; and all field personnel of the public works and water departments through the position of field supervisor shall be paid either overtime pay or given compensatory time off, for overtime work performed by the members of the police and fire departments during times of emergencies as defined in N.J.S.A. 40:47-12.12 and for overtime work performed by the personnel of the public works and water departments which is necessary for the health and welfare of the residents of the borough, at the following rate schedule: 
1.	For the police department, computed bi-weekly in excess of eighty hours, at an hourly rate of one and one-half the officer's hourly rate, not including longevity, computed by the officer's annual salary divided by two thousand eighty hours. 
2.	For the fire department, computed bi-weekly, in excess of eighty-four hours, at an hourly rate of one and one-half the member's hourly rate, not including longevity, computed by the officer's annual salary divided by two thousand one hundred eighty-four hours. 
3.	For the public works department, computed bi-weekly in excess of eighty hours, at an hourly rate of one and one-half the employee's hourly rate, not including longevity, computed by the employee's annual salary divided by two thousand eighty hours. Except that when an emergency requires public works employees to work the following holidays: New Year's Day; Memorial Day; July 4th; Labor Day; Thanksgiving Day or Christmas Day; said employee shall be compensated at double the hourly rate computed as aforementioned. 
4.	For the water department, computed bi-weekly in excess of eighty hours at an hourly rate of one and one-half the employee's hourly rate, not including longevity, computed by the employee's annual salary divided two thousand eighty hours. Except that double the employee's hourly rate shall be paid when said employee is required to work on any of the six holidays listed in subparagraph 3. 
B.	Overtime pay shall not be made part of the employee's regular pay for pension purposes. 
C.	In computing overtime compensation, the nearest one-half hour shall be the smallest fraction of an hour to be reported. 
D.	Department heads are charged with the responsibility of administering overtime. Regulations that are consistent with this section must be set up as a guideline. Periodic review of overtime requirements shall be taken with a view toward devising methods to accomplish the work during regular work shifts. 
E.	Department heads will submit a report to the borough council at the close of each month. Said report to summarize and justify the overtime paid to each employee named and the purpose for overtime, in the preceding month. 
F.	Clerical employees who incur overtime in excess of eighty hours, computed bi-weekly, at an hourly rate of one and one-half the employee's hourly rate, not including longevity, computed by the employee's annual salary divided by two thousand eighty hours. 
G.	Any request for deviation form any subsection of this section must be made in writing, by the department head, to the borough council. 
(Ord. 962 §§ 1, 2, 1974; Ord. 891 §§ 1-7, 1969) 
2.64.070 - Waiver of statutes in certain cases. 
A.	An act of the Legislature of the state of New Jersey, designated as Chapter 174 of the Laws of 1964, entitled "An Act to authorize the governing body of the Borough of Glen Ridge, in the County of Essex, to waive, in certain cases, the provisions of the general statutes which require that members of its police force and paid fire department must reside within the Borough" is adopted. 
B.	The borough may appoint and keep in its employ present and future officers or members of its police force or paid fire department, notwithstanding that the same do not meet the residence requirements specified by P.L. 1946, Chapter 25, and P.L. 1953, Chapter 107 (both as amended or supplemented), or by any other applicable law; provided, however, that: 
1.	The mayor and council shall find as a fact that adherence to said residence requirements in each particular case would seriously impede its ability to establish and maintain competent personnel for its police force or paid fire department, and that the appointment or continued employment of a named officer of member of its police force or paid fire department is deemed necessary to the proper establishment and operation of said police force or paid fire department; and 
2.	That the place of residence of such member or officer is within the county of Essex, or, if not, is within a distance of not over ten miles from the border of said borough and, in either case, is at a distance which, in the light of the functions, duties and assignments of such officer or member, will not adversely affect the efficient operation of said police force or paid fire department; and 
3.	A resolution embodying the foregoing findings shall be adopted authorizing the appointment or continued employment of such named officer or member of said police force or paid fire department, notwithstanding that he or she is not a resident of said borough and fixing the maximum distance, within the limits above provided, at which he or she may reside. 
(Ord. 833 §§ 1, 2, 1964) 
Chapter 2.68 - MUNICIPAL ALLIANCE COMMITTEE 
Sections: 

2.68.010 - Created. 
    Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 26:2BB-9 there is created in the borough a municipal alliance committee. 
(Ord. 1181 § 1, 1990) 
2.68.020 - Duties. 
    The municipal alliance committee, in conjunction with the local advisory committee on alcoholism and drug abuse, shall identify alcoholism and drug prevention, education and community needs. The committee also shall implement the alliance programs formulated pursuant to Section 8 of P.L. 1989, c. 51 (N.J.S.A. 26:2BB-8) and generally perform all functions and duties authorized by N.J.S.A. 26:2BB-1 et seq., as may hereafter be supplemented and amended. 
(Ord. 1181 § 2, 1990) 
2.68.030 - Membership-Appointment-Terms. 
A.	The municipal alliance committee shall consist of eleven regular members and ex officio members as deemed necessary to perform the duties required of the committee by statute. The regular committee members shall consist of: the director of public safety; the judge of the municipal court; one member of the borough council; one member of the Glen Ridge board of education, or the superintendent of schools for the borough; the substance abuse counsellor of the Glen Ridge board of education; the borough director of recreation; a representative of the Glen Ridge athletic association; a representative of the Glen Ridge High School student council; and three public members. 
B.	The ex officio members shall consist of the juvenile officer of the division of police of the Glen Ridge department of public safety; the principals of the Glen Ridge public schools; a member of the clergy; plus such additional public members as may be appointed. 
C.	Appointments are to be made by the mayor with the advice and consent of the borough council. 
D.	The term of office will be for one year, commencing January 1st, and expire on December 31st of each year. Terms of office for the initial committee will expire on December 31, 1990. 
E.	The chairperson shall be a public member of the committee to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the borough council. 
F.	Any vacancy occurring by reason of death, resignation or removal for cause of any member shall be filled by the mayor with the advice and consent of the borough council for the unexpired term of such member. 
(Ord. 1181 § 3, 1990) 
Chapter 2.76 - DOMESTIC VIOLENCE INTERVENTION TEAM 
Sections: 

2.76.010 - Statement of policy. 
    In 1991, the New Jersey Legislature passed the Prevention of Domestic Violence Act of 1991, N.J.S.A. 2C: 25-17, et seq., (the "Act"), having determined that domestic violence is a serious crime against society with victims from all social and economic backgrounds. Pursuant to the Act, crisis intervention teams of trained residents can be formed to assist police authorities in dealing with domestic violence cases. The Glen Ridge domestic violence intervention team would assist victims of domestic violence by providing information in available resources and referrals and acting as a liaison with the police and other agencies, as appropriate. 
(Ord. 1342 (part), 2000) 
2.76.020 - Establishment of team-Qualification for membership-Appointment, coordinator. 
    There is created the borough of Glen Ridge domestic violence crisis intervention team. The team shall consist of an unlimited number of volunteers who shall be at least twenty-one years of age. All team members shall serve without compensation. Interested persons shall complete an application form supplied by the borough, be fingerprinted by the police department and subject to a background check. Members of the team shall be appointed by resolution of the borough council upon recommendations of the mayor. The borough council shall also by resolution and upon recommendation by the mayor appoint certain team members as coordinators. All coordinators and other team members shall be supervised by the police department and shall serve at the discretion of the borough council. 
(Ord. 1496, 2008; Ord. 1342 (part), 2000) 
2.76.030 - Training program. 
    No person may serve as a team member unless he/she shall have first completed a forty-hour training program specializing in domestic violence crisis intervention team matters. This training further provides confidentiality protection to the member in comportment with N.J.S.A. 2A: 84A-22, et seq. 
(Ord. 1342 (part), 2000) 
2.76.040 - Functions and duties. 
    The functions and duties of the team shall include, but not limited to: 
A.	Meeting with victims of domestic violence to provide support, compassion and advice; 
B.	Providing information on available resources, appropriate agencies, hot lines and the like and serving as a liaison with police and other agencies as appropriate; 
C.	Such other functions and duties as may be established by the police department. 
(Ord. 1342 (part), 2000) 
2.76.050 - Annual report. 
    The police department shall prepare and submit to the mayor and borough council an annual report summarizing the activities of the team and any recommendations it sees fit to make. 
(Ord. 1342 (part), 2000) 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.04 - CLAIMS AGAINST THE BOROUGH 
Sections: 

3.04.010 - Form of claims. 
    All claims against the borough shall be presented in writing, fully itemized, on such voucher forms as shall be provided for that purpose and all vouchers shall be certified to by the claimant. 
(Ord. 817 § 1, 1963) 
(Ord. No. 1627, 4-13-2015) 
3.04.020 - Checking of claims. 
    All vouchers shall be reviewed and checked by, or under the direction of, the borough official in charge of the department responsible for the claim and if found correct the official shall complete the "officer's certification" thereon. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief financial officer or his or her designated representative to audit, warrant and make recommendations on all claims, bills and demands to ascertain that proper administrative procedures have been followed and that the goods and/or services are consistent with an existing contract or purchase order. 
    All vouchers shall thereafter be presented to the borough administrator, who, if satisfied with the propriety of the claim, shall so note his/her approval and refer the voucher to the borough treasurer. The treasurer shall then prepare checks and bill list, which shall then be forwarded to the borough clerk for presentation to the mayor and borough council at a meeting of said body. 
    The governing body shall approve payment or shall state its reason for rejecting the same. Any disproved claim shall be sent to the borough administrator with the reason for refusal and instructions. 
    The borough clerk shall record all claims in the official minutes, together with the governing body's disposition of the same. Such records shall be available for public inspection. 
    Vouchers for statutory payments, payrolls, investments, utilities and other periodic recurring payments required to be made by the Borough of Glen Ridge between formal public meetings of the governing body may be certified by the borough administrator and sent to the treasurer for disbursement. All such payments shall require ratification by the governing body at the formal public meeting of the governing body next following payment. 
(Ord. 817 § 2, 1963) 
(Ord. No. 1627, 4-13-2015) 
3.04.030 - Presentation to council. 
    The vouchers shall thereafter be presented to the chairperson of the council committee having primary interest in the department responsible for the claim who, if satisfied with the propriety of the claim, shall approve and return the same to the borough clerk for referral to the finance committee. 
(Ord. 817 § 3, 1963) 
3.04.040 - Approval by finance committee. 
A.	The chairperson of the finance committee, or in the chairperson's absence some other member of the committee, shall examine all vouchers referred by the borough clerk and if approved such approval shall be noted upon the vouchers and the vouchers returned to the borough clerk for presentation to the council for approval and authorization to pay the same. 
B.	All vouchers approved for payment pursuant to the foregoing shall be presented to the council at a regular meeting of said body. 
(Ord. 817 §§ 4, 5, 1963) 
3.04.050 - Approval of claims. 
    Council approval of the claims and authorization to draw the warrants to pay the same shall be by resolution adopted by an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the whole council. 
(Ord. 817 § 6, 1963) 
Chapter 3.08 - FEES FOR MUNICIPAL SERVICES 
Sections: 

3.08.010 - Fees for copies of records. 
    The following fees are established for the issuance of copies of such records of the borough: 
A. Birth Records $10.00 per copy B. Death Records $10.00 per copy C. Marriage Records $10.00 per copy D. Telephone Order $ 5.00 per order E. Shipping $ 5.00 per order F. Express Shipping $15.00 per order G. Corrections-All records $ 5.00 per copy H. Domestic Partnership Application $28.00 I. Certified Domestic Partnership Records $10.00 per copy J. Civil Unions $28.00 K. Performance of a Marriage or Civil Union Ceremony $100.00  
    There shall be the establishment of the fee of one hundred dollars per certificate for the issuance of a duplicate tax sale certificate in accordance with Chapter 99 Public Laws of 1997. 
(Ord. 1469 § 1, 2007; Ord. 1415 § 1, 2005; Ord. 1404 § 1, 2004; Ord. 1306 §§ 1, 2, 1998: Ord. 1170 § 1, 1989) 
3.08.020 - Application fee for representation by public defender. 
    The municipal court may require a person applying for representation by an assigned public defender to pay an application fee of not more than two hundred dollars. The municipal court may waive the required fee, in whole or in part, if the court determines, in its discretion, that the application fee represents an unreasonable burden on the person seeking the representation. 
(Ord. 1353 § 1, 2001: Ord. 1274 § 1, 1996) 
3.08.030 - Annual fee schedule. 
    The mayor and council shall by resolution adopt an annual fee schedule, the same may be changed or altered from time to time by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 1417 § 1, 2004) 
Title 4 - CONTRACTS[1] 
Chapters: 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1566, §§ 1-8, adopted Sept. 12, 2011, added provisions to the code, but did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, at the direction of the borough, said ordinance was codified as Title 4, Ch. 4.04. 

Chapter 4.04 - CONTRACTOR PAY-TO-PLAY REFORM 
Sections: 

4.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Campaign committee" means (i) every candidate for [the] borough elective municipal office; (ii) every candidate committee established by or for the benefit of a candidate for [the] borough elective municipal office; (iii) every joint candidate committee established in whole or in part by or for the benefit of a candidate for [the] borough elective municipal office; (iv) every political party committee of the borough; (v) every political party committee of the county of Essex; and (vi) every political committee, continuing political committee, or other form of association or organization that regularly engages in the support of candidates for the borough municipal or county of Essex elective offices or [the] borough municipal or county of Essex political parties or political party committees. The terms in the foregoing paragraph have the meaning prescribed in N.J.A.C. 19:25-1.7. 
    "Contribution" has the meaning prescribed in N.J.A.C. 19:25-1.7. By way of illustration, and not limitation, this definition includes pledges, loans, and in-kind contributions. 
    A "contract for professional or extraordinary services" means all contracts for "professional services" and "extraordinary unspecifiable services" as such term is used in N.J.S.A. 40A:11-5. 
    For purposes of this chapter, a "business entity" whose contributions are regulated by this chapter means: (i) an individual including the individual's spouse, and any child/children; (ii) a firm; corporation; professional corporation; partnership; limited liability company; organization; association; and any other manner and kind of business entity; (iii) any person who owns ten percent or more of the equity or ownership or income interests in a person or entity as defined in sections (i) and (ii) above and their spouses and child/children; (iv) all partners or officers of such an entity, in the aggregate, and their spouses and child/children; (v) any person, subcontractor, subsidiary, corporation, firm, partnership, limited liability company, organization or association who has received or indefeasibly acquired the right to receive, from a person described in subparagraph (i) above, more than one hundred thousand dollars in compensation or income of any kind (including, by way of illustration, and not limitation: wages, salaries, sums paid to independent contractors, benefits, dividends, profit-sharing, pension contributions, deferred contributions, stock, stock options or gifts), in any twelve-month period prior to the award of, or during the term of, a contract subject to this chapter; and (vi) all persons who are an "affiliate" of a business entity as defined in subsections (i), (ii) and (v) above, as such term is used in 11 U.S.C. 101(2). 
(Ord. No. 1566, 9-12-2011) 
Editor's note- Section 10 of Ord. No. 1566, adopted Sept. 12, 2011, states "The monetary thresholds of "Definitions" Section (d) and Section 1(c) [Sections 4.04.010 and 4.04.020(C)] of this ordinance [chapter] shall be increased effective March 1 of each calendar year by the percentage increase, in the prior calendar year, of the consumer price index for all urban consumers (CPI-U) for the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island region, rounded to the nearest $10.00. The Clerk of the Borough of Glen Ridge shall, by no later than April 1 of each calendar year, prepare and publish the revised thresholds on the official municipal website and in an official municipal newspaper." 
4.04.020 - Prohibition on awarding public contracts to certain contributors. 
A.	To the extent that it is not inconsistent with state or federal law, the borough and any of its departments, instrumentalities or purchasing agents shall not enter into any agreement or otherwise contract to procure "professional services" as such term is defined at N.J.S.A. 40A:11-2(6) and used at N.J.S.A. 40A:11-5(1)(a)(i) and/or banking, insurance or other consulting service (hereinafter "professional services"), nor "extraordinary unspecified services" as such term is defined at N.J.S.A. 40A:11-2(7) and used at N.J.S.A. 40A:11-5(1)(a)(ii) and/or media, public relations, lobbying, parking garage management or other consulting and/or management service (hereinafter "extraordinary unspecified services") from any business entity if such business entity has solicited or made any contribution to (i) a candidate, candidate committee or joint candidates committee of any candidate for elective municipal office in [the] borough or a holder of public office having ultimate responsibility for the award of a contract, or (ii) to any borough or county of Essex political committee or political party committee, or (iii) to any continuing political committee or political action committee that regularly engages in the support of [the] borough municipal or county of Essex elections and/or [the] borough municipal or county of Essex candidates, candidate committees, joint candidate committees, political committees, political parties, political party committees, (hereinafter "PAC"), in excess of the thresholds specified in subsection (C) within one calendar year immediately preceding the date of the contract or agreement. 
B.	No business entity who submits a proposal for, enters into negotiations for, or agrees to any contract or agreement with the borough or any of its departments or instrumentalities, for the rendition of professional services or extraordinary unspecified services shall knowingly solicit or make any contribution, to (i) a candidate, candidate committee or joint candidates committee of any candidate for elective municipal office in [the] borough, or a holder of public office having ultimate responsibility for the award of a contract, or (ii) to any borough or county of Essex political committee or political party committee, or (iii) any PAC between the time of first communication between that business entity and the municipality regarding a specific agreement for professional services or extraordinary unspecified services, and the later of the termination of negotiations or rejection of any proposal, or the completion of the performance or specified time period of that contract or agreement. 
C.	The monetary thresholds of this chapter are: (i) a maximum of three hundred dollars per calendar year each for any purpose to any candidate or candidate committee for mayor or governing body, or five hundred dollars per calendar year to any joint candidates committee for mayor or governing body, or three hundred dollars per calendar year to a political committee or political party committee of the borough; (ii) five-hundred-dollar maximum per calendar year to a county of Essex political committee or political party committee; and (iii) five-hundred-dollar maximum per calendar year to any PAC. However, for each business entity party to a contract for professional or extraordinary unspecified services as defined in subparagraph (A), or engaged in negotiations for a contract defined in subparagraph (A), when such business entity's contribution is aggregated with all "persons" defined in Section 4.04.010 "definitions" above, by virtue of their affiliation to that business entity party, a maximum of two thousand five hundred dollars to all borough candidates, candidate committees, joint candidate committees, and holders of public office having ultimate responsibility for the award of a contract, all borough or county of Essex political committees and political party committees as described herein combined, without violating subsection (A) of this section. 
D.	For purposes of this section, the office that is considered to have ultimate responsibility for the award of the contract shall be (i) the borough mayor or governing body, if the contract requires approval or appropriation from the mayor or governing body, or (ii) the mayor of the borough, if the contract requires approval of the mayor, or if a public officer who is responsible for the award of a contract is appointed by the mayor. 
E.	Rules Regarding Subcontractors. No person may be awarded a subcontract to perform under a contract subject to this chapter, if the subcontractor would be disqualified by paragraph (A) from receiving the contract at the time that the subcontract is awarded. Nor may any person who would be disqualified by paragraph (A) from receiving the contract perform substantially all of obligations described in a contract for professional or extraordinary services that is subject to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 1, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.030 - Contributions made prior to the effective date. 
    No contribution or solicitation of contributions made prior to the effective date of this chapter shall be deemed to give rise to a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 2, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.040 - Contract renewal. 
    No contract subject to this chapter may be renewed, extended, or materially modified unless the resulting renewal, extension, or modification would be allowable under the provisions of this chapter if it were an initial contract. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 3, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.050 - Contribution statement by business entity. 
A.	Prior to awarding any contract or agreement to procure "professional services" or "extraordinary unspecified services" from any business entity, the borough or its purchasing agents and departments, as the case may be, shall receive a sworn statement from said business entity which is the intended recipient of said contract that he/she/it has not made a contribution in violation of Section 4.04.020 of this chapter. The borough, its purchasing agents and departments shall be responsible for informing the mayor and borough council that the aforementioned sworn statement has been received and that the business entity is not in violation of this chapter, prior to awarding the contract or agreement. 
B.	A business entity shall have a continuing duty to report to the borough any contributions that constitute a violation of this act that are made during the negotiation, proposal process or the duration of a contract. The borough, its purchasing agents and departments shall be responsible for informing the governing body within ten business days after receipt of said report from the business entity, or at the next mayor and borough council meeting following receipt of said report from the business entity, or whichever comes first. 
C.	The certification required under this subsection shall be made prior to entry into the contract or agreement with the borough, or prior to the provision of services or goods, as the case may be, and shall be in addition to any other certifications that may be required by any other provision of law. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 4, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.060 - Return of excess contributions. 
    A business entity that is a party to a contract for professional services or extraordinary unspecified services may cure a violation of Section 4.04.020 of this chapter, if, within thirty days after the date on which the applicable ELEC report is published, said business entity notifies the municipality in writing and seeks and receives reimbursement of the contribution from the recipient of such contribution. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 5, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.070 - Exemptions. 
    The contribution limitations prior to entering into a contract in Section 4.04.020(A) do not apply to contracts which (i) are awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after public advertising for bids and bidding therefor within the meaning of N.J.S.A. 40A:11-4, or (ii) are awarded in the case of emergency under N.J.S.A. 40A:11-6.
