There is no exemption for contracts awarded pursuant to a "fair and open process" under N.J.S.A. 19:44A-20 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 6, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.080 - Penalty. 
A.	It shall be a material breach of the terms of a borough agreement or contract for professional services or extraordinary unspecified services when a business entity that is a party to such agreement or contract has: (i) made or solicited a contribution in violation of this chapter; (ii) knowingly concealed or misrepresented a contribution given or received; (iii) made or solicited contributions through intermediaries for the purpose of concealing or misrepresenting the source of the contribution; (iv) made or solicited any contribution on the condition or with the agreement that it will be recontributed to a candidate, candidate committee or joint candidates committee of any candidate for elective municipal office in [the] borough, or a holder of public office having ultimate responsibility for the award of a contract, or any borough or county of Essex political committee or political party committee, or any PAC; (v) engaged or employed a lobbyist or consultant with the intent or understanding that such lobbyist or consultant would make or solicit any contribution, which if made or solicited by the professional business entity itself, would subject that entity to the restrictions of this chapter; (vi) funded contributions made by third parties, including consultants, attorneys, family members, and employees; (vii) engaged in any exchange of contributions to circumvent the intent of this chapter; or (viii) directly or indirectly, through or by any other person or means, done any act which if done directly would subject that entity to the restrictions of this chapter. 
B.	Furthermore, any business entity that violates Section 4.04.080(A)(i)-(viii) shall be disqualified from eligibility for future borough contracts for a period of four calendar years from the date of the violation. 
C.	Any person who knowingly, purposely, or recklessly violates any provision of this chapter, or who conspires with another person to violate any provision of this chapter, or who, with the purpose of promoting or facilitating a violation of this chapter, solicits another person to commit it, or aids or agrees, or attempts to aid another person in planning or committing it, shall be subject to punishment including fines and/or imprisonment as fixed by law for violations of the ordinances of the borough. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 7, 9-12-2011) 
4.04.090 - Citizens private right of action. 
    In addition to any rights that were heretofore available, or which may hereafter be available, to citizens, taxpayers, or associations, to challenge violations of this chapter, every person aggrieved by a violation of the ordinance, or any taxpayer or resident of the borough has the right, consistent with the rules of court, to file charges in a court of competent jurisdiction, and/or to pursue a civil action for a violation of this chapter in a court of competent jurisdiction, and to seek and obtain declaratory, injunctive, or other legal or equitable relief, including but not limited to, attorneys fees and costs, arising from or related to a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § 8, 9-12-2011) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 5.04 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 
Sections: 

5.04.010 - Fees. 
A.	The fee for a plenary retail consumption license shall be two thousand four hundred dollars in the year 2005; and, two thousand five hundred dollars in the year 2006. 
B.	The fee for a plenary retail distribution license shall be one thousand two hundred forty-four dollars for the year 2005; and, one thousand four hundred ninety-two dollars for the year 2006; and, one thousand seven hundred ninety-one dollars for the year 2007; and, two thousand one hundred forty-nine dollars for the year 2008; and, two thousand five hundred dollars for the year 2009. 
C.	The fee for a limited retail distribution license shall be fifty dollars per year. 
D.	The fee for a club license shall be one hundred dollars per year. 
(Ord. 1419 § 1, 2004; Ord. 1367 § 1, 2002; Ord. 1339 § 1, 2000; Ord. 725 § 1, 1956: Ord. 619 § 1, 1943: Ord. 609 § 1, 1940) 
5.04.020 - Restaurant status required for retail consumption license. 
    No plenary retail consumption license shall be issued for any premises not conducted as a restaurant as defined in paragraph T of N.J.S.A. 33:1-1. 
(Ord. 619 § 2, 1943: Ord. 609 § 2, 1940) 
5.04.030 - Regulations. 
A.	No plenary retail consumption licensee shall sell, serve, deliver or allow, permit or suffer the sale, service or delivery of any alcoholic beverage, or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverage on licensed premises on weekdays between the hours of two a.m. and six a.m., or on Sundays between the hours of three a.m. and noon, excepting New Year's Day each year, as hereinafter provided. 
B.	No plenary retail consumption licensee shall sell, serve, deliver or allow, permit or suffer the sale, service or delivery of any alcoholic beverage, or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverage on licensed premises, on New Year's Day, when it is a weekday, between the hours of four a.m. and six a.m., or on New Year's Day when it is a Sunday between the hours of four a.m. and noon. 
C.	The hours above referred to shall be Eastern Standard Time, except from two a.m. on the last Sunday in April until two a.m. on the last Sunday in September of each year, when they shall be Eastern Daylight Saving Time, which time is one hour in advance of Eastern Standard Time. 
D.	The provisions of this section shall also apply to club licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
E.	Retail sale of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted on licensed premises during the following hours: 
a.	On any weekday between the hours of nine a.m. and ten p.m. as provided in N.J.S.A. 33:1-1 et seq. and N.J.A.C. 13:2-38.1, except for the sale of wine and malt alcoholic beverages which shall be permitted during the hours set forth in Section 5.04.030(A). 
b.	On any Sunday between the hours of twelve p.m. and five p.m., except for the sale of wine and malt alcoholic beverages which shall be permitted during the hours set forth in Section 5.04.030(A). 
c.	On the Sunday preceding Christmas Day or New Year's Day, the sale of any alcoholic beverage for off-premises consumption shall be permitted from nine a.m. to ten p.m. 
(Ord. 1460, 2006; Ord. 645 § 1, 1947; Ord. 609 § 3, 1940) 
5.04.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars, or imprisonment for not more than ninety days, or both, at the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 609 § 4, 1940) 
Chapter 5.08 - AUTOMOBILE SERVICE STATIONS 
Sections: 

5.08.010 - Restricted property. 
    No gasoline filling tank or pump or other means of supplying gasoline to motor vehicles shall be erected or maintained on property owned or maintained by the borough on or along any street or highway used by a common carrier as part of a regular route for the transportation, loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Ord. 703 § 1, 1954) 
5.08.020 - Restricted locations. 
    No gasoline filling station, motor vehicle service station or the like designed in whole or in part for the purpose of vending or supplying gasoline and oil or either of them from tanks or pumps or other devices to operators of motor vehicles which may be driven to or transported to such station under their own power or otherwise, and no gasoline filling tank or pump or other means of supplying gasoline to motor vehicles shall be erected or maintained on property which is: 
A.	Within five hundred feet of a school, hospital, church, public park, school or public playground or athletic field, or building occupied in whole or in part as a residence; or 
B.	At or within two hundred feet of a corner formed by a street intersection through or over which passes a regular route used by a common carrier for the transportation, loading or unloading of passengers; or 
C.	Within one thousand feet of a school, church, or school or public playground or athletic field, where such property and the property occupied by said school, church, or school or public playground or athletic field border upon the same street. 
(Ord. 703 § 2, 1954) 
5.08.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished, upon conviction thereof, by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for not more than thirty days, for each offense; and the further sum of not more than one hundred dollars or imprisonment for not more than thirty days for every day that any violation of this chapter shall be suffered to exist. 
(Ord. 703 § 3, 1954) 
Chapter 5.12 - AUTOMOBILE JUNK DEALERS 
Sections: 

5.12.010 - License required. 
    No person or persons, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of motor vehicle junk dealer in the borough without first obtaining a license so to do. 
(Ord. 564 § 1, 1932) 
5.12.020 - Definitions. 
    The term "motor vehicle junk dealer" means and describes any dealer engaged in the business of storing, displaying, buying or selling secondhand automobiles or parts thereof which are not intended or fit for reconditioning for use for highway transportation. 
(Ord. 564 § 2, 1932) 
5.12.030 - Vehicle identification. 
    The make, model, engine number and serial number of all motor vehicles received by any person or persons, firm or corporation engaged in the business of motor vehicle junk dealer shall be reported within forty-eight hours after the receipt thereof and before the same are dismantled or otherwise disposed of, to the chief of police of the borough. 
(Ord. 564 § 3, 1932) 
5.12.040 - Creating hazard unlawful. 
    It is unlawful to stack, pile or place parts of motor vehicles upon said premises in such a manner as to create a fire hazard or to create a place for the harboring or breeding of rats, mice or vermin. 
(Ord. 564 § 4, 1932) 
5.12.050 - Stacking of vehicles-Prohibited where. 
    It shall be unlawful to stack, pile or place any motor vehicle part or parts of motor vehicles closer to the curb line of the street adjacent to or in front of said premises than seventy-five feet, or nearer than twenty-five feet to any building or structure. 
(Ord. 687 § 1 (part), 1952: Ord. 564 § 5, 1932) 
5.12.060 - Storage of parts. 
    All parts of motor vehicles shall be so piled, stacked or otherwise placed a sufficient distance from the side line of said premises as to prevent the same from falling upon or doing injury to the adjoining premises or persons lawfully using the same, or other effective means provided to prevent such injury. 
(Ord. 564 § 6, 1932) 
5.12.070 - License fee. 
    Every person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of motor vehicle junk dealer shall pay a license fee of seven hundred dollars per year. 
(Ord. 726 § 1, 1956: Ord. 709 § 1, 1954: Ord. 687 § 1 (part), 1952: Ord. 682 § 1, 1951: Ord. 564 § 7, 1932) 
5.12.080 - License application. 
A.	All persons, firms or corporations now engaged in or hereafter engaging in the business of motor vehicle junk dealer shall, from and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, make application to the borough clerk, who is designated as the license officer for the purpose of this chapter. 
B.	Said application shall be in writing and shall set forth the name of the person or persons, firm or corporation, their respective addresses or principal places of business, and shall describe the premises upon which said business is to be conducted, giving the street frontage and approximate depth of said premises, and said application shall be accompanied by the license fee hereinabove provided. 
C.	The borough clerk is directed to present said applications to the borough council at its next meeting, and is authorized to issue a license to such persons, or person, firm or corporation, on approval of the same by the borough council, and said license shall be effective from the date of issue to the thirty-first day of December of the year in which said license is issued, and all persons, firms or corporations, upon the expiration of any license granted hereunder, shall make application to the borough clerk for a license to conduct said business for the ensuing year or part thereof, and shall pay for said license the same fee as hereinabove set forth. 
(Ord. 564 § 8, 1932) 
5.12.090 - License fee to treasurer. 
    The borough clerk, upon the issue of any license under the provisions of this chapter, shall turn over said license fee to the borough treasurer. 
(Ord. 564 § 9, 1932) 
5.12.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or persons, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall pay a fine on conviction thereof, not exceeding fifty dollars, or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding ten days, or both, for each violation; and for each day that such violation continues, it shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 687 § 1 (part), 1952: Ord. 564 § 10, 1932) 
Chapter 5.16 - CANVASSERS AND SOLICITORS 
Sections: 

5.16.010 - Regulations. 
    No person not a resident of or an owner of real property in the borough shall canvass or solicit business, subscriptions, contributions, or anything else, or distribute handbills, advertisements, circulars or other similar printed matter, from house-to-house or door-to-door in said borough without first being registered with the chief of police as hereinafter provided and until two weeks after such registration shall have been completed. In no event shall such person engage in such canvassing, soliciting or distributing between nine p.m. and nine a.m. 
(Ord. 704 § 1, 1954) 
(Ord. No. 1549, 2-14-2011) 
5.16.020 - Registration. 
A.	Registration with the chief of police within the meaning of Section 5.16.010 hereof shall consist of the completion and filing with the chief of police of an application under oath disclosing the name, residence address, occupation, business address, age, color, weight, height, color of eyes and hair and place of birth of applicant; whether or not applicant has been previously arrested or convicted of any crime; description of the project in which applicant intends to engage in house-to-house or door-to-door activity; and the name and address of the corporation, organization, association or person, if any, sponsoring or directing said project. Said registration shall not be complete until the applicant shall have been fingerprinted and photographed and shall have filed with the chief of police two character references in writing, including one from the corporation, organization, association or person, if any, sponsoring or directing said project. 
B.	Two weeks after said registration shall be complete, the police department shall issue to the registrant a card signed by the chief of police or acting chief of police so stating and stating further that the police department does not vouch for the registrant, his or her sponsor, the project in which he or she is engaged or the product, if any, in which he or she is dealing. The registrant shall exhibit said card to any resident of the borough on demand. Any card issued pursuant hereto shall be nontransferable and shall be surrendered by the registrant to the police department within twenty-four hours after any one of the following events: 
1.	The termination of his or her employment by the sponsor of the project in which he or she is engaged; 
2.	The cessation by him or her of his or her canvassing, solicitation or distribution activities within the borough; 
3.	The violation by him or her of any provision of this chapter. 
C.	A record of all registrants and cards issued pursuant thereto shall be kept by the police department. 
D.	A registrant whose card has been surrendered shall be required to register again as hereinabove provided before again canvassing, soliciting or distributing as described in Section 5.16.010 hereof. 
E.	Registration for canvassing, soliciting or the distribution of printed materials shall be limited to a period not to exceed sixty days. 
(Ord. 1366, 2002; Ord. 704 § 2, 1954) 
5.16.025 - Collection, preparation and maintenance of a nonsolicitation list. 
A.	The office of the administrator/borough clerk shall collect, prepare and maintain a list of addresses of those premises where the owner and/or occupant has notified the borough clerk that soliciting and canvassing is not permitted on his or her premises. To be included on the nonsolicitation list, residents shall complete a form. With the adoption of the ordinance codified in this section, the office of the borough clerk shall mail the form to all residential property owners or occupants. Thereafter, the form shall be available in the Municipal Building's general office during normal business hours, Mondays through Fridays from eight-thirty a.m. to four-thirty p.m. except on weekends and legal holidays. 
B.	The administrator/borough clerk and/or deputy borough clerk shall submit the nonsolicitation list to the chief of police on a quarterly basis which nonsolicitation listing shall be distributed to applicants seeking a license to solicit or canvas at any address on the nonsolicitation list. 
C.	Updating of Nonsolicitation List. On or about January 1st, April 1st, July 1st and October 1st of each year, the office of the borough clerk shall update the list. The updated list shall then be forwarded to the chief of police for distribution to solicitors and/or canvassers. 
D.	Any solicitor or canvasser violating the provisions of this section, described above, shall be punishable by a fine and/or imprisonment as prescribed in Section 5.16.030 under this chapter of the Code of the borough of Glen Ridge entitled "Canvassers and Solicitors." 
(Ord. 1461 § 1, 2006) 
5.16.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating this chapter shall be liable upon the first conviction thereof to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars or imprisonment in the county jail for a term not exceeding thirty days, or both; and for any second or more convictions to a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars or imprisonment in the county jail for a term not exceeding ninety days, or both. 
(Ord. 704 § 3, 1954) 
Chapter 5.20 - FOOD AND BEVERAGE VENDING MACHINES 
Sections: 

5.20.010 - License required-Compliance with provisions. 
    It is unlawful for any person or any body corporate to maintain a coin-operated vending machine in the borough for the sale of food and beverages within the borough without having first procured an annual license from the local board of health so to do and without complying with any and all provisions concerning the operation and maintenance of the same as contained in regulations, promulgated by the board of health of the borough. 
(Ord. 1038 § 1, 1980) 
5.20.020 - License fees. 
    The annual fees for licenses for each such food and beverage vending machine for the purpose of raising revenue, for inspection, for regulation and control, to be paid annually to this municipality, are fixed as follows: 
A.	The fee for each such vending machine shall be at the rate of one dollar per penny, calculated at the highest denomination of coin required in said machine, provided that there shall be a maximum fee of fifty dollars for any such machine. 
B.	Each machine having a separate coin slot shall be individually licensed. 
(Ord. 1038 § 2, 1980) 
5.20.030 - Posting requirements. 
    Each vending machine shall have attached to it a sticker with the following legend: 
This vending machine is licensed by the Glen Ridge Board of Health, License No. ____________ , effective from ____________ to December 31st, 19 ____________ . 
(Ord. 1038 § 3, 1980) 
5.20.040 - Duration of license. 
    The license fees shall be levied commencing January 1, 1980, and shall be issued for a calendar year. Any license issued for a part of a calendar year shall carry the full annual license fee. 
(Ord. 1038 § 4, 1980) 
5.20.050 - Enforcement. 
    The board of health of the borough shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1038 § 6, 1980) 
5.20.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not to exceed five hundred dollars or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of not to exceed ninety days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, and each violation of any of the provisions of this chapter and each day the same is violated shall be deemed and taken to be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 1038 § 5, 1980) 
Chapter 5.24 - GARAGE SALES 
Sections: 

5.24.010 - Definitions. 
    "Garage sales" means and includes all sales entitled "garage sale," "attic sale," "rummage sale" or "flea market sale" or any similar casual sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by a means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of said sale. 
    "Goods" is meant to include any goods or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder and which is owned by the licensee. 
    "Occupant" means owner or lessee of the premises. 
(Ord. 958 § 1, 1974) 
5.24.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful to conduct a garage sale in the borough without first filing with the borough clerk the information hereinafter specified and obtaining from such clerk a license so to do, to be known as a "garage sale license." The fee for such license is fixed at two dollars. 
(Ord. 958 § 2, 1974) 
5.24.030 - Issuance of license-Display requirements. 
A.	Such license shall be issued as to any one premises only once within a twelve-month period and no such license shall be issued for more than two consecutive calendar days. 
B.	Each license issued under this chapter must be prominently displayed on the premises and visible from the street upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the licensed sale. 
(Ord. 958 § 3, 1974) 
5.24.040 - Information required by clerk. 
    The information to be filed with the borough clerk pursuant to this chapter shall be as follows: 
A.	Name of person, firm, group, corporation, association or organization conducting said sale; 
B.	Name of owner or lessee of the premises on which said sale is to be conducted; 
C.	Location at which sale is to be conducted; 
D.	Number of days of sale; 
E.	Date and nature of any past sale; 
F.	Sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing that the information therein given is full and true and known to him or her to be so. 
(Ord. 958 § 4, 1974) 
5.24.050 - Conduct of sale. 
    The person to whom such license is issued and the owner or tenant of the premises on which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity. No such persons shall permit any loud or boisterous conduct on said premises nor permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of such premises. All such persons shall obey the reasonable orders of any member of the police or fire departments of the borough in order to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. All licensed premises shall at all times be subject to such reasonable rules as may be made from time to time by the borough council and shall be subject to inspection at all times by the building inspector, chief of police and fire chief, or any of their agents or any other duly authorized representative of the borough. 
(Ord. 958 § 5, 1974) 
5.24.060 - Hours of sale. 
    All garage sales shall be conducted between the hours of nine a.m. and five p.m. only. 
(Ord. 958 § 6, 1974) 
5.24.070 - Posting of signs-Place of sale. 
A.	No signs for advertising or directing customers are to be posted on any place other than the premises where the sale is to be held. The sign shall not exceed two feet by two feet in size and shall not be placed on the premises earlier than one week prior to the sale and must be removed within twenty-four hours after the sale has terminated. 
B.	Sales, as defined and permitted under this chapter, shall be conducted on the licensed premises only in the dwelling, garage or rear yard. 
(Ord. 958 § 7, 1974) 
5.24.080 - Regulations for sale items. 
    It is unlawful for any person to offer for sale mattresses, bedsprings, cots, lounges and sofas in any garage sale authorized under this chapter without first complying with the appropriate section of N.J.S.A. 26:10-1 through 26:10-18, with respect to the labeling, sterilizing, disinfecting of said mattresses, bedsprings, cots, lounges and sofas. 
(Ord. 958 § 8, 1974) 
5.24.090 - Persons and sales excepted. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
A.	Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
B.	Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
C.	Any person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement, and which separate items do not exceed five in number; 
D.	Any sale conducted by any merchant of mercantile or other business establishment from or at a place of business wherein such sale would be permitted by the zoning regulations of the borough, or under the protection of the nonconforming use section thereof or any other sale conducted by a manufacturer, dealer or vendor and which sale would be conducted from properly zoned premises and not otherwise prohibited in the ordinances; 
E.	Any bona fide charitable, educational, cultural or governmental institution or organization; provided, however, that the burden of establishing the exemption under this subsection shall be on the organization or institution claiming such exemption. Such exemption may be permitted by resolution of the borough council after application by any of the aforementioned types of organizations. 
(Ord. 958 § 9, 1974) 
5.24.100 - Enforcement. 
    This chapter shall be enforced by the building inspector. It shall be the duty of the building inspector to investigate any violations of this chapter coming to his/her attention, whether by complaint or arising from his/her own personal knowledge, and if a violation is found to exist, he/she shall prosecute a complaint before the local municipal court pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. It shall be the duty of the police department to bring to the attention of the building inspector for further investigation, any violation of this chapter of which the police department becomes aware during the course of its normal duties. 
(Ord. 958 § 10, 1974) 
5.24.110 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, association or corporation conducting any such sale or similar activity without being properly licensed therefor or who shall violate any of the other terms and regulations of this chapter shall upon conviction be fined not less than twenty-five dollars nor more than one hundred dollars or be imprisoned for a period not to exceed ten days for each violation. Each day that such sale shall continue without being duly licensed shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. 958 § 11, 1974) 
Chapter 5.28 - HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS 
Sections: 

5.28.010 - Regulations. 
A.	Use of Streets. No peddler shall have any exclusive right to any location, nor shall he or she be permitted to operate in any congested area where his or her operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this section, the judgement of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
B.	Inspection of Equipment. The equipment used or employed by peddlers of ice cream, foods, beverages, confections and other related commodities shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary manner and be subject to the inspection of the health officer or his or her authorized agents. Any violation found and not immediately corrected shall be grounds for revocation of the license. 
C.	Conduct. 
1.	No person or persons, whether licensed under the terms or provisions of this chapter or unlicensed, shall scatter, throw or deposit any garbage, handbills, advertisements, circulars or other printed matter in and about the street, sidewalk, parks and public places within the borough or upon the premises of any resident or property owner. 
2.	The use of any sound system upon any vehicle, including but not limited to bells, horns or musical playing devices used to attract patrons, is not permitted while any such vehicle is stopped or standing. Any sound device may only be used for a short period of time, not to exceed two minutes of continual playing. 
3.	The use of active public streets and sidewalks within the borough by peddlers are hereby prohibited. 
4.	Unattended vehicles: leave any vehicle unattended at any time or store, place or leave the same overnight on any public property of the borough. 
5.	It shall be unlawful for any peddler to misrepresent the character or quality of merchandise offered for sale, to importune or otherwise annoy any person for the purpose of effecting or inducing a purchase or to conduct himself otherwise than honestly and courteously. 
6.	Conduct, or attempt to conduct, his business within two hundred feet of any place occupied exclusively as a train station, public or private school or for school purposes, nor, during such times, shall he permit his cart, wagon or vehicle to stand on any public highway within such distance of any school property. 
(Ord. 1397 (part), 2003: Ord. 374 § 1, 1924: Ord. 271 § 1, 1918) 
(Ord. No. 1579, 6-11-2012) 
5.28.020 - Standards for approval or rejection of application. 
A.	If, after investigation, the chief of police concludes that the applicant's character and business responsibility are satisfactory, he or she shall signify his or her approval of the application. 
B.	If, after an investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall disapprove such application and his or her reasons therefore. Any determination by the chief of police that an applicant shall be disapproved shall be based upon one or more of the following findings with respect to the applicant or, in the case of solicitation of contributions, any of the organizations officers, managers or agents: 
1.	Conviction of a crime involving moral turpitude. 
2.	Prior violation of a peddling or soliciting ordinance. 
3.	Previous fraudulent acts or conduct. 
4.	Record of breaches of solicited contracts. 
5.	Evidence of bad character. 
6.	False swearing upon application. 
C.	In the absence of any such finding, the chief of police shall find the application satisfactory and shall endorse his or her approval upon same. 
(Ord. 1397 (part), 2003: Ord. 271 § 2, 1918) 
5.28.030 - License fee-Duration. 
    Each and every person or corporation so licensed as aforesaid shall pay to the borough clerk for such license the nonrefundable sum of fifty dollars for the use of the borough, and such license when used shall be in force until the first day of May next succeeding the date granting of said license; provided, however, that the fee for the license issued after the expiration of six months from the first day of May shall be twenty-five dollars. 
(Ord. 1397 (part), 2003: Ord. 271 § 3, 1918) 
5.28.040 - Application to licensed vehicle only. 
    Every person or corporation licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall be entitled to the use of one wagon, cart or other vehicle for each license taken out and no more. 
(Ord. 271 § 4, 1918) 
5.28.050 - Plates required. 
    The borough clerk shall issue with each license granted under the authority of this chapter, when a wagon, cart or other vehicle is to be used, duplicate metal plates, bearing the words "Licensed Hawker, Borough of Glen Ridge," together with the number of the license and the year for which it is issued; and all carts, wagons or other vehicles used for the purpose of hawking or peddling as aforesaid shall have affixed on each side thereof one of the metal plates above mentioned and the name of the licensee in letters at least two inches in height written or painted clearly and distinctly thereon. 
(Ord. 271 § 5, 1918) 
5.28.060 - License nontransferable. 
    Licenses granted pursuant hereto are not transferable, and no person, persons or corporation, having obtained a license as aforesaid shall lend or hire the same or any duplicate thereof or allow the use of any such vehicle with such licensee's name thereon or any such metal plate referred to in Section 5.28.050, for the purpose of vending, hawking or peddling. 
(Ord. 271 § 6, 1918) 
5.28.070 - Required to carry license-Exhibit when. 
    Every licensee, as aforesaid engaged in hawking or peddling in the streets and public places of the borough, shall at all times, when so engaged, carry the license hereinabove referred to and shall exhibit the same on demand to any citizen of the borough. 
(Ord. 271 § 7, 1918) 
5.28.071 - Suspension. 
    The borough administrator and/or borough council may immediately suspend a license issued under this chapter for a period of not more than thirty days, pending a hearing to revoke the permit for any of the following causes: 
1.	Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement in any application for a license; or 
2.	Fraud, misrepresentation, false statement or other dishonesty in the conduct of the licensed activity; or 
3.	An alleged violation of any provisions of this article; or 
4.	Conviction of the licensee for any felony or high misdemeanor or a misdemeanor or disorderly person's offense involving moral turpitude; or 
5.	Conduct of the licensed activity in an unlawful manner or in a manner that constitutes a breach of the peace or a menace to the public health, safety or general welfare; or 
6.	Whenever a license has been issued based upon an application pending the results of the investigation, the license may be summarily revoked if the result of the investigation is such as would have resulted in denial of the application. 
B.	Notice of a hearing for the revocation of a license shall be given to the licensee in writing by the municipal clerk. The notice shall specifically set forth the grounds on which the proposed revocation is based and the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall be served by mailing a copy to the licensee at his last known address by certified mail, return receipt requested, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
C.	At the hearing, the licensee shall have the right to appear and be heard in his own behalf, to cross-examine opposing witnesses and to have a permanent record made of the proceedings at his own expense. The borough council may revoke or suspend the license if it is satisfied by a preponderance of the evidence that the licensee is guilty of the acts charged. 
(Ord. No. 1579, 6-11-2012) 
5.28.072 - Reinstatement of revoked licenses. 
    The borough council may issue another license to a person whose license has been revoked or denied if after hearing it is satisfied by clear and convincing evidence that the acts which led to the revocation or denial will not occur again; otherwise, no person whose license has been revoked or denied nor any person acting for him, directly or indirectly, shall be issued another license to carry on the same activity. 
(Ord. No. 1579, 6-11-2012) 
5.28.073 - Insurance requirements. 
A.	Every licensee shall carry and maintain in force insurance covering its operations written by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state of New Jersey, providing the following minimum coverage and language: 
1.	Comprehensive general liability: Five hundred thousand dollars (combined single limit each occurrence). 
2.	Business automobile liability: Five hundred thousand dollars (each accident), or if the license is granted to an entity that does not own any automobiles and uses employees that would use their own automobiles to conduct business, then employer's non-ownership automobile liability will be accepted for the business auto insurance requirement. 
B.	The borough and its agents and employees shall be indemnified and held harmless from all claims and demands, losses and expenses arising from the permission granted and shall be named as an additional insured. 
C.	The issuing company shall notify the borough with ten days of the cancellation of any of the policies. 
D.	The licensee shall provide proof of paid-up insurance coverage, and in the case of not having paid the policy for a full year, appropriate i.e., monthly, quarterly or semiannual proof shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 1579, 6-11-2012) 
5.28.074 - Special permits; fees. 
    Permits for one day to three days may be issued by the borough clerk in lieu of the licenses required by this article, subject to the approval of the chief of police or captain of police, upon payment of a fee of sixty-two dollars and fifty cents to the municipal clerk. 
    If any clause, sentence, subdivision, paragraph, section or part of this ordinance be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder thereof, but shall be confined in its operation to the clause, sentence, subdivision, paragraph, section, or part thereof, directly involved in the controversy in which said judgment shall have been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 1579, 6-11-2012) 
5.28.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be liable to a penalty not exceeding fifty dollars upon the first conviction, and to a penalty not exceeding two hundred dollars upon the second and every subsequent conviction. 
(Ord. 1397 (part), 2003: Ord. 271 § 8, 1918) 
Chapter 5.32 - JUNK DEALERS 
Sections: 

5.32.010 - Issuance of license-Fees. 
    The borough clerk shall from time to time, on application, issue a license to any person or corporation as a ragpicker or junk dealer or to keep what is commonly called a "junk shop," for the purchase and sale of junk, old rope, old iron, brass, copper, tin, lead or other metals, old bottles and such like; every person or corporation receiving such license shall pay to the borough clerk therefor, the sum of twenty-five dollars for the use of the borough; provided, however, that no such license shall be issued without the written approval of the chief of police; and provided further, that any such license may be revoked at the option of the borough council in its discretion. 
(Ord. 270 § 1, 1918) 
5.32.020 - Secondhand dealers. 
    All persons and corporations engaging in the business of buying secondhand clothes, jewelry or other secondhand articles or materials of any kind or description within the borough shall be deemed junkmen, junk dealers or ragpickers within the meaning of this chapter, and shall before engaging in said business, secure a license, and shall be subject to all the rules and regulations provided for junkmen, junk dealers and rag-pickers in this chapter. 
(Ord. 376 § 1, 1924) 
5.32.030 - Location. 
    No license to keep a junk shop shall entitle any person or corporation to keep the same at or in any other place than that which is mentioned and specified in said license. 
(Ord. 270 § 2, 1918) 
5.32.040 - Pawning prohibited. 
    No keeper of a junk shop or any junk dealer or ragpicker shall receive in the line of said business any article or thing by way of pledge or pawn, nor shall any loan or any sum of money be advanced by any such licensee on the security of any such article or thing. 
(Ord. 270 § 3, 1918) 
5.32.050 - Bookkeeping. 
A.	Every ragpicker or keeper of a junk shop or junk dealer whose place of business is in Glen Ridge shall provide and keep a book in which shall be written at the time of every purchase a description of the article or articles so purchased, the name and residence of the person from whom such purchase was made and the day of the purchase. 
B.	Every such book shall at all times be open to the inspection of any new member of this borough council or any police officer of the borough, or to any person who may be authorized in writing for that purpose by any of them or by the recorder of the borough. 
(Ord. 270 §§ 4, 5, 1918) 
5.32.060 - Term of license. 
    Every such license shall continue in force until the first day of May next succeeding the granting of such license. 
(Ord. 270 § 6, 1918) 
5.32.070 - Purchasing regulations. 
    No ragpicker or keeper of a junk shop or junk dealer shall purchase or receive in the course of business any goods, articles or things whatsoever between the setting of the sun and the hour of seven a.m., or purchase or receive in the line of such business any goods, article or thing whatsoever from any person under the age of fifteen years. 
(Ord. 270 § 7, 1918) 
5.32.080 - Stolen goods. 
    Every ragpicker or keeper of a junk shop or junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or thing which may have been lost or stolen shall forthwith, on demand to view the same, present the same to the recorder or any member of the borough council or any police officer of the borough. 
(Ord. 270 § 8, 1918) 
5.32.090 - Collection vehicles-Regulations. 
    Every licensee shall be entitled to keep one cart, wagon or vehicle for the purpose of collecting junk, old rope, old iron, brass, copper, tin, lead or other metals, rags, old bottles and such like in the borough; provided, however, that if any licensee desires to keep more than one cart, wagon or vehicle application to the council for such privilege shall be made and the sum of five dollars shall be paid for each cart, wagon or vehicle, the said council may authorize said licensee to use as aforesaid; and provided also that any person or corporation using any such cart, wagon or vehicle, or causing the same to be used, shall cause to be painted on the outside of such cart, wagon or vehicle the name of the licensee and the street and number of the place of business, in plain letters, and shall also attach to each side of such wagon a metal plate bearing the number of such license to be furnished by the borough clerk. 
(Ord. 270 § 9, 1918) 
5.32.100 - Vehicle operator must carry license. 
    Every person engaged in drawing or driving any cart, wagon or vehicle for the purpose of collecting junk, old rope, old iron, brass, copper, tin, lead or other metals, rags, old bottles, and such like shall at all times carry with him when so engaged, the license or duplicate thereof, whereby such conveyance is authorized, and shall exhibit the same to any citizen of the borough. 
(Ord. 270 § 10, 1918) 
5.32.110 - License regulations. 
    All licenses under this chapter shall at all times be subject to such rules and regulations as may be made for their control and government by the borough council. 
(Ord. 270 § 11, 1918) 
5.32.120 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or corporation violating or refusing or neglecting to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be subject to a penalty not to exceed twenty-five dollars or imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed ten days. 
(Ord. 636 § 1, 1945: Ord.635 § 1, 1945; Ord. 376 § 2, 1924; Ord. 270 § 12, 1918) 
Chapter 5.36 - RETAIL FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 
Sections: 

5.36.010 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person or any body corporate to conduct a retail food establishment as defined in and governed by Chapter XII of the State Sanitary Code of New Jersey, without first having procured an annual license from the local board of health so to do and without complying with any or all of the provisions concerning operation and maintenance of the same as contained in the aforementioned Chapter XII of the State Sanitary Code of New Jersey. 
(Ord. 1039 § 1, 1980) 
5.36.020 - License fees-Duration. 
A.	The annual fees for licenses of retail food establishments are fixed, as follows: 
1.	Restaurants, Luncheonettes, Etc. 
Group Seating Capacity Annual Fee I 1-25 $ 25.00 II 26-50 50.00 III 51-75 75.00 IV 76-100 100.00 V Over 100 150.00  
2.	Miscellaneous. 
Single food handling, retail $ 25.00 Single food handling, nonprocessing 15.00 Taverns (no food service) $ 15.00 Delicatessens 25.00 Soda fountains, snack bars, stands 15.00 Candy counters 5.00 Plant, school and institutional cafeterias 25.00 Supermarkets 150.00 Catering units, mobile (package goods only) 25.00 Milk route (per vehicle) 5.00  
3.	Food Handling Permits-Temporary. 
Maximum, ten days for carnivals, fairs, etc. $25.00  
B.	The licenses issued aforesaid shall be effective for the calendar year, expiring on the thirty-first day of December of the year of issue, and may be renewable for succeeding calendar years thereafter. The fee for license renewals shall be due and payable on or before the first day of February in the year of renewal. Retail food establishments in operation at the time of enactment of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be required to procure licensing immediately as specified herein, the fees for said licenses shall be due and payable forthwith in the sums hereinabove provided, for the calendar year 1980, and said licenses shall expire on December 31, 1980, and be subject to renewal for succeeding years. 
(Ord. 1039 § 2, 1980) 
5.36.030 - Revocation of license-Hearing. 
A.	Any license issued under the terms and provisions of this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the board of health of this municipality for the violation by the licensee of any provision of this chapter, or Chapter XII of the State Sanitary Code of New Jersey, or whenever it shall appear that the business, trade, calling, profession or occupation of the person, firm or corporation to whom such license was issued is conducted in a disorderly or improper manner, or in violation of any law of the United States, the state of New Jersey, or any ordinance of this municipality, or that the person or persons conducting the retail food establishment is of an unfit character to conduct the same or that the purpose for which the license has been issued is being abused to the detriment of the public, or is being used for a purpose foreign to that for which the license was issued. 
B.	A license issued under the terms and provisions of this chapter shall not be revoked, cancelled or suspended until a hearing thereon shall have been had by the board of health. Written notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be served upon the licensee at least three days prior to the date set for such hearing. Such notice shall also contain a brief statement of the grounds to be relied upon for revoking, cancelling or suspending such license. Notice may be given either by personal delivery personal delivery thereof to the person to be notified or by being deposited in the United States Post Office in a sealed envelope (certified mail), postage prepaid, addressed to such person to be notified at the business address appearing upon said license. At the hearing before the board of health, the person aggrieved shall have an opportunity to answer and may thereafter be heard, and upon due consideration and deliberation by the board of health, the complaint may be dismissed, or if the governing body concludes that the charges have been sustained and substantiated, it may revoke, cancel or suspend the license held by the licensee. 
C.	If any such license shall have been revoked, neither the holder thereof nor any person acting for him, directly or indirectly, shall be entitled to another license to carry on the same business within the borough, unless the application for such license shall be approved by the board of health. 
(Ord. 1039 § 3, 1980) 
5.36.040 - Applicability of provisions. 
    No provision of this chapter shall be applied so as to impose any unlawful burden on either interstate commerce or any activity of the state or federal government. 
(Ord. 1039 § 4, 1980) 
5.36.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars, by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of not to exceed ninety days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, and each violation of any of the provisions of this chapter and each day the same is violated shall be deemed and taken to be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 1039 § 5, 1980) 
Chapter 5.40 - COMMERCIAL LANDSCAPERS 
Sections: 

5.40.010 - Purpose. 
    An ordinance to add this chapter of the Code of the borough of Glen Ridge establishing requirements for commercial landscapers to control noise in the borough of Glen Ridge, so as to protect public health, safety, and welfare, and to prescribe penalties for the failure to comply. 
(Ord. 1447 § 1, 2006) 
5.40.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Annual fee" means the fee charged by and payable to the municipal clerk of the borough of Glen Ridge to obtain a license as a landscaper. 
    "Annual license" means license issued by the municipal clerk of the borough of Glen Ridge for the period starting October 1st and ending September 30th for the purposes stated. 
    "Customer" means anyone who employs the services of a landscaper to perform the services of maintaining, cutting, cleaning or raking property within the borough of Glen Ridge. 
    "Landscape contractor" means the same meaning as landscaper. 
    "Landscaper" means a person or persons doing business with residential or commercial customers for the purpose of maintaining, cutting, cleaning, raking or performing similar activities on property within the borough of Glen Ridge. 
    "Vehicle" means any vehicle required to be registered with the New Jersey department of motor vehicles for use on local roads and highways and used by a landscaper in the performance of his or her work in the borough of Glen Ridge. 
(Ord. 1447 § 2, 2006) 
5.40.030 - License required. 
    All landscapers utilizing a truck, van or trailer for landscaping services within the borough of Glen Ridge shall be required to obtain a license in order to offer their services in the borough of Glen Ridge. A license shall be required for each vehicle the landscaper owns or operates within the borough of Glen Ridge. Such license shall be obtained from the municipal clerk prior to October 1 of each calendar year. (Such licenses shall terminate September 30.) Proof of licensor will be demonstrated by the issuance and the display of a decal, which will be issued to each licensee and displayed in each vehicle the landscaper owns or operates in the borough of Glen Ridge. 
(Ord. 1447 § 3, 2006) 
5.40.040 - Application for license. 
A.	All applications for landscaping licenses shall be in writing on all forms furnished by the borough, signed by the applicant or the authorized agent of the applicant and presented to the municipal clerk. The application shall state: 
1.	The name of the landscaper; 
2.	The correct name under which the business is being operated; 
3.	The residence of the applicant; 
4.	Registration for each vehicle which is licensed; 
5.	Proof of insurance; 
6.	Emergency contact number; 
7.	Such other pertinent information as may be necessary for an investigation of the applicant. 
B.	All applications for licenses received by the municipal clerk shall after appropriate investigation either grant or refuse the application. Thereafter, if the application is approved, the municipal clerk shall issue the license upon payment of the license fee as hereinafter provided. All licenses issued shall expire September 30 of each year. 
(Ord. 1447 § 4, 2006) 
5.40.050 - Name of company on vehicle. 
    Every landscaper operating within the borough of Glen Ridge shall be required to comply with the following: 
A.	The name of the landscaping company shall be clearly indicated on both sides of any vehicle used in the operation, shall be no less than three inches in height and shall include the name, address and telephone number. 
(Ord. 1447 § 5, 2006) 
5.40.060 - License fee; terms. 
A.	Upon filing such application, the applicant shall pay to the municipal clerk a fee of fifty dollars. Any fraction of the year will be considered a full year for the purposes of this section. 
B.	The term of such license shall expire on September 30 of each year. 
C.	Such license shall be automatically renewed by the municipal clerk upon payment by the applicant to the municipal clerk of an annual renewal fee of fifty dollars. Such renewal shall be for the following year in which such renewal occurs. 
D.	The licensing requirements of this chapter shall not apply to any landscaper who maintains a valid registration certificate issued pursuant to the New Jersey Contractors' Registration Act, N.J.S.A. 56:8-136 et seq. Landscapers who maintain a valid registration certificate issued pursuant to the New Jersey Contractors' Registration Act shall register with [the] borough and provide the following information: 
1.	All applications for landscaping registration shall be in writing on all forms furnished by the borough, signed by the applicant or the authorized agent of the applicant and presented to the municipal clerk. The application shall state: 
a.	The name of the landscaper; and 
b.	The correct name under which the business is being operated; and 
c.	The residence of the applicant; and 
d.	Registration for each vehicle which is licensed; and 
e.	Proof of insurance; and 
f.	Emergency contact number; and 
2.	All registrations issued shall expire September thirtieth of each year. 
(Ord. 1447 § 6, 2006) 
(Ord. No. 1560, § 1, 5-9-2011) 
5.40.070 - Revocation of license. 
    If any person licensed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be convicted of violating any statute, ordinance or regulation in the execution of any work for which a permit is required by the applicable ordinance of the borough of Glen Ridge relevant to landscaping, the borough of Glen Ridge shall revoke the license of such person immediately. The municipal clerk shall not restore such license during such time as the violation for which such conviction was obtained, exists or remains. Five convictions of any applicable ordinance relevant to landscaping in a license year shall result in the lost of a commercial landscaper's license for the remainder of the license year. 
(Ord. 1447 § 7, 2006) 
5.40.080 - Relicensing after revocation. 
    Any person whose license has been revoked under the provisions of this chapter may be relicensed by the municipal clerk when the grounds upon which such license was revoked are removed or corrected and upon payment of the fee prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1447 § 8, 2006) 
5.40.090 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 1.08.010, general penalty, of this code. 
(Ord. 1447 § 9, 2006) 
(Ord. No. 1584, 9-10-2012) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 6.04 - DOGS 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Authority to issue dog licenses. 
    The borough clerk is designated pursuant to Chapter 151 of the Laws of 1941 of the state of New Jersey to license dogs in the borough of Glen Ridge. 
(Ord. 615 § 1, 1941) 
6.04.020 - License fees. 
    Effective on January 1, 1984, and until further amended, the sum to be paid annually for a dog license is fixed at the sum of seven dollars in addition to the New Jersey state registration fee of one dollar as prescribed by the statutes hereinabove mentioned. 
(Ord. 1076 § 1, 1983: Ord. 1066 § 1(a), 1982: Ord. 1025 § 1, 1979: Ord. 866 § 1, 1966: Ord. 745 § 1, 1958: Ord. 615 § 2, 1941) 
6.04.030 - Failure to license dog-Penalty. 
    All persons owning or having the care, custody or control of a dog(s) shall license said dog(s) during the month of January of each year, in accordance with the statutes of the state of New Jersey. Failure to license said dog(s) during January will result in a ten-dollar penalty being levied and ten dollars for each subsequent month. Failure to license said dog(s) by April 1st of each year will result in the matter being placed in the jurisdiction of the municipal court and shall be subject to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars upon conviction. Said fine shall be in addition to the monthly late penalty. 
(Ord. 1066 § 1(b), 1982: Ord. 615 § 2A, 1941) 
6.04.040 - Running at large-Prohibited activities. 
    Each and every person owning, harboring, keeping or having charge of any male or female dog in the borough shall: 
A.	Prevent such dog from running at large upon any public highway, street, alley, park or other public place in the borough at any time; 
B.	Prevent such dog from being on any public highway, street, avenue, alley, park or other public place in the borough at any time unless such dog be accompanied and controlled by a person of the age of seven years or over and be securely confined by an adequate leash not more than eight feet in length; 
C.	Prevent such dog from running at large in the borough upon the lands of any person, other than the person owning, harboring, keeping or having charge of such dog, without the consent of the owner of such lands; 
D.	Prevent such dog from injuring or damaging any vegetable garden, flower garden, lawn, plant, tree, shrubbery, grounds or other property of any person other than the person owning, harboring, keeping or have charge of such dog; 
E.	Prevent such dog from barking, crying, whining, howling or otherwise disturbing the peace or quiet of the neighborhood or sleep of any person for any unreasonable length of time; 
F.	Prevent such dog from causing any injury to any person. 
(Ord. 789 § 1, 1962) 
6.04.050 - Impoundment. 
    Any male or female dog that shall be found running at large upon any public highway, street, avenue, alley, park or other public place in the borough at any time, or that shall be found at any time doing any of the other things mentioned in Section 6.04.040 and which the person owning, harboring, keeping or having charge of such dog is required by this chapter to prevent, shall forthwith be taken and impounded by the police or dog warden of the borough and shall be kept and confined for a period of seven days next thereafter, and shall then be humanely destroyed or otherwise disposed of according to law; provided, however, that within said period of seven days the police or dog warden of the borough shall release such dog to the owner or other person entitled to the possession thereof, upon claim therefor, and upon payment of the expense of keeping such dog, while so impounded, at a reasonable rate per day; and provided further that if any dog, at the time of such taking and impounding thereof, shall wear any registration tag, collar or other harness by means of which the police or dog warden of the borough are enabled to ascertain the name of the person owning, harboring, keeping or having charge of such dog, said police or dog warden shall promptly serve written notice upon such person that such dog has been taken and impounded under the provisions of this chapter, which notice shall be sufficiently served if the same be delivered to such person, or be left at such person's usual or last known place of abode, or be forwarded by mail with prepaid first class postage to such person at his usual or last known place of abode, and such dog meanwhile shall remain impounded for not less than seven days next after the service of said notice, unless such dog be sooner claimed and released as hereinabove provided. 
(Ord. 789 § 2, 1962) 
6.04.060 - Creation of nuisance-Owner responsibility. 
A.	No person owning or having the care, custody or control of a dog shall knowingly or negligently permit such dog to commit any nuisance, and more particularly and without limiting the generality thereof, any excretion of feces upon any public sidewalk or other thoroughfare, or in or upon any public building, or any public park or public playground; or on any private property without the permission of the owner of said property; nor shall any person omit to do any reasonable and proper act, or omit to take any reasonable and proper precaution to prevent any such dog from committing a nuisance in, on or upon any of the places or premises herein specified. 
B.	Any person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any dog which soils, defiles, defecates on or commits any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, sidewalk, passageway, bypath, play area, park or any place where people congregate or walk, or upon any public property whatsoever, or upon any private property, without the permission of the owner of such property, shall immediately remove all feces deposited by such dog by any sanitary method approved by the local health authority. 
(Ord. 1040 § 1, 1980: Ord. 789 § 3, 1962) 
6.04.070 - Vicious dog-Penalty. 
A.	It is unlawful for any person to possess, harbor or conceal a vicious dog, or one suffering from a contagious disease or from the bites of another animal, except under strict medical care; and a dog so affected shall be kept closely confined until pronounced cured by the attending veterinarian. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of up to one thousand dollars but not less than five hundred dollars and/or up to ninety days imprisonment. 
B.	Any dog which has attacked or bitten any human being or which habitually attacks other dogs or domestic animals is hereby defined to be a vicious dog, for the purposes of the section. 
C.	It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or the person designated by the chief of police, to receive and cause to be investigated complaints against dogs. When any dog complained of shall be deemed by the chief of police, or his or her designee, to be vicious, he or she shall cause a complaint to be filed against the owner or person harboring such a dog and shall cause said complaint and summons to be served upon said owner or person harboring such dog for a hearing to be held before the municipal judge, at which time said judge shall inquire into the facts and give all interested persons an opportunity to be heard under oath and to be represented by counsel. 
D.	If the judge shall decide in accordance with the evidence before him or her, that such dog complained of is vicious as defined by this section, notice of such decision shall be given to the owner or person harboring such dog. Thereafter, no such dog determined as aforesaid to be a vicious dog shall be permitted to run at large, and that, further, the owner or person harboring such a dog shall have it securely muzzled and under leash at all times when out of doors. The owner or person harboring any such vicious dog who shall suffer or permit such dog to run at large, or be upon any street, public or private place in the borough while not securely muzzled and on a leash shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. Any person(s) found guilty of violating any provision of this section, shall be subject to, upon conviction thereof, a fine of up to one thousand dollars but not less that five hundred dollars and/or up to ninety days imprisonment. 
E.	Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the power of the borough of Glen Ridge or any officer or department to enforce any provisions of its charter, or any other provisions of its code or regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to prevent or punish violations thereof, and the powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the borough by any other law or provision of the Glen Ridge Code. 
F.	If any clause, sentence, subdivision, paragraph, section or part of the ordinance codified in this chapter be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder thereof, but shall be confined in its operation to the clause, sentence, subdivision, paragraph, section, or part thereof, directly involved in the controversy in which said judgment shall have been rendered. 
(Ord. 1451, 2006: Ord. 1066 § 1(c), 1982: Ord. 615 § 4, 1941) 
6.04.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    That any person who shall violate this chapter or any of the terms or provisions thereof, or do any act or thing herein prohibited, or neglect, fail, refuse to do any act or thing herein required to be done, shall, upon conviction thereof before the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer authorized to hear and determine the matter, forfeit and pay such fine, not exceeding the sum of twenty-five dollars for the first offense and not exceeding the sum of one hundred dollars for any subsequent offense, as shall be imposed by the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer in his or her discretion, or (if the party so convicted be a natural person) be imprisoned in the borough jail or county jail for such a term, not exceeding ten days, as the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer in his or her discretion shall determine; provided, however, that the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer shall have power in his or her discretion to impose sentence of both fine and imprisonment not exceeding the maximum limits fixed in this section. 
(Ord. 1381, 2003: Ord. 789 § 4, 1962) 
Chapter 6.08 - CATS 
Sections: 

6.08.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth below: 
    "Cat" means and includes any member of the domestic feline species, male, female or neutered which has attained the age of seven months or which possesses a set of permanent teeth. 
    "Certificate of exemption" means a certificate issued by a duly authorized veterinarian stating that because of an infirmity, other physical condition or regimen therapy the inoculation of a particular cat against rabies is deemed inadvisable. 
    "Inoculated against rabies" means inoculated by a duly licensed veterinarian with a rabies vaccine of a type approved by and administered in accordance with the recommendations of the United States Department of Agriculture and the United States Department of Human Services. 
    "Owner of a cat" means and includes any person who has a right of property in or custody of a cat, who harbors or maintains a cat, or who knowingly permits a cat to remain on or about any premises occupied by that person within the borough. 
    "Resident of the borough" means a person whose ordinary dwelling place is within the borough. 
(Ord. 1185 § 1, 1991) 
6.08.020 - Inoculation against rabies-Required. 
A.	Every resident of the borough who is the owner of a cat shall have and keep such cat inoculated against rabies at all times, unless a certificate of exemption issued as to such cat is currently effective. 
B.	Upon the request of any authorized agent of the Glen Ridge board of health, or upon the request of any police officer or animal control officer, a resident of the borough who is the owner of a cat shall provide evidence that such cat has been inoculated against rabies and that the period during which such inoculation is considered to be effective has not expired. 
C.	Exemption. The provision of this section shall not apply to a cat being kept in a pet shop or in a veterinary establishment. 
(Ord. 1185 §§ 2-4, 1991) 
6.08.030 - Impoundment of cats-Provisions and regulations. 
A.	Any person appointed for the purpose by the board of health of the borough shall take in custody and impound or cause to be taken into custody and impounded, and thereafter destroyed or offered for adoption as provided in this section: 
1.	Any cat off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring said cat which said official or his or her agent or agents have reason to believe is a stray cat; 
2.	Any female cat in season off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring said cat; 
3.	Any cat or other animal which is suspected to be rabid; 
4.	Any cat or other animal off the premises of the owner reported to, or observed by, a certified animal control officer to be ill, injured or creating a threat to public health, safety or welfare, or otherwise interfering with the enjoyment of property. 
B.	If any animal so seized wears a collar or harness having inscribed thereon or attached thereto the name and address of any person, or the owner or the person keeping or harboring said animal is known, any person authorized by the governing body shall forthwith serve on the person whose address is given on the collar, or on the owner or the person keeping or harboring said animal, if known, a notice in writing stating that the animal has been seized and will be liable to be offered for adoption or destroyed if not claimed within seven days after the service of the notice. 
C.	A notice under this section may be served either by delivering it to the person on whom it is to be served or by leaving it at the person's usual or last known place of abode, or at the address given on the collar, or by forwarding it by post in a prepaid letter addressed to that person at his or her usual or last known place of abode, or to the address given on the collar. 
D.	Any person authorized by the board of health may cause an animal to be destroyed in a manner causing as little pain as possible and consistent with the provisions of N.J.S.A. 4:22-19 or offered for adoption seven days after seizure; provided that: 
1.	Notice is given as set forth above and the animal remains unclaimed; or 
2.	The owner or person keeping or harboring the animal has not claimed the animal and paid all expenses incurred by reason of its detention including maintenance costs; or 
3.	The owner or person keeping or harboring a cat which was unlicensed at the time of seizure does not produce a license and registration tag for the cat. 
E.	At the time of adoption, the right of ownership in the animal shall transfer to the new owner. No cat or other animal so caught and detained or procured, obtained, sent or brought to a pound or shelter shall be sold or otherwise made available for the purpose of experimentation. Any person who sells or otherwise makes available any such cat or other animal for the purpose of experimentation shall be guilty of a disorderly persons offense. 
F.	After observation, any animal seized under this section suspected of being rabid shall immediately be reported to the health officer. 
(Ord. 1185 § 5, 1991) 
6.08.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any resident of the borough who violates or fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty-five dollars nor more than five hundred dollars (26:3-70 Fine and Penalties). Each day that a violation of or failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1185 § 6, 1991) 
Chapter 6.10 - DISPOSAL OF PET WASTE 
Sections: 

6.10.010 - Purpose. 
    A chapter to establish requirements for the proper disposal of pet solid waste in the borough of Glen Ridge, so as to protect public health, safety and welfare, and to prescribe penalties for failure to comply. 
(Ord. 1429 § 1, 2005) 
6.10.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings stated herein, unless their use in the text of this chapter clearly demonstrates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    "Immediate" means that the pet solid waste is removed at once, without delay. 
    "Owner/keeper" means any person who shall possess, maintain, house or harbor any pet or otherwise have custody of any pet, whether or not the owner of such pet. 
    "Person" means any individual, corporation, company, partnership, firm, association, or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
    "Pet" means a domesticated animal (other than a disability assistance animal) kept for amusement or companionship. 
    "Pet solid waste" means waste matter expelled from the bowels of the pet; excrement. 
    "Proper disposal" means placement in a designated waste receptacle, or other suitable container, and discarded in a refuse container which is regularly emptied by the municipality or some other refuse collector; or disposal into a system designed to convey domestic sewage for proper treatment and disposal. 
(Ord. 1429 § 2, 2005) 
6.10.030 - Requirement for disposal. 
    All pet owners and keepers are required to immediately and properly dispose of their pet's solid waste deposited on any property, public or private, not owned or possessed by that person. 
(Ord. 1429 § 3, 2005) 
6.10.040 - Exemptions. 
    Any owner or keeper who requires the use of a disability assistance animal shall be exempt from the provisions of this section while such animal is being used for that purpose. 
(Ord. 1429 § 4, 2005) 
6.10.050 - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the Glen Ridge police department and the board of health of Montclair. 
(Ord. 1429 § 5, 2005) 
6.10.060 - Violations and penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 1.08.010, general penalty, of this code. 
(Ord. 1429 § 6, 2005) 
(Ord. No. 1584, 9-10-2012) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.04 - ALARM SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

8.04.010 - Findings. 
    The borough council finds that the existence within the borough of external audible alarm systems which do not contain automatic shut-off systems permits the continuing emission of loud alarm signals without termination, and that, in the event of unavailability of those able to control and terminate the alarm, persons in the vicinity are exposed to these loud noises for lengthy and indefinite periods without means of obtaining relief; that this condition is inimical to the public health and welfare and to the well-being of persons within the borough; and that lengthy emission of alarm signals is not necessary to the legitimate purposes of the property owner or occupant. The council further finds that many residents and commercial entities have installed burglar, fire and other warning devices within their residences or buildings, and that false alarms from said devices require a response and the unproductive diversion of personnel and equipment from their public safety function within the borough. 
(Ord. 1079 § 1, 1984) 
8.04.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish regulations concerning the operation and maintenance of certain alarm systems within the borough and to provide penalties for violations of any of the provisions set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1079 § 2, 1984) 
8.04.030 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    "Alarm console" means the control panels in public safety headquarters giving alarm indications and locations. 
    "Alarm device" means any type of alarm actuating equipment which provides warning of intrusion, fire, smoke, burglary, flood, or like peril, including a direct alarm, dial alarm or local alarm. 
    "Alarm system" means the installation in or on one or more buildings of one or more alarm devices. 
    "Dial alarm" means the type of device which employs an automatic dialing system, precoded, to connect with a telephone in public safety headquarters. 
    "Direct alarm" means an alarm device which has a direct line to an alarm console. 
    "False alarm" means the activation of an alarm system where an emergency does not exist. False alarms will not include: activations caused by public utility interruptions where such interruptions have been reported to the public safety department; or those activations caused by a natural event or a malfunction of the public safety department equipment; or those activations caused by testing or repair of the system, provided the public safety department has been notified before such tests or repairs commence. 
    "Local alarm" means any alarm device, other than a direct alarm or dial alarm, which when activated, produces an external emergency signal. 
    "Person" means any natural person, partnership or corporation, limited partnership, association, business, club or organization. 
(Ord. 1079 § 3, 1984) 
8.04.040 - Notification before tests or repairs. 
    All persons responsible for an alarm system within the borough shall notify the public safety department before tests or repairs of the system commence and after completion of the same. 
(Ord. 1079 § 4, 1984) 
8.04.050 - Registration of alarm system. 
    Any person that owns, maintains or has on his/her property an alarm system with the borough of Glen Ridge shall be required to register annually with the borough police department the existence of the alarms. Alarms installed and in service must be registered by April 15th of each year. Alarms installed and put into service after April 15th of any year must be registered within forty-five days of installation and commencement of service. If registration is not received by the applicable time, the alarm owner will be subject to the penalty prescribed in Section 8.04.110. Registration forms will be made available at the public safety building and the following information will be required as part of the alarms' registration: the location of any alarm device so owned or operated, the type of device, the name, address and telephone number of at least two persons who can be reached in case of an emergency or malfunction of the alarm device in order that the device can be shut off or temporarily disconnected. The person owning, maintaining or having any such alarm system on his/her property may, but is not required to leave a key to the property with the public safety department to enable a member of the department to turn off the device when necessary. In the event of any change in the provided information, the person responsible for the device shall submit to the public safety department, in writing, such revised information within thirty days of any such change. 
(Ord. 1343 § 1, 2000) 
8.04.060 - Connection with public safety department alarm console. 
    Any connection to the public safety department alarm console shall be of a type inspected and approved by the contractor servicing the public safety department alarm console at the time of installation of the alarm device.
