Chapter 10.24 - PERMIT PARKING IN PUBLIC PARKING LOTS 
Sections: 

10.24.010 - Permits required-Where. 
    No vehicle shall be permitted to park in the public parking lots designated in Section 10.24.040 except a vehicle which satisfies each and all of the following criteria: 
A.	The vehicle is registered for noncommercial, passenger use; 
B.	The vehicle is parked within an area marked on the pavement thereof for the parking of vehicles; 
C.	The vehicle displays a permit issued for such parking; and 
D.	The permit is displayed as directed in Section 10.24.030. 
(Ord. 1379 § 2, 2002) 
10.24.020 - Obtaining permits. 
    All permits, other than permits for board of education employees, may be obtained from the borough cashier. Permits issued for board of education employees shall be of a decal type issued by and at the discretion of the borough administrator. Only one permit per vehicle may be issued. 
(Ord. 1379 § 3, 2002) 
10.24.030 - Types of permits in public parking lots. 
    The following rules shall apply for parking permits in public parking lots: 
A.	Types of Permits. 
1.	Permits for Overnight Resident Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to residents for parking between the hours of two a.m. and seven a.m. 
b.	No fees shall be charged for this type of permit. 
c.	Proof of residency is required, such as, a valid driver's license and/or registration to the vehicle. 
d.	A valid driver's license and registration to the vehicle must be presented. 
e.	Decal will be affixed to the rear window, lower corner of the driver's side or as instructed by the borough police department. 
f.	The vehicle owner will be required to remove the vehicle from the parking lot by seven a.m. or be subject to a summons and towing at the owner's expense. 
g.	The permitted vehicle must be registered, insured, have current inspection sticker and maintained in operating condition during the duration of the permit. Failure to comply will result in the revocation of the permit. 
2.	Permits for Daytime Resident Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to residents for parking between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. 
b.	Fees shall be chrged for this type of permit according to the fee schedule in Section 10.24.030(B) "Permit Fee Schedule." 
c.	Proof of residency is required, such as, a valid driver's license and/or registration to the vehicle. 
d.	A valid driver's license and registration to the vehicle must be presented. 
e.	Decal will be affixed to the rear window, lower corner of the driver's side or as instructed by the borough police department. 
f.	The vehicle owner will be required to remove the vehicle from the parking lot by seven p.m. or be subject to a summons and towing at the owner's expense. 
3.	Permits for Daytime Nonresident Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to nonresidents for parking between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. 
b.	Fees shall be charged for this type of permit according to the fee schedule in Section 10.24.030(B) "Permit Fee Schedule." 
c.	A valid driver's license and registration to the vehicle must be presented. 
d.	Decal will be affixed to the rear window, lower corner of the driver's side or as instructed by the borough police department. 
e.	Vehicles must be removed from the parking lot by seven p.m. or be subject to a summons and towing at the owner's expense. 
4.	Permits for Twenty-four Hours Resident Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to residents for parking for twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. 
b.	Fees shall be charged for this type of permit according to the fee schedule in Section 10.24.030(B) "Permit Fee Schedule." 
c.	Proof of residency is required, such as, a valid driver's license and/or registration to the vehicle. 
d.	A valid driver's license and registration to the vehicle must be presented. 
e.	Decal will be affixed to the rear window, lower corner of the driver's side or as instructed by the borough police department. 
f.	The permitted vehicle must be registered, insured, have current inspection sticker and maintained in operating condition during the duration of the permit. Failure to comply will result in the revocation of the permit. 
5.	Permits for Employee Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to borough officials or employees for parking for twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. 
b.	Permits issued for borough employees shall be of a decal type issued by the borough administrator, affixed to the rear window, lower left driver's side. 
c.	Only one sticker may be issued to each municipal employee. 
d.	The permitted vehicle must be registered, insured, have current inspection sticker and maintained in operating condition during the duration of the permit. Failure to comply will result in the revocation of the permit. 
6.	Parking Between Five p.m. and Two a.m. on Weekends. 
a.	No permit is required for either resident or nonresident parking between five p.m. on Friday to two a.m. on Monday morning. 
7.	Designated Parking Spaces. 
a.	Only vehicles with employee permits shall be parked within a parking space designated as such by appropriate signage. Vehicles with twenty-four-hour permits shall be parked within a parking space designated as such by appropriate signage or markings on the pavement. 
B.	Permit Fee Schedule. 
1.	Herman Street Lot: 
Overnight resident parking $-0- Daytime, resident $520 Daytime, nonresident $800 24 hours, resident $520  
2.	Hillside Avenue Lot: 
Overnight resident parking $-0- Daytime, resident $400 Daytime, nonresident $600 24 hours, resident $400 24 hours, nonresident $800  
3.	Clark Street Lot: 
Overnight resident parking $-0- Daytime, resident $200 24 hours, resident $200  
4.	Benson Street Parking Lot: 
Overnight resident parking $-0- Daytime, resident $180 Daytime, nonresident $400 24 hours, resident $180  
    The fee for any permit purchased prior to the last day of September in any calendar year will be the applicable yearly fee set forth above. Any permit purchased after the last day of September in any calendar year will be sold at a monthly rate for the remaining months of the year. 
C.	Number of Permits Issued. The number of permits issued for parking in public parking lots shall be established by the borough administrator. 
(Ord. 1489 § 1, 2008; Ord. 1379 § 4, 2002) 
(Ord. No. 1519, 8-10-2009; Ord. No. 1540, § 1, 11-22-2010; Ord. No. 1558, 4-25-2011) 
10.24.040 - Designated public parking areas. 
A.	Benson Street Parking Lot. Situated on the south side of Wildwood Terrace adjacent to the New Jersey transit railroad right-of-way. 
B.	Hillside Avenue Parking Lot. Situated on the southeast corner of Bloomfield Avenue and Hillside Avenue and extending south on Hillside Avenue and east on Bloomfield Avenue. 
C.	Herman Street Parking Lot. Situated on the westerly side of Herman Street. 
    No person shall park any vehicles in the borough parking area situated on the southerly side of Herman Street, adjacent to the municipal building, except for employee vehicles. 
D.	Clark Street Parking Lot. Situated on the west side of Clark Street between Toney's Brook and the Montclair Branch of the New Jersey transit railroad right-of-way. 
E.	Spaces for the vehicles operated by and for the police, fire and public works departments shall be assigned by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. 1148 § 4, 1988; Ord. 1005 §§ 1, 2, 1977) 
(Ord. No. 1628, 5-11-2015) 
10.24.050 - Handicapped parking spaces. 
A.	Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 39:4-197-5, no person shall park any vehicle in any space which is designated as a handicapped parking space and which is appropriately marked as such without a special vehicle identification card. Any vehicle parking in a restricted parking space without a special identification card shall be liable to a fine of one hundred dollars for the first offense and for second and subsequent offenses a fine of one hundred dollars and community service. 
B.	Each handicapped parking space shall be marked by a vertical sign indicating that it is a handicapped parking space. The sign shall contain the penalty for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1193 §§ 1, 2, 1991) 
10.24.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.	Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding the sum of fifty dollars, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding sixty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment for each offense. 
B.	In the case of repeated or continuous offenses, the department of public safety, police division, will have the right to have the vehicle removed (towed) and stored at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. 1148 § 5, 1988) 
Chapter 10.28 - SCHOOL PARKING RESTRICTIONS 
Sections: 

10.28.010 - Definitions. 
    The following terms used in this chapter shall be taken and construed to mean as follows: 
    "Park" shall include the placing, staying or waiting of any type of vehicle. 
    "Person" shall include any person, corporation, partnership or form of organization. 
    "Vehicle" shall be construed to include all vehicles propelled by any type of motor, animal or other power. 
(Ord. 659 § 1, 1949) 
10.28.020 - Findings. 
A.	The parking of vehicles in the semi-circle driveway in front of the Middle School on the east side of Ridgewood Avenue north of Bloomfield Avenue constitutes a hazard to the safety and welfare of persons attending or using the Middle School and would hamper and prevent access to the Middle School by fire and police apparatus in the event of an emergency. 
B.	The parking of vehicles in the semi-circle driveway in front of Linden Avenue School, on the north side of Linden Avenue east of Hawthorne Avenue, constitutes a hazard to the safety and welfare of persons attending or using the Linden Avenue School and would hamper and prevent access to Linden Avenue School by fire and police apparatus in the event of an emergency. 
(Ord. 1073 § 1, 1983: Ord. 911 § 2, 1970: Ord. 659 §§ 2, 2A, 1949) 
10.28.030 - Parking prohibitions. 
    No vehicle shall park, at any time, in or on the semi-circle driveway, or any portion thereof, located in front of the Middle School on the east side of Ridgewood Avenue north of Bloomfield Avenue; and no vehicle shall park, at any time, in the semi-circle driveway, or any portion thereof, located in front of the Linden Avenue School on the north side of Linden Avenue east of Hawthorne Avenue. 
(Ord. 1073 § 2, 1983: Ord. 911 § 2, 1970: Ord. 659 § 3, 1949) 
10.28.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, on conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding the sum of fifty dollars, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding sixty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment for each offense. 
(Ord. 659 § 4, 1949) 
Chapter 10.30 - PERMIT PARKING IN THE VICINITY OF THE HEALTH CARE ZONE 
Sections: 

10.30.010 - Purpose. 
    The council desires to put into effect a permit parking system to prevent such overflow of vehicular traffic. It is the express purpose of this chapter to reduce traffic conditions resulting from the overflow of traffic into and the overcrowding of streets exclusively or primarily serving residential land uses with parked vehicles. This will protect the streets and their inhabitants from excessive noise, unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their residences, preserve the residential character of the streets, to promote efficiency in the maintenance of the streets, to preserve and protect the safety of children and other pedestrians and traffic safety on such streets. 
(Ord. 1293 § 1, 1997) 
10.30.020 - Permit parking zone. 
A.	Parking by permit only in designated residential areas is effective on the following described streets or portions thereof in the borough between the hours of eight a.m. and eight p.m. daily: 
1.	North side of Inness Place from Montclair town line to Sherman Avenue; 
2.	South side of Inness Place from Montclair town line to Sherman Avenue; 
3.	North side of Roswell Terrace from Montclair town line to Sherman Avenue; 
4.	East side of Sherman Avenue from Oxford Street south to Bay Avenue; 
5.	East and west side of Sherman Avenue from Bay Avenue south to the southern side of Laurel Place; 
6.	South side of Bay Avenue from Sherman Avenue to Ridgewood Avenue; 
7.	South side of Hathaway Place from Highland Avenue to Sherman Avenue; 
8.	South side of Laurel Place from Highland Avenue to Sherman Avenue. 
B.	From Glen Ridge Community Pool opening day to pool closing day: 
1.	East side of Clark Street from Bloomfield Avenue to Thomas Street. 
2.	Both sides of Thomas Street from the Bloomfield Township border to Clark Street. 
C.	Permit parking for teachers and staff of private schools: 
1.	Clark Street from Ridgewood Avenue East to Hillside Avenue; 
2.	Baldwin Street on the South side from the Montclair Town Line to a point two hundred fifty feet east; 
3.	Highland Avenue from Baldwin Street to a point four hundred eighteen feet south. 
(Ord. 1497 (part), 2008; Ord. 1386 § 1, 2003; Ord. 1293 § 2, 1997) 
(Ord. No. 1645, § 1, 7-11-2016) 
10.30.030 - Issuance of permits. 
A.	Parking permit placards shall be issued through the borough administrative office for automobiles and noncommercially registered pick-up trucks and vans. Applicants for such permits shall be required to present proof of residence. 
B.	Each residence within the borough will be entitled to a maximum of five permit placards at no cost. Replacement for lost or destroyed placards will be at a cost to the resident of two dollars per permit placard. 
C.	When a residence changes ownership the permit placards must be returned to the administrative office in the municipal building. The new homeowner will have to apply for the issuance of five new placards. 
D.	Permit placards issued shall be subject to all the conditions and restrictions set forth in this chapter and of the permit parking zone for which they were issued, including conditions or restrictions which may be altered or amended from time to time. The issuance of such permit shall not be construed to be a permit for, or approval of, any violation of any provisions of this code or any other law or regulation. 
(Ord. 1293 § 3, 1997) 
10.30.040 - Prohibitions. 
A.	Permit placards shall be affixed to the rear view mirror when parked on a street in the permit parking zone, this will make the permit placard visible to the enforcement officer from the street. 
B.	No vehicle displaying a permit placard shall be parked or stopped adjacent to any curb in a permit parking zone in violation of any posted or noticed prohibition or restriction. 
C.	It is unlawful for any person to sell, rent, transfer or lease, or cause to be sold, rented, transferred or leased, for any value or consideration or no value or consideration any parking permit placard. Upon conviction for a violation of this subsection, all permit placards issued to, or for the benefit of, the dwelling unit for which the sold, rented, transferred or leased permit was authorized shall be void and returned to the administrative office in the municipal building. 
D.	It is unlawful for any person to acquire for value or otherwise use any parking permit placard, except as provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1293 § 4, 1997) 
10.30.050 - Penalty for violation. 
    Penalty for violation of this chapter shall be a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or imprisonment for a period of thirty days, and revocation of the parking permit privilege. 
(Ord. 1293 § 5, 1997) 
10.30.060 - Exemptions. 
A.	People visiting residences in the permit parking zone will be required to display a permit placard in their vehicle. The visitor will obtain a permit placard from the resident he or she is visiting. When the person is done visiting, the permit placard will be removed from the vehicle and returned to the resident. 
B.	Residences having a party or large gathering where there are not enough permit placards to hand out will be required to notify the police department in advance. 
C.	Contractors, service and delivery vehicles bearing the name and address of a commercial business may park without a permit during the time they are rendering service to a residence within the permit parking zone. 
D.	Emergency vehicles and public service, telephone and other public utility vehicles may park without a permit during the time they are rendering service to a residence in the permit parking zone. 
(Ord. 1293 § 6, 1997) 
Chapter 10.32 - PARKING RESTRICTIONS ON DESIGNATED STREETS 
Sections: 

10.32.010 - No parking any time. 
    No vehicle shall be parked at any time on the following named streets, sides or portions thereof: 
1.	North side of Baldwin Street from Clinton Road to Forest Avenue. 
2.	South side of Baldwin Street from Clinton Road to Forest Avenue.

B.	Street parking permit placards shall be issued through the borough or police administrative office to residents for automobiles and noncommercial registered pick-up trucks and vans for use only in front of the resident's home. Applicants for such permits shall be required to present proof of residence. 
C.	Each residence within the three hours parking time limit zone will be entitled to a maximum of three permit placards at no cost. Replacement for lost or destroyed placards will be at a cost to the resident of two dollars per permit placard. 
D.	When a residence changes ownership the permit placards must be returned to the administrative office in the municipal building. The new homeowner will have to apply for the issuance of three new placards. 
E.	Permit placards issued shall be subject to all the conditions and restrictions set forth in this chapter and of the permit parking zone for which they were issued, including conditions or restrictions which may be altered or amended from time to time. The issuance of such permit shall not be construed to be a permit for, or approval of, any violation of any provisions of this code or any other law or regulation.

10.32.190 - No parking-Three a.m. to six a.m. 
A.	Except as set forth in subsection B of this section, no vehicle shall be parked on any streets of the borough, excepting county roads under the jurisdiction of the board of chosen freeholders of the county of Essex, between the hours of three a.m. and six a.m. 
B.	1. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection A of this section, where, by reason of exceptional narrowness, shallowness or shape of a specific piece of property or by reason of other extraordinary and exceptional situations or conditions which preclude the accommodation of off-street parking, thereby resulting in practical and economic hardship to the owner or a tenant or resident of the affected property or a part thereof and after evidence having been provided that other parking options in the area are not available, then, upon application to and approval by the mayor and council, the chief of police is authorized to issue a permit for the on-street parking of not more than one vehicle per dwelling unit during the hours of three a.m. to six a.m. (except during snow emergencies) on the street abutting the lot upon which such owner, tenants or residents reside. 
2.	Any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall not exceed a period of twelve months from the date of its issuance; provided, however, that in those instances where the physical characteristics of the lot preclude the accommodation of any off-street parking whatsoever, the mayor and council may authorize the chief of police to issue an on-street parking permit for a period or periods longer than twelve months but in no event more than three years; provided further, however, that notwithstanding any of the foregoing any permit issued under this section shall expire upon the change in residence of the permittee. 
 The mayor and council may authorize the chief of police to issue an on-street parking permit(s) for a period or periods longer than three years if the following conditions are met: 
  No driveway currently exists on the property. 
  No easement allowing parking on another property exists. 
  Construction of a driveway is precluded due to narrowness of lot or topography. 
  No public parking lot is located within 500 feet of the permittee's residence. 
3.	If the renewal of any permit issued under this section is desired, the permittee shall, at least thirty days prior to the expiration date of the existing permit, submit an application to the mayor and council for renewal. 
4.	Permits under this section shall not be transferable. 
5.	An applicant seeking a permit to be issued under this section must file with the office of the chief of the police an application in form approved by the mayor and council and pay a nonrefundable application fee of fifty dollars as a condition of the application being processed and considered. 
6.	A permittee to whom a permit is issued under this section must pay an annual fee of one hundred dollars. 
7.	From Memorial Day to Labor Day, parking is permitted from three a.m. to six a.m. on Clark Street from Bloomfield Avenue to Toney's Brook by resident permit only. 
(Ord. 1387 § 1, 2003; Ord. 1257 § 1, 1994: Ord. 928 § 1, 1971: Ord. 790 § 15, 1962) 
(Ord. No. 1613, 5-12-2014)

10.32.220 - Excepted days. 
    The provisions of this chapter, except Sections 10.32.010, 10.32.190, 10.32.200, 10.32.230 and 10.32.240, shall not apply on any Saturday, Sunday, New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day or Christmas Day. 
(Ord. 790 § 20, 1962)

(Ord. 790 § 21, 1962) 
10.32.240 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by New Jersey Statute, any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, on conviction thereof, be punished by a fine in any sum not exceeding the sum of fifty dollars, by imprisonment for a period not exceeding fifteen days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, for each offense. 
(Ord. 790 § 22, 1962) 
Chapter 10.35 - PERMIT PARKING ON PUBLIC STREETS 
Sections: 

10.35.010 - Permits required-Where. 
    No vehicle shall be permitted to park in those street public parking areas of the borough designated in Section 10.35.030 except a vehicle which satisfies each and all of the following criteria: 
A.	The vehicle is registered for noncommercial, passenger use; 
B.	The vehicle is parked within an area marked for the parking of vehicles; 
C.	The vehicle displays the appropriate and applicable permit issued for the parking area; and 
D.	The permit is displayed as directed in Section 10.24.030. 
(Ord. 1379 § 6 (part), 2002: Ord. 1354 § 6 (part), 2001) 
10.35.020 - Obtaining permits. 
    All permits, other than permits for borough employee and student permits, may be obtained from the borough cashier. Permits issued for borough employees shall be of a decal type issued by and at the discretion of the borough administrator. Only one permit per vehicle may be issued. 
(Ord. 1379 § 6 (part), 2002: Ord. 1354 § 6 (part), 2001) 
10.35.030 - On-street permit parking areas. 
A.	On Street Permit Parking Areas for Faculty. Between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. Monday through Friday, parking is permitted only by borough employees holding a valid employee parking permit on the following designated areas of the following described streets: 
1.	West side of High Street, between Bloomfield Avenue and Belleville Avenue;

3.	East side of Ridgewood Avenue from Clark Street to Appleton Place; 
4.	West side of Ridgewood Avenue from centerline of Lincoln Street to a point 201.69 feet north; 
5.	West side of Ridgewood Avenue between Lincoln Street and Old Oak Road. 
6.	South side of Clark Street from a point seventy-five feet east of the intersection with Ridgewood Avenue to a point three hundred ten feet east of the intersection with Ridgewood Avenue. 
7.	North side of Clark Street from the intersection of Ridgewood Avenue to a point two hundred eight feet east. 
B.	On Street Permit Parking Areas for Commuters. Between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. Monday through Friday, parking is permitted only by borough residents holding a valid and applicable residential parking permit on the following designated areas of the following described streets: 
1.	West side of Ridgewood Avenue from Woodland Avenue to a point 201.69 feet north of the centerline of Lincoln Street. 
C.	Between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. Monday through Friday, Student holding a valid student parking permit must only park on the following designated areas of the following described streets: 
1.	West side of Ridgewood Avenue between Lincoln Street and Old Oak Road; 
2.	East side of Ridgewood Avenue from a point one hundred thirty-five feet south of Clark Street to Appleton Road; 
3.	Both sides Lincoln Street from Ridgewood Avenue to two hundred eighty feet west of Ridgewood Avenue. 
D.	For Employees of 123 and 200 Highland Avenue and the residence located at 147 Highland Avenue between the hours of seven a.m. and seven p.m. Monday through Friday, parking is permitted only by such employees/resident holding a valid and applicable residential parking permit on the following designated area of the following described streets: 
1.	West side of Highland Avenue from Bay Street to Baldwin Street; south side of Baldwin Street from Highland Avenue one hundred feet west. 
(Ord. 1420 § 1, 2005; Ord. 1379 § 6 (part), 2002: Ord. 1354 § 6 (part), 2001) 
(Ord. No. 1582, 10-9-2012; Ord. No. 1601, 11-25-2013; Ord. No. 1605, 12-23-2013; Ord. No. 1646, § 1, 8-8-2016) 
10.35.040 - Types of permits for parking on public streets. 
    The following rules shall apply for parking permits on public streets: 
A.	Types of Permits. 
1.	Permits for Daytime Resident Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to residents for parking between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. 
b.	There will be fees charged for this type of permit according to the fee scheduled in Section 10.35.040(B) "Permit Fee Schedule." 
c.	Proof of residency is required, such as, a valid driver's license and/or registration to the vehicle. 
d.	A valid driver's license and registration to the vehicle must be presented. 
e.	Decal will be affixed to the rear window, lower corner of the driver's side or as instructed by the borough police department. 
2.	Permits for Daytime Nonresident Parking: 
a.	Permits issued for non-residents for parking between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m. 
b.	There will be fees charged for this type of permit according to the fee schedule in Section 10.35.040(B) "Permit Fee Schedule." 
c.	A valid driver's license and registration to the vehicle must be presented. 
d.	Decal will be affixed to the rear window, lower corner of the driver's side or as instructed by the borough police department. 
3.	Permits for Employee Parking: 
a.	Permits may be issued to employees for parking twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. 
b.	Permits issued for employees shall be of a decal type issued by the borough administrator, affixed to the rear window, lower left driver's side. 
c.	Only one sticker may be issued to each employee. 
    Permit stickers issued shall be subject to all the conditions and restrictions set forth in this chapter and of the permit parking zone for which it was issued, including conditions or restrictions which may be altered or amended from time to time. The issuance of such permit shall not be construed to be a permit for, or approval of, any violation of any provisions of this code. 
B.	Permit Fee Schedule.

    The fee for any permit purchased prior to the last day of September in any calendar year will be the applicable yearly fee set forth above. Any permit purchased after the last day of September in any calendar year will be sold at a monthly rate for the remaining months of the year. 
C.	Number of Permits Issued. The number of permits issued for parking in designated on-street permit parking areas shall be established by the borough administrator. 
(Ord. 1420 § 2, 2005; Ord. 1379 § 6 (part), 2002: Ord. 1354 § 6 (part), 2001) 
(Ord. No. 1558, 4-25-2011) 
10.35.050 - Prohibitions. 
    The following activities are prohibited: 
A.	No vehicle displaying a permit sticker shall be parked or stopped adjacent to any curb in an on-street permit parking zone in violation of any posted or noticed prohibition or restriction. 
B.	It is unlawful for any person to sell, rent, transfer or lease, or cause to be sold, rented, transferred, or leased, for any value or consideration or no value or consideration any parking permit sticker. Upon conviction for a violation of this subsection, all permit stickers issued to, or for the benefit of, the owner of the vehicle for which the sold, rented, transferred or leased permit was authorized shall be void and returned to the administrative office in the municipal building. 
C.	It is unlawful for any person to acquire for value or otherwise use any parking permit sticker, except as provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1379 § 6 (part), 2002: Ord. 1354 § 6 (part), 2001) 
10.35.060 - Penalty for violation. 
A.	Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding the sum of fifty dollars, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding sixty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment for each offense. 
B.	In the case of repeated or continuous offenses, the department of public safety, police division, will have the right to have the vehicle removed (towed) and stored at the owner's expense and/or his or her permit revoked. 
(Ord. 1379 § 6 (part), 2002: Ord. 1354 § 6 (part), 2001) 
Chapter 10.36 - PARKING RESTRICTIONS IN SNOWY CONDITIONS 
Sections: 

10.36.010 - Parking prohibitions. 
A.	Whenever snow has fallen and the accumulation is such that it covers the street or highway, no vehicle shall be parked on the following main traveled or major roadways or portions thereof: 
1.	Ridgewood Avenue from the East Orange Line to Bay Avenue; 
2.	Washington Street from the Montclair Line to the Bloomfield Line. 
B.	The above parking prohibitions shall remain in effect after the snow has ceased until the streets have been plowed sufficiently and to the extent that parking will not interfere with the normal flow of traffic. 
(Ord. 788 § 1, 1961) 
10.36.020 - Declaration of emergency-Posting of signs. 
    Upon the declaration of an emergency, there shall be no parking upon streets or sections of streets where temporary "EMERGENCY NO PARKING" signs are displayed. The chief of police, or in the chief's absence the ranking police officer, is authorized to declare an emergency and to direct the posting of said "EMERGENCY NO PARKING" signs when weather conditions, accidents, fires, or public celebrations dictate or require the avoidance of hazards or other conditions which interfere with the free flow of traffic. Notification that the "EMERGENCY NO PARKING" signs are being or will be posted shall be given to the operator or owner of any vehicle which has been parked prior to the posting of the signs. 
(Ord. 788 § 2, 1961) 
10.36.030 - Vehicles in violation-Removal. 
    Any unoccupied vehicle parked or standing in violation of this chapter shall be deemed a nuisance and a menace to the safe and proper regulation of traffic and any peace officer may provide for the removal of such vehicle. The owner shall pay the reasonable costs of the removal and storage which may result from such removal before regaining possession of the vehicle. 
(Ord. 788 § 3, 1961) 
10.36.040 - Effectiveness of provisions. 
    The effectiveness of this chapter is contingent on signs being erected as required by law. 
(Ord. 788 § 4, 1961) 
10.36.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by New Jersey Statute, every person convicted of a violation of a provision of this chapter or any supplement thereto shall be liable to a penalty of not more than fifty dollars or imprisonment for a term not exceeding fifteen days, or both. 
(Ord. 788 § 5, 1961)

Chapter 10.44 - PARKING OF CERTAIN CONVEYANCES AND HOUSING UNITS IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS 
Sections: 

10.44.010 - Prohibition against the parking or storage of certain conveyances and housing units. 
    No owner, lessee or occupant of any premises in any residential district in the borough shall park or store, or allow the parking or storing, on any such premises or on any street in the borough any of the following conveyances and/or housing units without the written approval of the mayor and council unless it is the only one of the following conveyances and/or housing units stored or garaged thereat and unless it is stored in a garage at all times: 
A.	Any commercially registered vehicle with a registered gross vehicle weight of five thousand pounds or more when not loaded; 
B.	Any unregistered vehicles; 
C.	Motorboats, sailboats or other watercraft twenty feet or more in length; 
D.	Trailers, house trailers, housing units, mobile homes and self-propelled housing units; 
E.	Collapsible housing units, whether assembled or disassembled; and 
F.	Animal conveyances, either trailer or self-propelled. 
(Ord. 1314 § 1 (part), 1999) 
10.44.020 - Application for approval-Duration of approval-Renewal. 
A.	Application for the parking, storing or garaging of any conveyance and/or housing unit other than as permitted hereunder shall be made in writing to the mayor and council of the borough and shall set forth the following: 
1.	Name of the owner, lessee or occupant and address of the premises in question; 
2.	Survey, sketch or plan of the premises; 
3.	Description and specification of the vehicle or unit, including size, weight, height and dimensions; 
4.	Any other information deemed necessary by the mayor and council to make a proper determination. 
B.	The mayor and council may grant, within their discretion, for the purpose of promoting the general welfare and public interest, permission and approval to have any conveyance and/or housing unit not otherwise permitted hereunder parked, stored or garaged at such premises for a period of not more than one year from the effective date of approval. 
C.	The applicant shall have the privilege of renewing its application. 
(Ord. 1314 § 1 (part), 1999) 
10.44.030 - Nonapplicability. 
    This chapter shall not be applicable to or curtail the use of commercial vehicles making deliveries to or performing services at premises in a residential district. 
(Ord. 1314 § 1 (part), 1999) 
10.44.040 - Investigation and enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty and obligation of the police department of the borough to investigate violations and to enforce this chapter. 
(Ord. 1314 § 1 (part), 1999) 
10.44.050 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter or neglecting or refusing to comply with any of the terms or conditions hereof shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit and be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars or to imprisonment in the county jail for not more than thirty days or to a period of community service not exceeding thirty days, any or all of the above, in the discretion of the judge imposing the same. Each and every violation of this chapter or each day that any provision of this chapter is violated shall be construed as a separate and distinct violation thereof. 
(Ord. 1314 § 1 (part), 1999) 
Chapter 10.48 - TRAFFIC CONTROLS FOR STREET AND HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS 
Sections: 

10.48.010 - Adoption of manual on uniform traffic control devices for streets and highways. 
    The council hereby finds and declares that problems of traffic control occur when traffic must be moved through or around street construction, maintenance operations, and utility work, above and below ground which requires blocking the roadway and obstructing the normal flow of traffic; and that such obstructions are or can become dangerous when not properly controlled. In order to better promote the public health, safety, peace and welfare, it is necessary to establish controls and regulations directed to the safe and expeditious movement of traffic through construction and maintenance zones and to provide safety for the work force performing these operations. 
    The Borough of Glen Ridge in the County of Essex, State of New Jersey, does hereby adopt the current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, hereafter known as M.U.T.C.D., except as hereby supplemented and amended, as it controls and regulates whenever construction maintenance operations of utility work obstructs the normal flow of traffic. Any person, contractor, or utility who fails to comply with the provisions of M.U.T.C.D. while performing such work is in violation of this section. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.020 - Pre-construction meetings. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the person, contractor, or in the case of a public utility as required under the public utility agreement, wishing to conduct work on, under or above the roadway to contact the Glen Ridge police department in order to arrange a pre-construction meeting to submit plans for the safe movement of traffic during such period of construction of work. Any person, contractor or utility who fails to comply with this section prior to the start of such work or whose plans are not approved by the (traffic bureau of the) police department is in violation of this section. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.030 - Hazardous conditions. 
    The person, contractor, or utility shall provide the Glen Ridge police department with at least two (2) emergency contact phone numbers to be called in case of emergency problems at the construction or maintenance site prior to the start of any work. If for any reason emergency contact cannot be reached, or if the emergency contact person does not respond to the call from the police department to correct a hazardous condition, the borough may respond to correct such hazardous conditions. The reasonable fees for such emergency service by the borough shall be charged to the person, contractor, or utility responsible for such conditions. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.040 - Hours. 
    There shall be no construction, maintenance operations, or utility work on any roadway in the borough before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after 4:00 p.m. This time limit may be adjusted to permit work prior to 9:00 a.m.. or after 4:00 p.m. by the officer in charge (of the traffic bureau) of the Glen Ridge police department. If it is determined by the officer in charge (of the police traffic bureau) that the construction or maintenance operations prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 4:00 p.m. would substantially delay traffic or cause a safety or health hazard, the work shall then be permitted only between 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.050 - Road closings and detours. 
    Road closings and/or traffic detours shall not be permitted unless approved by the Glen Ridge police department (traffic bureau). 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.060 - Traffic directors. 
    Traffic directors shall be posted at all construction or maintenance sites when determined by the Glen Ridge police department that same is necessary to provide for the safe and expeditious movement of traffic. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.070 - Stop work. 
    The (traffic bureau of the) Glen Ridge police department shall have the authority to stop work, including the removal of equipment and vehicles, stored material within the street right-of-way, back filling of open excavations and/or other related work, in order to abate any nuisance and/or safety hazard or for any violation of this section. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.080 - Site preparation. 
    It is to be expressly understood that no materials, vehicles or equipment are to be placed in the roadway or sidewalk area until all construction, signs, lights, devices, and pavement markings are installed. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
10.48.090 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 1.08.010, general penalty, of this code. 
(Ord. 1361 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 1584, 9-10-2012) 

Title 11 - VACANT AND ABANDONED PROPERTIES	
Chapters:

Chapter 11.04 - REGISTRATION OF VACANT PROPERTIES	
Sections:


11.04.010 - Definitions.	
As used in this section, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated:

"Abandoned property," as defined in accordance with the Abandoned Properties Rehabilitation Act, N.J.S.A. 55:19-78 et seq., shall mean the following:

1.Except as provided in Section 6 of P.L. 2003, c. 210 (N.J.S.A. 55:19-83), any property that is not legally occupied and which meets any one of the following additional criteria may be deemed to be abandoned property upon a determination by the public official that:a.The property is in need of rehabilitation in the reasonable judgment of the construction official, and no material rehabilitation has taken place during that six-month period;b.Construction was initiated on the property and was discontinued prior to completion, leaving the building unsuitable for occupancy, and no material construction has taken place for at least six consecutive months as of the date of a determination by the public official pursuant to this section;c.At least one installment of property tax remains unpaid and delinquent on that property in accordance with Chapter 4 of Title 54 of the Revised Statutes (see N.J.S.A. 54:4-1 et seq.) as of the date of a determination by the public official pursuant to this section; ord.The property has been determined to be a nuisance by the public official in accordance with Section 5 of P.L. 2003, c. 210 (N.J.S.A. 55:19-82).2.A property which contains both residential and non-residential space may be considered abandoned pursuant to P.L. 2003, c. 210 (N.J.S.A. 55:19-78 et seq.) so long as two-thirds or more of the total net square footage of the building was previously legally occupied as residential space and none of the residential space is legally occupied at the time of the determination of abandonment by the construction official and the property meets the criteria of either subsection (1)(a) or subsection (1)(d) of this Section 11.04.010.
"Evidence of vacancy" means:

1.Any condition that on its own or combined with other conditions present would lead a reasonable person to believe that the property is or has been vacant. Such evidence would include, but is not limited to, evidence of the existence of two or more of the following conditions at a property: overgrown or dead vegetation; accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers or mail; past-due utility notices or disconnected utilities; accumulation of trash, junk or debris; the absence of window coverings such as curtains, blinds or shutters; the absence of furnishings or personal items consistent with residential habitation; statements by neighbors, delivery agents, or government employees that the property is vacant or abandoned; infestation by insects, vermin, rats or other pests; windows or entrances that are boarded up or closed off; multiple window panes that are damaged, broken or unrepaired; doors that are smashed, broken, unhinged or continuously unlocked; or any uncorrected violation of a municipal building, housing or similar code during the preceding year.2.Property determined to be "abandoned property" in accordance with the meaning of such term in the Abandoned Properties Rehabilitation Act, N.J.S.A. 55:19-78 et seq., shall also be deemed to be vacant property for the purposes of this section.
"Owner" shall include the title holder, any agent of the title holder having authority to act with respect to a vacant property, any foreclosing entity subject to the provisions of C.46:10B-51 (P.L. 2008, c. 127, § 17), a debtor in possession or any other entity determined by the Borough of Glen Ridge to act with respect to the property.

"Vacant property" means any building used or to be used as a residence which is not legally occupied or at which substantially all lawful construction operations or residential occupancy has ceased for a period of at least three months, and any commercial property that has not been legally occupied or at which substantially all lawful construction operations have ceased for a period of at least three months, and which exhibits evidence of vacancy such that a reasonable person would believe that the property is vacant. Any property that contains all building systems in working order, is being maintained on a regular basis, has not been cited by the borough for any violation of municipal ordinance within such time and is being actively marketed by its owner for sale or rental shall not be deemed vacant.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 1, 2-27-2017)

11.04.020 - General requirements.	
A.The owner of any vacant property as defined herein shall, within thirty days after the building becomes vacant property or within thirty days after assuming ownership of the vacant property, whichever is later, file a registration statement for each such vacant property with the Borough of Glen Ridge on forms provided by the Borough of Glen Ridge for such purposes. The owner shall be required to renew the registration semi-annually as long as the building remains vacant property and shall pay a registration or renewal fee in the amount prescribed in Section 11.04.040 of this chapter for each vacant property registered. The initial and renewal fees shall be prorated and/or credited accordingly upon legal occupancy.B.Any owner of any building that meets the definition of "vacant property" prior to adoption date, shall file a registration statement for that property on or before adoption date plus sixty days. The registration statement shall include the information required under Section 11.04.030 of this chapter, as well as any additional information that the construction official may reasonably require.C.The owner shall notify the Borough of Glen Ridge within thirty days of any change in the registration information by filing an amended registration statement on a form provided by the Borough of Glen Ridge for such purpose.D.The registration statement shall be deemed prima facie proof of the statement therein contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the Borough of Glen Ridge against the owner or owners of the building.
(Ord. No. 1654, § 2, 2-27-2017)

11.04.030 - Registration statement requirements; property inspection.	
A.After filing a registration statement or a renewal of a registration statement, the owner of any vacant property shall provide access to the Borough of Glen Ridge Construction Official if requested, following reasonable notice, during the period covered by the initial registration or any subsequent renewal. If an inspection is required of the interior of the property due to complaints or other cause, the fee for such inspection shall be the same as that for a continued certificate of occupancy inspection as provided in the applicable provisions of the code of the Borough of Glen Ridge.B.The registration statement shall include the name, street address, and telephone number of a natural person twenty-one years of age or older, designated by the owner or owners as the authorized agent for receiving notices of code violations and for receiving process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding, on behalf of such owner or owners in connection with the enforcement of any applicable code. The designated agent must have a contact number that will be available twenty-four hours per day on an emergency basis. The statement shall also include the name of the person responsible for maintaining and securing the property, if different from the designated agent.C.An owner who is a natural person and who meets the requirements of this section as to availability of a contact number on a twenty-four-hour emergency basis may designate himself or herself as agent.D.By designating an authorized agent under the provisions of this section, the owner consents to receive any and all notices of code violations concerning the registered vacant property and all process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding brought to enforce code provisions concerning the registered building by service of the notice or process on the authorized agent. Any owner who has designated an authorized agent under the provisions of this section shall be deemed to consent to the continuation of the agent's designation for the purpose of this section until the owner notifies the Borough of Glen Ridge of a change of the authorized agent or until the owner files a new annual registration statement. The designation of an authorized agent in no way releases the owner from any requirement of this section.E.The registration shall remain valid for six months from the date of registration. The owner shall be required to renew the registration every six months as long as the building remains vacant property and shall pay a registration or renewal fee in the amount prescribed herein for each vacant property registered.
(Ord. No. 1654, § 3, 2-27-2017)

11.04.040 - Fee schedule.	
The initial registration fee for each building shall be five hundred dollars. The fee for the first renewal is one thousand five hundred dollars. The fee for any subsequent renewal is five thousand dollars. Initial fee shall be prorated according to the month of registration and renewal fees shall be credited when a property becomes legally occupied during a renewal period.

Vacant and Abandoned Property Registration Fee Schedule
Registration	Fee
Initial registration	$ 500.00
First renewal	1,500.00
Any subsequent renewal	5,000.00
 

(Ord. No. 1654, § 4, 2-27-2017)

11.04.050 - Requirements for owners of vacant and abandoned property.	
The owner of any building that has become vacant and abandoned property, and any person maintaining, operating or collecting rent for any such building that has become vacant, shall, immediately:

1.Post a sign affixed to the inside of the building indicating the name, address and telephone number of the owner, the owner's authorized agent for the purpose of service of process (if designated pursuant to Section 11.04.030 of this chapter), and the person responsible for the day-to-day supervision and management of the building, if such person is different from the owner holding title or authorized agent. The sign shall be of a size and placed in such a location so as to be legible from the nearest public street or sidewalk, whichever is nearer, but shall be no smaller than fifteen inches by seventeen inches; and2.Enclose and secure the building against unauthorized entry as provided in the applicable provisions of the code of the Borough of Glen Ridge and maintain the sign required in subsection (1) above until the building is again legally occupied or demolished or until repair or rehabilitation of the building is complete; and3.Make provision for the maintenance of the lawn and yard, including regular grass cutting as required by the applicable provisions of the code of the Borough of Glen Ridge; and4.Make provision for the cessation of the delivery of mail, newspapers and circulars to the property, including having the property listed on the exclusion list maintained by the Borough of Glen Ridge for the delivery of circulars and advertisements to the property; and5.Make provision for the winterizing of the property by the cessation of water service to the property and the draining of water lines; other than buildings with a fire sprinkler system, and6.Make provision for the cessation of electric or gas utility services to the property; other than buildings with a fire sprinkler system, and7.Make provision for the regular maintenance of the exterior of the property.
(Ord. No. 1654, § 5, 2-27-2017)

11.04.060 - Administration.	
The Borough of Glen Ridge Mayor and Council shall issue rules and regulations for the administration of the provisions of this section.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 6, 2-27-2017)

11.04.070 - Violations and penalties.	
A.Any owner who is not in full compliance with this section or who otherwise violates any provision of this section or of the rules and regulations issued hereunder shall be subject to a fine of not less than five hundred dollars and not more than one thousand dollars for each offense. Every day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Fines assessed under this section shall be recoverable from the owner and shall be a lien on the property.B.For purposes of this section, failure to file a registration statement in time, failure to provide correct information on the registration statement, failure to comply with the provisions of Section 11.04.050 of this chapter, or such other matters as may be established by the rules and regulations of the Borough of Glen Ridge shall be deemed to be a violation of this section.
(Ord. No. 1654, § 7, 2-27-2017)

11.04.080 - Compliance with other provisions.	
Nothing in this section is intended to nor shall be read to conflict or prevent the Borough of Glen Ridge from taking action against buildings found to be unfit for human habitation or unsafe structures as provided in applicable provisions of the Code of the Borough of Glen Ridge and/or the Uniform Construction Code. Further, any action taken under any such code provision other than the demolition of a structure shall not relieve an owner from its obligations under this section.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 8, 2-27-2017)

Chapter 11.08 - RESPONSIBILITIES OF CREDITORS	
Sections:


11.08.010 - Responsibilities of creditors, violations and fines.	
A.Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40:48-2.12s, the creditor filing the summons and complaint in an action to foreclose shall be responsible for the care, maintenance, security, and upkeep of the exterior of the vacant and abandoned residential property. This obligation applies whether the determination that the property is vacant and abandoned is made by the public officer pursuant to Chapter 111 "Property Maintenance," Chapter 67 "Buildings or Structures, Repair or Demolition of," N.J.S.A. 2A:50-73, or otherwise.B.If the creditor is located out-of-state, the creditor shall be responsible for appointing an in-state representative or agent to act for the foreclosing creditor.C.An out-of-state creditor shall include the full name and contact information of the in-state representative or agent in the notice required to be provided to the municipal clerk pursuant to N.J.S.A. 46:10B-51(a)(1).D.An out-of-state creditor found by the municipal court, or by any other court of competent jurisdiction, to be in violation of any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine of two thousand five hundred dollars for each day of the violation, commencing on the day after the ten-day period set forth in N.J.S.A. 46:10B-51(a)(1) for providing notice to the municipal clerk that a summons and complaint in an action to foreclose has been served.E.A public officer appointed pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:48-2.3 et seq., or any enforcement officer described in this chapter, shall be authorized to issue a notice to the creditor filing the summons and complaint in an action to foreclose, if the public officer or enforcement officer determines that the creditor has violated this chapter by failing to provide for the care, maintenance, security, and upkeep of the exterior of the property. The notice shall require the person or entity to correct the violation within thirty days of receipt of the notice, or within ten days of receipt of the notice if the violation presents an imminent threat to public health and safety. The issuance of this notice shall constitute proof that a property is "vacant and abandoned" for purposes of N.J.S.A. 2A:50-73.F.A creditor found by the municipal court, or by any other court of competent jurisdiction, to be in violation of the requirement to correct a care, maintenance, security, or upkeep violation cited in a notice issued pursuant to subsection (A) shall be subject to a fine of one thousand five hundred dollars for each day of the violation commencing thirty-one days following receipt of the notice, except if the violation presents an imminent risk to public health and safety, in which case any fines shall commence eleven days following receipt of the notice.
(Ord. No. 1654, § 9, 2-27-2017)

Chapter 11.12 - MUNICIPAL POWERS TO REHABILITATE ABANDONED PROPERTIES	
Sections:


11.12.010 - Municipal powers to rehabilitate abandoned property.	
The Borough of Glen Ridge hereby grants to itself all such powers granted to municipalities by the state of New Jersey for the rehabilitation of abandoned property. Such powers are set forth, inter alia, in the "Abandoned Properties Rehabilitation Act" (N.J.S.A. 55:19-78 et seq.) and in applicable portions of the "New Jersey Urban Development Corporation Act" (N.J.S.A. 55-19-1 through 55-19-77). These state statutory powers are collectively referred to herein as the "enabling statutes."

(Ord. No. 1654, § 10, 2-27-2017)

11.12.020 - Public officer.	
The Public Officer, as defined in N.J.S.A. 55:19-80, who is responsible for executing the provisions of this chapter for the rehabilitation of abandoned property, shall be designated by resolution of the borough council.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 11, 2-27-2017)

11.12.030 - Abandoned property.	
The public officer shall designate a property as an "abandoned property" if said property meets the criteria set forth in N.J.S.A. 55:19-81 (abandoned property criteria) and/or N.J.S.A. 55:19-82 (nuisance property criteria). The public officer's designation is limited by the provisions of N.J.S.A. 55:19-83.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 12, 2-27-2017)

11.12.040 - Abandoned property list.	
The public officer shall establish an abandoned property list pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-55. An interested party (as that term is defined in N.J.S.A. 55:19-105a) may request that the public officer include a property on the abandoned property list, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-105.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 13, 2-27-2017)

11.12.050 - Municipal powers.	
Borough of Glen Ridge has such powers and rights regarding abandoned properties as set forth in the enabling statutes. Such powers include but are not limited to:

1.Sale of tax lien, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-56;2.Special tax sales, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-101;3.Foreclosing the right to redemption, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-58;4.Recourse directly against property owner, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-100;5.Possession and control of property, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-84 to 55:19-92 et seq.;6.Rehabilitation and reuse of property, while in possession and control, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-90;7.Borrowing money and making applications for rehabilitation of property, while in possession and control, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-91;8.Sale of property, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-96;9.Purchase of property, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-96;10.Recover rehabilitation costs by lien on property, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-98;11.Clearance, development, redevelopment or repair of property through power of eminent domain, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 55:19-56, 55:19-102.
(Ord. No. 1654, § 14, 2-27-2017)

11.12.060 - Effect on other laws.	
Nothing in this article is intended to or shall be read to conflict or prevent the borough from taking action against buildings found to be unfit for human habitation or unsafe structures, as provided in applicable provisions of the code of the Borough of Glen Ridge, or imposing a lien for costs on any property to the full extent permitted by law.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 15, 2-27-2017)

11.12.070 - Interpretation.	
All references in this chapter to state statutes include reference to all amendments thereto. References to particular sections of the enabling statutes are for ease of reference, but may not be exhaustive and are not meant to be exclusive of other applicable statutory provisions contained in the enabling statutes or elsewhere in the New Jersey statutes.

(Ord. No. 1654, § 16, 2-27-2017)

Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - STREET DEDICATION REQUIREMENTS 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Dedication-Compliance with provisions. 
A.	The dedication of any street hereafter laid out shall not be accepted by the borough, unless the conditions and provisions of this chapter shall have been complied with, and all improvements made in accordance with the standard specifications on file in the office of the borough engineer. These improvements shall comprise a permanent pavement of approved type, curbs and sidewalks; a sanitary sewer with house connections to the curbs; a water main, gates, gate boxes, and fire hydrants. The house connections for water will be laid by the borough at the expense of the property owner. 
B.	The streets of the borough shall be lighted with gas. 
C.	The sewer, water and gas mains, with all connections, shall be installed under the supervision of the borough engineer, before the pavement is laid. 
(Ord. 396 § 1, 1925; Ord. 16 § 1, 1896) 
12.04.020 - Dedication-Notice and proposal. 
A.	Before any street is physically opened, a notice of intention to open and a proposal to dedicate the same to public use shall be filed with the borough clerk. Such notice and proposal shall be signed by all owners whose land is included within the boundaries of the proposed street, and shall be accompanied by a map showing all details thereof, and such notice and proposal shall contain or have annexed thereto: 
1.	A statement showing the exact location of the proposed street or streets, together with an accurate description of the land to be dedicated; 
2.	Map or maps showing the lines and grades of the proposed street or streets to be laid out; 
3.	A written approval by the borough engineer as to details of said laying out; 
4.	A written approval by the borough attorney as to the legal form and effect of said proposal; 
5.	A deposit for inspection contingent upon the length of said street or streets; 
6.	A statement showing that arrangements have been made with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to have gas mains and connections to the curbs of the street and all necessary underground electric conduits and manholes placed, and a statement showing that arrangements have been made with the telephone company to have all necessary underground work completed prior to the paving of said proposed street. 
B.	Said notice and proposal, and the details of laying out said street or streets, must be in form and substance satisfactory to the council of the borough, which said council may, in its discretion, either approve or reject said proposal. The approval of said proposal, however, shall be held in no way to bind the borough to accept any dedication of said street or streets. 
C.	The procedure and requisites relating to the deed of dedication, the maps accompanying the same, the improvements to be provided on said street or streets, and the deposit for the recording of the deed and maps shall be in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 469 §§ 1, 2, 1928: Ord. 396 §§ 2, 2A, 2B, 1925) 
12.04.030 - Street width requirements. 
A.	Every street hereafter laid out shall be at least fifty-four feet wide. Of this width, at least twelve feet on each side shall be reserved for sidewalk plots, and the remainder shall be roadway. Of the sidewalk plot, at least five feet on each side of the roadway, next to the curb line, shall be reserved for the planting of trees and grass. If the street be sixty feet or more in width, the sidewalk plots on each side shall be fifteen feet wide, and the parts reserved for ornamental planting shall be eight feet wide; provided, however, under the following circumstances that the council may by resolution permit a street to be laid out: 
1.	With a width not less than forty-two feet, in a residential zone, which said street shall form a block no greater in length than six hundred feet and which said block shall contain not more than one interior one-family building plot on each side of said street exclusive of the corner lots, and which said street shall run only from one cross street to the next cross street and shall not form a continuation of any other street; or 
2.	With a width not less than forty-two feet in a residential zone which said street shall not extend more than two hundred fifty feet from an existing intersecting street line and shall not have more than four interior one-family building plots exclusive of the corner lots; and may permit in the resolution said street to be dead-end if a turnabout with a minimum radius of fifty feet measured to the property (street) line be provided at the closed end of the dead-end street rather than a sixty-foot turnabout minimum radius provided in Section 12.04.050 of this chapter. 
B.	The foregoing provisions shall also specify the width of sidewalk plots and parts reserved for planting. 
(Ord. 706 § 1, 1954: Ord. 553 § 1, 1931: Ord. 396 § 3, 1925) 
12.04.040 - Grade. 
    The grade shall be fixed and established on the street prior to its acceptance by the borough, and such grade shall be approved by the council. The deed shall contain provisions, satisfactory to the council, releasing the borough from liability for any damage to abutting or adjacent property by reason of the establishment of such grade. 
(Ord. 396 § 4, 1925) 
12.04.050 - Laying out of streets-Maps. 
A.	New streets shall connect with existing streets, except that with the approval of the mayor and council dead-end streets may be laid out, provided a turnabout with a minimum radius of sixty feet measured to the property (street) line be provided at the closed end of a dead-end street. 
B.	When the tract to be developed adjoins land which has not been subdivided, the new streets shall be carried to the boundaries of the tract under development. 
C.	Property lines at street corners shall be rounded on a radius of not less than ten feet and the curve of the curb at the corner shall be concentric with that of the property. For streets of unequal width the curve of the curb at the corner shall be rounded on a radius equal to that used for the property plus the width of the sidewalk of the narrower street. 
D.	All side lines of lots shall be either at right angles or radial to the street lines. 
E.	All final maps showing the subdivisions of property shall be drawn to a scale of fifty feet to the inch and shall contain complete data regarding the following facts: 
1.	Lot numbers, dimensions and true meridian bearings; 
2.	Length of tangents, radii, arcs, chords and central angles of all line curves on streets; 
3.	Tangent, chord, arcs, radius and central angles at all corners; 
4.	Chord lengths, arcs and central angles for curved frontage. 
(Ord. 664 § 1, 1950: Ord. 396 § 5, 1925) 
12.04.060 - Deviations. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of this chapter might result in an unnecessary hardship or in an undesirable layout, the borough council may by resolution approve certain deviations from the terms of this chapter and accept for dedication a street in accordance with said approval. 
(Ord. 769 § 1, 1960: Ord. 396 § 5A, 1925) 
12.04.070 - Reserved strips. 
    No divisions showing reserved strips controlling access to public ways, or showing strips of land which will be untaxable for improvements will be approved, except where the control and disposal of the land comprising such strips are definitely placed within the borough jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 396 § 6, 1925) 
12.04.080 - Execution of deed-Monument. 
A.	After the street is opened, a deed shall be executed, and acknowledged or approved for record, by all owners of the land included within the boundaries of the street, and delivered to the borough clerk. It shall contain, whenever possible, the usual covenants of warranty, and shall convey the said land to the borough free and clear of all encumbrances. The deed shall have annexed thereto, or be accompanied by: 
1.	A map accurately delineating the street; 
2.	Evidence, satisfactory to the council, that the condition of the street and of the abutting property is such that dedication of the street may be accepted without risk of injury to the interests of the borough or neighboring property owners, and that suitable monuments are properly set so as to definitely locate each corner of the street. 
B.	Monuments shall be made of granite, and shall be not less than four feet long, five inches square at the top, eight inches square at the bottom, and set in concrete. If located in a roadway or in a sidewalk, the top of the monument shall be protected by a cast iron box, fitted with a hinged lid, and set flush with the finished grade. Where no box is required, the top of the monument shall be one and one-half inches above the level of the ground. 
C.	A certificate from the collector that there are no unpaid taxes or assessments against the property included within said street, and a deposit of five dollars to cover the cost of recording the deed. The balance above the cost of recording shall be returned to the depositor. 
(Ord. 396 § 7, 1925) 
12.04.090 - Owner guarantees. 
    A written guarantee or a contract, in form satisfactory to the council, signed by the owners of the property, shall be filed with the borough clerk, wherein the owners shall agree with the borough that they will fill in, to the satisfaction of the borough engineer, any depressions or settling of the ground over the sewer or water mains, which may occur within one year from the date of the guarantee or contract, and that they will complete such filling in within ten days after notice so to do, and repair the pavement to the satisfaction of the borough engineer. 
(Ord. 396 § 8, 1925) 
12.04.100 - Ordinance required for dedication. 
    No street shall be deemed or construed as having been dedicated to and accepted by the borough, nor shall any such street be lighted, improved, or maintained at the public expense unless and until an ordinance shall have been passed, by the borough council, accepting dedication thereof. 
(Ord. 396 § 9, 1925) 
Chapter 12.08 - EXCAVATIONS 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Guard required. 
    Any person or corporation making or causing to be made any excavation or any obstruction of any kind whatsoever in, on, or about any sidewalk, street or public place within the borough shall keep such excavation or obstruction properly guarded at all times by barricades in such a manner that the safety of the public will be amply protected. 
(Ord. 380 § 1, 1924) 
12.08.020 - Illumination required. 
    Any person or corporation making or causing to be made any excavation or any obstruction of any kind whatsoever in, on, or about any sidewalk, street or public place within the borough shall keep such excavation or obstruction illuminated or marked between the hours of sunset and sunrise in such a manner that the safety of the public will be amply protected. 
(Ord. 380 § 2, 1924) 
12.08.030 - Interference with barricades or illumination. 
    No person shall remove, or in any way interfere with, any barricade guarding any excavation or obstruction as above provided, nor shall any person remove, extinguish, or in any way interfere with any lantern or light illuminating or marking any excavation or obstruction as above provided. 
(Ord. 380 § 3, 1924) 
12.08.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 1.08.010, general penalty, of this code. 
(Ord. 380 § 4, 1924) 
(Ord. No. 1584, 9-10-2012) 
Chapter 12.12 - SIDEWALK REPAIRS 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Payment for repairs-Control of repairs. 
    In any case where the governing body of the borough shall, by resolution, determine to relay or repair any sidewalk on any street, road, avenue, or other public place with the borough now laid or which hereafter may be laid, the work of such relaying and repairing shall be done by or at the expense of the owner or owners of the land in front of which said improvement shall be made, and under the supervision, control and direction of the borough engineer, and the committee on public works of said borough. 
(Ord. 439 § 1, 1927) 
12.12.020 - Notice to abutting owners to repair. 
    Whenever the pavement or surface of any public sidewalk or portion thereof upon or along a public street or highway in the borough shall be found to be broken, disintegrated, uneven or otherwise defective to such an extent that it would be likely to cause a pedestrian to trip or fall in passing along the same, and such condition shall be complained of to, or discovered by the supervisor of public works of the borough, he/she shall make, or cause to be made, an inspection of the sidewalk or portion thereof, and shall report the condition thereof by him/her so found, to the borough administrator with his/her recommendations for the correction or elimination of such condition. If such condition shall be found to constitute a hazard to pedestrians' use of the sidewalk or portion thereof, and may be eliminated by repair or reconstruction, the borough administrator or his/her designee may cause written notice to be given to the owner of all real estate abutting upon the sidewalk or portion thereof so found to be dangerous or hazardous and to require reconstruction or repair, requiring such owner to reconstruct or repair the sidewalk or portion thereof, within thirty days after the service of such notice, in the manner, to the extent and in accordance with the specifications to be set forth in the notice. Such notice shall also contain a description of the property abutting upon such sidewalk or portion thereof so required to be reconstructed or repaired, which description shall be sufficient to identify such property. 
(Ord. No. 1592, 5-20-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1592, adopted May 20, 2013, repealed former §§ 12.12.020 and 12.12.030, and enacted new provisions in lieu thereof as § 12.12.020. Former §§ 12.12.020 and 12.12.030 pertained to required resolution and repairs-time limits, and derived from Ord. No. 439, §§ 2, 3, adopted in 1927. 
12.12.040 - Failure to do work. 
    In case the owner or owners shall not, within thirty days from the date of the service of such notice, perform the work as required therein, the mayor and council, through its committee having charge of the streets and roads of the borough, shall proceed to relay or repair such sidewalk or sidewalks at the cost of the owner or owners of such abutting land. 
(Ord. 439 § 4, 1927) 
Chapter 12.16 - REMOVAL OF GRASS, WEEDS AND OTHER IMPEDIMENTS FROM SIDEWALKS 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Owner requirements. 
    The owner or tenant of each lot, piece or parcel of land abutting or bordering upon the sidewalks or gutters of the public streets, avenues or highways shall remove all grass, weeds or other impediments therefrom within three days after notice to remove the same. 
(Ord. 272 § 1, 1918) 
12.16.020 - Defining impediments. 
    Permitting any grass or weeds to grow immediately adjoining any sidewalk or gutter within any public street, avenue or highway, to a height exceeding six inches, shall for the purpose of Section 12.16.020, be deemed an impediment. 
(Ord. 272 § 2, 1918) 
12.16.030 - Removal of impediments. 
    The superintendent of public works or its successor entity shall cause to be removed any such impediment whenever the owner or tenant of any lot, piece or parcel of land, after notice as aforesaid, shall have failed to cause such removal. 
(Ord. 1222 (part), 1993: Ord. 272 § 4, 1918) 
12.16.040 - Costs become lien on property. 
    In the event of the removal of any such impediment by the superintendent of public works or its successor entity as aforesaid, the costs thereof, as nearly as the same can be ascertained, shall be charged upon the books of the borough against the lands abutting upon or bordering such sidewalk or gutter, and the amount of such cost, together with interest thereon, shall forthwith become a lien upon such lands, and shall be added to and form a part of the taxes next to be assessed and levied upon such lands and shall be certified to the collector of taxes for said borough and shall be collected in the same manner as other taxes. 
(Ord. 1222 (part), 1993: Ord. 272 § 5, 1918) 
12.16.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 1.08.010, general penalty, of this code. 
(Ord. 1382 (part), 2003: Ord. 620 § 1, 1943: Ord. 272 § 3, 1918) 
(Ord. No. 1584, 9-10-2012) 
Chapter 12.20 - SIDEWALK SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Snow and ice removal. 
A.	The owners of and occupants of land, or any agent thereof, fronting upon any street or public place within the limits of the borough shall, within twenty-four hours next ensuing after a fall of snow or after the freezing of water into ice upon any sidewalk, of whatsoever kind, in front of said land aforesaid, remove such snow or ice from such sidewalks in front of said lands owned or occupied by them, and any snow or ice thrown into said streets shall be leveled, so as not to obstruct the use of said streets. Where snow or ice shall have become frozen to the sidewalk so that it cannot be removed therefrom, said owner or occupants or agents above referred to shall cause said snow or ice to be covered with sand or ashes. 
B.	Provided that this section shall not apply to any sidewalk which shall not at the time have been laid, either to the whole width or a part thereof, with flagging, cement, concrete, plank or boards. 
(Ord. 751 § 1, 1959; Ord. 148, 1907: Ord. 144 § 1, 1906) 
12.20.020 - Failure to remove ice and snow-Lien on property. 
    In case of the refusal or neglect of said owner or occupant of land or agent thereof to comply with this chapter, the council may cause such snow or ice to be removed from said sidewalks, and that the cost of removing said snow or ice, as ascertained by the council, with interest thereon, shall be added to and form a part of the taxes next to be levied and assessed upon such land, and shall be a lien upon such lands until the same shall be paid. 
(Ord. 144 § 2, 1906) 
12.20.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any owner, occupant of lands or agent thereof in the borough who shall neglect or refuse to comply with the terms of Section 12.20.010 shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine: 
A.	For the first and second offense, a penalty of twenty-five dollars will be imposed; 
B.	For the third and each subsequent offense, the penalty may not be less than fifty dollars or more than one hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1382 (part), 2003: Ord. 1247 § 1, 1994: Ord. 841 § 1, 1962: Ord. 144 § 3, 1906) 
Chapter 12.24 - DRIVEWAYS 
Sections: 

12.24.010 - Driveway construction.
