When within ten (10) feet of any building not an essential part of the installation, and the top of the tank is above the lowest floor of the building, the capacity of the tank shall be not more than five hundred and fifty (550) gallons. 
 The capacity of storage of combustible liquids other than volatile flammables as herein defined, shall be restricted to five (5) times the values specified in Table 7-A. 
  Section 403.23 Inside Underground System. Inside underground tanks shall be located not less than 12 inches below the cellar floor, which in the area over the tank shall be six (6) inch reinforced concrete, extending at least two (2) feet beyond the outline of the tank in all directions. 
  Section 407.1 Classification of Systems. Systems for the storage and use of liquefied petroleum gases shall be classified as cylinder or bottled gas systems. 
  Section 411.11 Buildings. All such buildings and structures, unless herein otherwise specifically provided, shall be of fireproof (Type 1) construction, within the height and area limits of high hazard uses (Use Group A) of Table 6. 
  Section 413.6 Electric Wiring and Equipment. All electrical equipment and wiring shall conform to the requirements of Article 15 for hazardous locations and the cylinders and shells of all washing machines, drying tumblers, drying cabinets, extractors, and all above-ground storage containers shall be grounded as required. 
  Section 414.11 One- and Two-Family Dwellings. Private garages located beneath a one- or two-family dwelling shall have walls, partitions, floors and ceilings, separating the garage space from the dwelling, constructed of not less than three-quarter (3/4) hour fire resistance, except that exterior walls shall have their interior faces finished with materials having not less than the fire resistance of the interior materials of said separating walls, partitions and ceilings. All openings in exterior walls shall have doors and windows constructed of noncombustible materials. Such garages having a floor area in excess of seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet shall be divided into areas not exceeding seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet by interior partitions having not less than three-quarter (3/4) hour fire resistance ratings. Any door opening between the garage space and the dwelling shall be protected by a three-quarter (3/4) hour fire door complying with Article 9 with the sills of all door openings between said garage space and the dwelling raised not less than four (4) inches above the garage floor. 
  Section 414.12 Motels and Multi-Family Dwellings. Private garages located beneath motels and multi-family dwellings and in which no gasoline or oil is stored or handled shall be of protected construction of not less than one and one half (11/2) hour fire resistance except that exterior walls are not required to have a fire resistance rating at window and door openings but such openings shall be protected by windows and doors constructed of noncombustible materials. 
  Section 414.13 Separation by Breezeway. Private garages attached to and within ten (10) feet of any dwelling or within six (6) feet of any lot line shall have their entire construction conform with 414.11. Private garages located more than six (6) feet from a lot line or more than ten (10) feet from a dwelling and attached to a dwelling but not by a common wall, shall have the attaching wall constructed of fire-resistive materials as required in 414.11. Any garage having a floor area in excess of seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet shall be divided into areas not exceeding seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet by interior partitions having not less than three-quarter (3/4) hour fire resistance ratings. 
  Section 414.3 Detached Garages. Private garages within ten (10) feet of any dwelling or within six (6) feet of any lot line shall be constructed in accordance with 414.11. Private garages located more than ten (10) feet from any dwelling or more than six (6) feet from any lot line may be constructed of unprotected frame Type 4B construction. Any garage having a floor area in excess of seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet shall be divided into areas not exceeding seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet by interior partitions having not less than three-quarter (3/4) hour fire resistance ratings. 
  Section 416.1 Construction. Buildings and structures used for the storage and sale of motor fuel oils shall be of Types 1A and 1B construction within the height and area limitations of Table 6 for business (Use Group E) buildings and as modified by Section 303. 
  Section 421.31 Frame Construction. No frame grandstand unit or similar structure shall be more than ten thousand (10,000) square feet in area, nor more than twenty (20) feet in height to the highest level of seat platforms nor more than two hundred (200) feet in length. Not more than three such units shall be constructed in any one group provided with the fire separations herein required. When more than one (1) such group is erected, they shall be separated by a wall of two (2) hours fire resistance when the fire separation is less than fifty (50) feet. 
  Section 421.32 Noncombustible Construction. All grandstand structures, two (2) or more tiers in height, shall be of noncombustible (Type 2-C) construction or better. 
  Section 423.1 Location and Permits. Outside the fire limits temporary tents may be erected for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days for religious, educational or recreational purposes. A special permit shall be secured from the Building Official for all such installations. 
  Section 423.12 Private Tents. When in the judgment of the Building Official, small tents are erected by residents on their own property for their own use, the requirements for a permit and compliance with this Section may be waived. 
  Section 424.2 Lanes and Parking Spaces. No outdoor parking area shall be considered adequate unless there shall be a minimum allowance for stalls and aisles, exclusive of driveways serving said aisles, of not less than two hundred and eighty (280) square feet per motor vehicle for conditions where stalls are provided on both sides of aisles, and three hundred ninety (390) square feet for conditions where stalls are provided on only one side of an aisle and the minimum width of a stall shall be not less than nine (9) feet. Every parking space shall be so located that a standard size passenger motor vehicle can be driven into it without moving other parked passenger motor vehicles. 
  Section 424.4 Protection of Adjoining Property. A substantial anchored bumper of masonry, steel or heavy timber shall be placed near all interior lot lines to protect structures and property abutting the parking lot. 
  Section 424.5 Surface and Drainage. Any parking area, any loading zone and any approach or driveway to the same shall be paved in such manner that it shall have a hard, dust-free impervious surface and shall be properly drained so that any surface water shall not flow onto any other properties or across the public sidewalk. 
  Section 424.6 Electric Illumination. Electric light wiring shall be provided on approved standards to furnish adequate illumination of driveways and lanes as required by the municipal authorities for street lighting, but in no case shall such illumination be less than one-half (1/2) of one (1) foot candle measured at the surface of the pavement in any location. 
  Section 427.2 Construction. All radio towers shall be constructed of steel or other approved corrosion-resistive noncombustible materials. Steel members shall be not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch thick of galvanized nor less than three-sixteenths ( 3/16 ) inch thick if painted to comply with Section 827. 
  Section 427.4 Electrical Requirements. Radio towers shall be grounded to comply with the requirements of Article 15. 
  Section 428.3 Electrical Grounding. All wiring shall comply with the requirements of Article 15. 
  Section 429.1 General. Pools used for swimming or bathing shall be in conformity with the requirements of this Section, provided, however, these regulations shall only be applicable to any such pool having a depth in excess of twenty-four (24) inches or a surface area in excess of one hundred and twenty (120) square feet, or a capacity in excess of fourteen hundred (1400) gallons, except these regulations shall be applicable to any pools which are permanently equipped with a water recirculating system. For the purposes of this Code, pools are classified as private swimming pools or public and semi-public swimming pools, as defined in Section 429.2. 
  Section 429.4 Locations. All swimming pools shall be located in accordance with the Ordinances of the Borough of Glen Ridge. 
  Section 429.81 Overhead Electrical Conductors. No overhead electrical conductors shall be permitted within fifteen (15) feet of any swimming pool. All metal fences, enclosures or railings near or adjacent to swimming pools to which bathers have access, which may become electrically alive as a result of contact with broken overhead conductors, or from any other cause, shall be effectively grounded. 
  Section 502.0 Plans and Specifications. Plans for all buildings and structures other than one- and two-family dwellings, which are designed for human occupancy shall designate the number of occupants to be accommodated in the various rooms and spaces and when means of artificial lighting and ventilation are required, the application shall include sufficient details and description of the mechanical system to be installed as herein required or as specified in Article 18. 
  Section 505.1 When Required. When natural light and ventilation do not meet the minimum requirements of the Basic Code, or when rooms, which by use or occupancy involve the presence of dust, fumes, gases, vapor or other noxious or deleterious impurities that create a fire or health hazard, or when required by the provisions of Article 4 for special uses, the building shall be equipped with artificial light and mechanical means of ventilation under the conditions and of the minimum capacity herein prescribed. The amount of fresh air required for various uses and occupancies shall be based on the lesser of the minimum requirements of Table 9-A and Section 515. 
  Section 508.3 Crawl Spaces. In buildings and structures constructed without basements, in which the first floor construction does not bear directly on the ground, a clear space shall be provided under the first floor structure not less than two (2) feet in depth; and such space shall be vented with screened openings having a clear area of not less than one-third ( 1/3 ) of one (1) percent of the enclosed building area, or shall be provided with other means of ventilation approved by the Building Official. An access opening not less than two (2) feet square shall be provided. When floating mat foundations are provided in accordance with Section 729.2 the requirements for ventilation shall not apply. 
  Section 513.5 Mechanical Ventilating Systems. By any system of mechanical or gravity ventilation exhausting forty (40) cubic feet of air per minute per water closet or urinal in public bathrooms and not less than twenty-five (25) cubic feet of air per minute in private bathrooms, but in no case shall the fresh air supply be less than specified in Section 515 and Table 9-A. 
  Section 522.0 Fire Ventilation and Protection of Open Wells. Unenclosed well openings for stairways not accepted as required means of egress shall be permitted in buildings equipped with an approved sprinkler system and protected on every floor pierced by the opening with one of the following methods of protection: 
  Section 522.1 Sprinkler-Vent Method. The sprinkler-vent method is an approved combination of an automatic fire or smoke-detection system, automatic exhaust system and an automatic water curtain meeting the following requirements: 
  Section 522.11 Exhaust System. An exhaust system shall be so located and of such capacity as to create a downdraft through the stairway floor opening having an average velocity of not less than three hundred (300) feet per minute under normal conditions for a period of not less than thirty (30) minutes. The operation of the exhaust system for any floor opening shall be initiated by an approved device in the story involved. There shall also be provided a manual means of operating and testing the system at periodic intervals. 
  Section 522.12 Water Curtain. A water curtain shall be formed by open sprinklers or spray nozzles so located and spaced as to form a complete and continuous barrier along the exposed sides of the floor opening and reaching from the ceiling to the floor. Water intensity for the water curtain shall be not less than three (3) gallons per minute per lineal foot of water curtain measured horizontally around the opening. The water curtain shall operate automatically from a fixed temperature type device so placed with respect to the floor opening that the water curtain operates upon the advance of heat towards the stairway opening. 
  Section 522.2 Rolling Shutter Method. The rolling shutter method is an approved automatic self-closing rolling shutter which will completely enclose the top of each stairway and meeting the following requirements: 
  Section 522.21 Shutter Location. The shutter shall not be used to protect floor openings for stairways communicating directly with basements. Where used to protect floor openings the operation of the shutter shall be initiated by an automatic fire or smoke-detection system located near the stairway. There shall be a manual means of operating and testing the operation of the shutter. 
  Section 522.22 Shutter Construction. The shutter assembly shall be capable of supporting two hundred (200) pounds applied on any one square foot of area and shall be not less resistant to fire than 24 gauge steel. The shutter shall operate at a speed of not greater than thirty (30) feet per minute and shall be equipped with a sensitive leading edge. The leading edge shall arrest the progress of the moving shutter and cause it to retract a distance of approximately six (6) inches upon the application of a force not in excess of twenty (20) pounds applied on the surface of the leading edge. The shutter, following retraction, shall continue to closure immediately. 
  Section 522.3 Spray Nozzle Method. The spray nozzle method is an approved combination of an automatic fire or smoke detection system and a system of high velocity water spray nozzles meeting the following requirements: 
  Section 522.31 Spray Nozzles. The number of spray nozzles, their discharge angles and their location, shall be such that the stairway opening between the top of the wellway housing and the treadway will be completely filled with dense spray on operation of the system. Spray nozzles shall be of the open type and shall have a solid conical spray pattern with discharge angles between 45° and 90°. The number and size of nozzles and water supply shall be sufficient to deliver a discharge of two (2) gallons of water per square foot per minute through the wellway, area to be figured perpendicular to the slope of the stairway. Spray nozzles shall be so located and positioned that the center line of spray discharge is as closely as possible in line with the slope of the stairway; at not more than an angle of 30 degrees with the top slope of the wellway housing. Nozzles shall be positioned, also, so that the center line of discharge is at an angle of not more than 30 degrees from the vertical sides of the wellway housing. The spray nozzles shall discharge at a pressure of not less than twenty-five (25) pounds per square inch. Water supply piping may be taken from the sprinkler system, provided in so doing an adequate supply of water will be available for the spray nozzles and the water pressure at the sprinkler furthest from the supply riser is not reduced to a point below that required for the sprinklers. Control valves for the water supply to spray nozzles shall be so located as to be readily accessible. The spray nozzle system shall operate automatically from thermal response elements of the fixed temperature type so placed with respect to the floor opening that the spray nozzle system operates upon the advance of heat towards the stairway opening. The system shall also be provided with a manual means of operation. 
  Section 522.32 Draft Curtain. A noncombustible draft curtain shall be provided extending at least twenty (20) inches below and around the opening and a solid noncombustible wellway housing at least five (5) feet long measured parallel to the handrail, and extending from the top of the handrail enclosure to the soffit of the stairway or ceiling above, at each stairway floor opening. Where necessary, spray nozzles shall be protected against mechanical injury. 
  Section 522.4 Kiosk Method. The Kiosk method consists of a noncombustible enclosure at upper-floor landings equipped with an approved double-acting self-closing door or doors of metal and wired glass. 
  Section 522.41 Enclosure. Wired glass in metal framework may be used for the enclosure provided no light of glass has a length or width greater than forty-eight (48) inches. The enclosure shall include a landing at each floor which is of sufficient length beyond the moving stairway to permit the full opening of the door or doors beyond the handrail and having a width not less than that of the floor opening. 
  Section 605.2 Exhaust Ducts. No exhaust ducts or vents of air conditioning systems shall discharge into stair or elevator enclosures nor shall corridors or other exitways in hotels and institutional buildings be used as the return exhaust from air-conditioned spaces through louvers or other devices in the doors or partitions enclosing such air-conditioned spaces. 
  Section 611.1 Minimum Number. Except in one- and two-family dwellings there shall be not less than two (2) approved independent exitways serving every floor area, two (2) of which shall be interior enclosed exitways except as permitted in 621 and 624. In one-family dwellings there shall be at least one (1) approved exitway serving every floor area above and below the first or grade floor and not less than two (2) approved exitways serving the first or grade floor. In two-family dwellings there shall be not less than two (2) approved exitways serving every floor above the first or grade floor. Exitways from first or grade and below grade floor areas of two-family dwellings shall be as required in one-family dwellings. Exits in dwellings shall be so arranged that they may be reached without passing through another living unit. 
  Section 612.3 Width. The unit exit width and occupancy allowance of aisles and corridors, unless otherwise provided for special uses and occupancies in Article 4, shall be the same as for stairways (Table 12) with a minimum total width of forty-four (44) inches, except in one-family dwellings, sixty (60) inches in school buildings, and seventy-two (72) inches in church schools; except that in churches and chapels, side aisles may be one-half (1/2) these widths, but in no case less than twenty-four (24) inches. 
  Section 613.42 Show Windows. Show windows opening on such lobbies shall be protected with automatic sprinklers and shall be backed with fire partitions of two (2) hour fire resistance rating. 
  Section 613.44 Sprinklered Buildings. When the grade floor lobbies, passageways, public hallways and other public spaces connected thereto are equipped with an approved automatic sprinkler system complying with Article 12, the requirement of Section 613.43 shall be waived. 
  Section 614.0 Exit Doorways Except In One- and Two-family Dwellings. 
  Section 614.41 Operation. Locks and fastenings on required exit doors shall be readily opened from the inner side, without the use of keys. Draw bolts, hooks and other similar devices shall be prohibited on all required exit doors. 
  Section 616.1 Opening Protectives. Door openings in fire walls or fire divisions which are required to have a fire resistance rating of two (2) hours or more shall be protected with an approved three (3) hour self-closing swinging fire door and frame or its labeled equivalent, said door to swing in the direction of exit travel. When serving as a dual exitway, there shall be adjacent openings with the same type swinging fire doors opening in opposite directions; except that in school buildings where supervised fire drills are conducted a double-acting fire door may be substituted for the pair of doors herein specified. 
  Section 618.21 Width. All interior required stairways shall be not less than forty-four (44) inches in clear width between walls and not less than forty (40) inches in clear tread length except that such widths may be reduced to thirty-six (36) inches and thirty-two (32) inches respectively in one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3) and in exitways from boiler rooms and similar service spaces not open to the public or in general use by employees and except as herein permitted. When the boiler room is less than three hundred (300) square feet in area, housing a low-pressure boiler, and is completely enclosed in two (2) hour fire-resistive construction with approved opening protectives and an iron ladder or other approved direct exit is furnished to the street, the primary stairway may be omitted. In one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3) interior stairways between attic and upper floor and basement and first floor shall be not less than thirty (30) inches in clear width between walls and not less than twenty-eight (28) inches in clear tread length. 
  Section 618.32 Vertical Rise. In assembly (Use Group F) and institutional (Use Group H) buildings, the height of vertical rise shall not exceed eight (8) feet between landings and intermediate platforms. In all other buildings except one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3), no stairway shall have a height of rise of more than twelve (12) feet between landings, nor shall any single flight of stairs have less than three (3) risers. 
  Section 618.41 Minimum Dimensions. The height of risers and width of treads in inches shall be as follows except as permitted in 618.42. 
Use Group Maximum Riser Minimum tread exclusive of nosing or projection One- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3) 81/4? 9? All other residential (Use Groups L-1 & L-2) 7? 10? Assembly and Institutional 7? 10? Business 7? 10?  
  Section 618.42 Winders. No winders shall be permitted in required stairways except in one- and two-family dwellings. In required stairways of one- and two-family dwellings, treads shall have a minimum width of four (4) inches increasing to the minimum width required in 618.4 measured at a point twelve (12) inches and beyond the inside edge of a rail, wall, or other guard. Other tread and riser dimensions shall be as herein required. 
  Section 620.3 Court Size. The yard or court shall have a minimum area of two hundred (200) square feet and a minimum dimension of ten (10) feet. 
  Section 620.52 Doors. Door openings from building to vestibules or balconies and to the stairways shall be not less than forty (40) inches wide. The doors shall be capable of being opened from both sides without a key, complying with all the requirements of exit doors for stairways, except that the fire resistance rating shall be not less than one and one-half (11/2) hours or the approved labeled equivalent complying with Article 9. 
  Section 621.0 Exterior Stairways. Exterior stairways shall not be permitted as any required exit. 
  Section 622.5 Railings. Railings shall be of the solid type surmounted by moving handrails traveling at the same speed as the stairway. 
  Section 623.0 Elevators as Exits. Elevators shall not constitute required means of exit. 
  Section 624.0 Fire Escapes. Fire escape stairs may be used as required means of exit only in existing buildings, subject to the provisions of the occupancy section applying. Fire escape stairs shall not constitute more than 50% of the required exit capacity in any case. Fire escape stairs shall not be accepted as constituting any part of the required exits for new buildings. 
  Section 625.0 Slidescapes. Slide-scapes and similar chutes shall not be permitted. 
  Section 626.2 Power Source. All exit signs shall be generally located at doors or exitways so as to be readily visible and not subject to obliteration by smoke. They shall be illuminated at all times from an independent electric circuit or other source of power which shall insure continued illumination of all exit signs in the event of failure of the building's main electric supply. 
  Section 627.4 Independent Power Source. Except in one- and two-family dwellings, the lighting shall be from an independent electric circuit or other source of power which shall insure continued illumination of all exitways in the event of failure of the building's main electric supply. 
  Section 701.0 Definitions. All the definitions are adopted with the following change: 
  Controlled Construction. See Section 129. 
  Section 707.1 Uniform Live Load. The entire Table 13 is adopted with the exception of Dwellings, which is changed as follows: 
Dwellings: 
Dwelling Units (Multifamily dwellings) ..... 50 
First Floor ..... 50 
Second Floor and habitable attic ..... 40 
Uninhabitable attics ..... 30(c) 
  Section 711.1 Minimum Roof Load. Flat and pitched roofs shall be designed for a live load of not less than thirty (30) pounds per square foot of horizontal projection. When used for incidental promenade purposes, roofs shall be designed for a minimum live load of sixty (60) pounds per square foot; and one hundred (100) pounds per square foot when designed for roof-garden or assembly uses. 
  Section 720.0 Combined Loading. The structural frame of all buildings shall be investigated for the combined effect of lateral and vertical loading and the individual members of the frame shall be designed accordingly. 
  Section 726.1 When Required. In the absence of satisfactory data from immediately adjacent areas, the owner or applicant shall make borings, test pits, or other soil investigations at such locations and to sufficient depths of the bearing materials to the satisfaction of the Building Official. For all buildings which are more than three (3) stories or forty (40) feet in height, and whenever it is proposed to use float, mat or any type of deep foundation, there shall be at least one exploratory boring to rock or to a depth of not less than fifty (50) feet below the load-bearing strata for every twenty-five hundred (2500) square feet of built-over area, and such additional tests that the Building Official may direct. 
  Section 727.1 Soil Test Method. The test procedure and testing apparatus shall be approved by the Building Official before they are used, and a complete record of tests together with a record of the soil profile shall be filed by a licensed New Jersey Professional Engineer qualified in soils testing, who shall have a fully qualified representative on the site during all borings and test operations. 
  Section 729.0 Depth of Footings. Except when erected upon solid rock or when otherwise protected from frost, foundation walls, piers and other permanent supports of all buildings and structures shall extend not less than 3'6? below the finished grade; spread footings of adequate size shall be provided when necessary to properly distribute the load within the allowable bearing value of the soil. Such structures shall be supported on piles when solid earth or rock is not available. No footings shall be founded on frozen soils. 
  Section 729.1 Isolated Footings. Footings on granulated soil of classes 5 to 10 inclusive in Table 15 shall be so located that the line drawn between the lower edges of adjoining footings shall not have a steeper slope than thirty (30) degrees with the horizontal, unless the material supporting the higher footing is braced or retained or otherwise laterally supported in an approved manner. 
  Section 730.2 Pressure Due to Lateral Loads. Increased pressure on any footing due to wind or other lateral loads shall be considered in the design of all footings. 
  Section 730.6 Keys. All footings shall have approved keys in their top surface to tie in the construction above. 
  Section 733.1 Concrete Strength. Concrete in unreinforced foundation footings shall be so proportioned as to develop an ultimate compressive strength of not less than three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch at twenty-eight (28) days. 
  Section 733.3 Dimensions. In unre-inforced concrete footings, the edge thickness shall be not less than eight (8) inches for footings on soil, and not less than twelve (12) inches above the tops of piles in footings on piles; except that for one-story and basement buildings of wood frame or brick veneered walls, their thicknesses may be reduced to six (6) inches and eight (8) inches respectively. In all cases the footing projection from the wall shall be not less than one-half the edge thickness of the footing. 
  Section 800.1 Accepted Engineering Practice. See 109.2 
  Section 816.62 Non-Shrink Mortar. Mortar used under base plates and similar structural members shall be an approved non-shrink type. 
  Section 818.2 Transportation. Ready-mixed concrete shall be transported in approved conveyances which insure delivery of the concrete with all aggregates properly proportioned and mixed dry, with water added at the construction site. 
  Section 821.4 Sheathing. The studs shall be covered with approved sheathing complying with Section 855. 
  Section 821.6 Application on Masonry Base. When applied directly to masonry or monolithic concrete, the surface shall be roughened or shall be made sufficiently rough to assure sufficient bond for plastering materials. 
  Section 823.4 Metal Lath. The dimension and sizes of expanded, ribbed, and sheet metal lath shall comply with accepted engineering practice and the standards listed on Appendix B; and shall be fabricated from not less than No. 30 U.S. Gage steel sheets. It shall be manufactured from copper bearing steel factory-coated with rust inhibitive paint after cutting or cut from zinc coated steel sheets. 
  Section 823.7 Combustible Lath. Wood or any other combustible lath shall not be used in plaster walls and ceilings. 
  Section 825.2 Types. Plywood for interior use may be either of the moisture-resistant or exterior type; plywood for exterior use shall be of the exterior waterproof type. Exterior plywood may be applied directly to the framing as a siding, provided it has a nominal thickness of one-half (1/2) inch except as herein provided. Joints shall occur over framing members unless wood or plywood sheathing is used or joints are lapped horizontally a minimum of one and one-half (11/2) inches or otherwise made waterproof to the satisfaction of the Building Official. If plywood is used as lapped siding without sheathing, the wall framing to which it is attached shall be diagonally braced. All habitable frame (Type IV) structures shall have sheathing applied under the approved exterior siding except that one thickness of plywood may be used as combination sheathing and siding provided said plywood is not less than three-quarter (3/4) inch thick approved marine-type plywood. 
  Section 825.3 Spans and Thickness. The maximum spans of plywood roof sheathing shall be limited by the allowable stresses and deflections for the design live load, but shall have not less than the following thicknesses, provided it is continuous over two or more spans and laid with face grain perpendicular to the supports:

Blocking installed at edges unless separate underlayment of one-fourth (1/4) inch minimum thickness, twenty-five thirty-seconds ( frax;25;32 ) inch wood strip flooring, or plywood with approved tongue and groove edges is used. qa If wood strips are perpendicular to supports, one-half (1/2) inch and five-eighths ( frax;5;8 ) inch can be used on twenty-four (24) inch span. 
*  This table applies also to all grades identified as Group I, excepting the sheathing grades (C-D and C-C) which, if identified as Group I, may be used as shown in upper portion of this table for Douglas fir plywood, etc. 
  Section 827.51 Shop Coat. After inspection and approval, all structural steel work, except work which is to be welded or encased in approved concrete non-corrosive aggregates or when specifically approved for members fabricated from approved corrosion-resistive alloy steel, shall be thoroughly cleaned and given one coat of acceptable metal protection well worked into the joints and other open spaces and applied only to dry surfaces. 
  Section 827.52 Contact Surfaces. No surfaces which are to be riveted or welded in contact shall be painted. Parts which are to be shop welded shall receive the shop coat after shop welding is finished. Parts which are to be field welded shall be protected with linseed oil or other approved protection before shipment. 
  Section 827.53 Field Coat. All field welds and field rivets and bolts and all abrasions to the shop coat of paint shall be spot painted. All exposed exterior steel shall be given a field coat of distinguishing color. 
  Section 839.1 Limitations. No wall less than twelve (12) inches thick shall be corbeled except to support firestopping around floor framing. The maximum total horizontal projection of corbels shall be not more than one-third ( 1/3 ) the thickness of the wall, nor shall the projection of the individual masonry unit exceed one-third ( 1/3 ) the height of the unit. 
  Section 842.3 Cinder Concrete. Cinders shall not be used as aggregate in reinforced concrete structural members. 
  Section 843.0 Controlled Concrete. When controlled materials are used in the design and construction of a reinforced concrete building or structure, the allowable working stresses shall conform to accepted engineering practice in accordance with the Building Code requirements for reinforced concrete listed in Appendix B. The ultimate compressive strength of the concrete shall not be limited in controlled concrete, provided proper provision is made to limit deflections and cracking. 
  Section 846.0 Short Span Floor Filling. For spans not exceeding ten (10) feet between steel flanges, the safe supporting capacity of concrete floor and roof slabs built as fireproof floor filling between steel beams shall be determined by the provisions of Section 842.2 or in accordance with the approved rules for stone concrete and other approved fire-resistive floor filling. 
  Section 855.0 Wood Frame Construction. The exterior walls, interior partitions, floors and roofs of wood frame construction shall be designed and constructed to develop adequate strength to resist all vertical and lateral forces due to both dead and live loads. Braced, platform, post and beam types of construction shall be acceptable framing methods and the framing shall consist of sills, plates, posts and girts braced at all angles, or adequately sheathed. 
  Section 855.1 Wood-Stud Frame. All studs shall be spaced not more than sixteen (16) inches on centers and shall be not less than 2? x 4? size with the short dimension parallel to the face of wall unless otherwise approved by the Building Official. 
  Section 855.11 Bearing Walls. Posts and studs in bearing walls and partitions shall be designed as columns, with due allowance for lateral support furnished by sheathing, intermediate bracing, horizontal bridging, wall coverings and the floor and roof assemblies. 
  Section 855.13 Bracing. Corner posts shall be the equivalent of not less than three (3) pieces of two (2) by four (4) inch studs braced by not less than one (1) piece of one (1) by four (4) inch continuous diagonal brace let into the studs. Bracing may be omitted when diagonal wood sheathing or plywood panels are used or other sheathing specified in Section 855.2 is applied vertically in panels of not less than four (4) feet by eight (8) feet in area with approved nailing complying with Appendix L. Sills shall be at least the equivalent of two (2), two (2) by six (6) inch studs. Plates which are used in bearing walls shall be double of the same width as the supporting studs and each not less than two (2) inches thick. In nonbearing partitions, at least one (1) top and bottom plate shall be provided, of the same width as the studs. Balloon framing is prohibited. 
  Section 855.16 Framing Over Openings. All window and door openings in wall and partitions shall have double joists at jambs, or trussed or framed by other approved methods and connection devices to support the superimposed loads. 
  Section 855.2 Exterior Wall Sheathing. Except as provided in Section 855.3 for weather boarding or when stucco construction complying with Section 821 is used, all enclosed buildings shall be sheathed with one of the materials of the following nominal thickness or any other material of equal strength and durability approved by the Building Official: 
Wood sheathing ..... 1 inch 
Plywood ..... 1/2 inch 
Gypsum sheathing ..... 1/2 inch 
Fiber boards ..... 1/2 inch 
  Section 855.3 Exterior Weather Boarding, Veneers and Condensation. To secure weather-tightness in framed walls and other unoccupied spaces, the exterior walls shall be faced with an approved weather resisting covering properly attached to resist wind and rain. The cellular spaces shall be so ventilated as not to vitiate the firestopping at floor attic and roof levels or shall be provided with interior non-corrodible vapor-type barriers complying with the approved rules; or other means shall be used to avoid condensation and leakage of moisture. The following materials shall be acceptable as approved weather coverings of the nominal thickness specified: 
Brick masonry veneers ..... 2 inches 
Stone veneers ..... 2 inches 
Clay Tile Veneers ..... 1/4-1 inch 
Stucco or exterior plaster ..... 3/4 inch 
Precast Stone Facing ..... 2 inches 
Wood siding (with sheathing) ..... 1/2 inch 
where over 5 inches exposed to weather ..... 3/4 inch 
Wood shingles .....3/8 inch 
Exterior plywood (with sheathing):\ 
for soffits and ceilings .....3/8 inch 
for walls ..... 1/2 inch 
Asbestos Shingles .....5/32 inch 
Aluminum Clapboard Siding ..... 0.030 inch 
Formed steel Siding ..... 28 gage 
  Section 855.32 Metal Veneers. Veneers of metal shall be fabricated from approved corrosion-resistive materials or shall be protected front and back with porcelain enamel or shall be otherwise treated to render the metal resistant to corrosion. Such veneers shall be mounted on wood or metal furring strips when mounted over masonry or on approved sheathing on the frame construction. 
  Section 855.34 Nailing. All weather-boarding, sidewall shingles, wall and roof coverings shall be securely nailed with aluminum, copper zinc, zinc-coated or other approved corrosion-resistive nails in accordance with the recommended nailing schedule or the approved manufacturer's standard. 
  Section 855.4 Foundation Anchorage. When required to resist wind uplift, wall sills shall be anchored to the foundation walls or piers at corners and at intermediate intervals of not more than eight (8) feet with one-half (1/2) inch bolts. The bolts shall be imbedded in the masonry foundations to a depth of not less than eight (8) inches in placed concrete, and not less than fifteen (15) inches in unit masonry. Sill plates shall be at least equivalent to two (2) two (2) by six (6) inch members. 
  Section 855.61 Bridging. In all floor, attic and roof framing, if flat, there shall be not less than one line of bridging for each eight (8) feet of span. The bridging shall consist of not less than one by three (1 × 3) inch lumber, double nailed at each end, or of equivalent metal bracing of equal rigidity secured at the intersection. A line of bridging shall also be required at supports where adequate lateral support is not otherwise provided. 
  Section 855.71 Types of Decking and Sheathing. Roof deck sheathing shall consist of not less than one (1) inch boards or plywood of the thickness specified in Section 825.3 or other approved materials of equivalent strength and rigidity. 
  Section 855.8 Flashing. Approved corrosion-resistive flashing shall be provided at the top of all exterior windows and door openings in such manner as to be leakproof. Similar flashings shall be installed at the intersection of chimneys or other masonry construction with frame or stucco walls, with projecting lips on both sides under stucco copings; under and at the ends of masonry, wood or metal copings and sills; continuously above all projecting wood trim; at wall and roof intersections; under built-in gutters; at junction of chimneys and roofs; in all roof valleys and around all roof openings. When veneers of natural or artificial stone are used fifteen (15) pound felt or paper shall be attached to the sheathing with flashing wherever necessary to prevent moisture penetration behind the veneer. 
  Section 859.3 Gutters and Coping. Unless constructed with parapet walls and coping as required by Section 870, all exterior walls shall be protected by approved drainage and in accordance with the Plumbing Code. 
  Section 868.0 Thickness of Masonry Walls. All masonry walls shall be of the minimum thickness specified in the Building Code standards for masonry listed in Appendix B. In no case shall the combined stress due to all loads exceed the allowable working stresses specified in the Basic Code for the materials of construction. 
  Section 870.0 Parapet Walls. All masonry exterior walls over 15 feet high except in one and two-family dwellings and structures where the roof overhangs the wall or in places where such walls are capped with cornices or gutters and except as required for fire walls in Section 907 or as herein specifically provided, shall be constructed with approved non-combustible weather-resistant parapet walls of sufficient strength, thickness and height to provide for approved roof drainage and waterproofing. 
  Section 871.1 Design. Foundation walls shall extend to at least 3'6? below finished grade unless otherwise constructed in accordance with the provisions of Article 7. They shall be designed to resist frost action and to support safely all vertical and lateral loads as provided in Article 7. The maximum stresses due to combined load shall be within the values specified for the materials used in the construction. Unless properly reinforced, tensile stresses shall not exceed those permitted on plain masonry. 
  Section 871.2 Minimum Thickness. The thickness of foundation walls shall be not less than the thickness of the wall supported and the minimum thickness shall be limited for the various materials of construction as herein specified. 
  Section 871.23 Hollow Unit Masonry Block Below Grade. Foundations of approved hollow masonry units shall have their voids completely filled with concrete up to finished grade where such blocks are in contact with earth on both faces of the block and where such blocks are exposed to freezing temperatures. Where blocks are in contact with earth on one face only and subject to freezing temperatures the first two courses of block shall have their voids completely filled with concrete. 
  Section 872.0 Retaining Walls. All retaining walls where the difference in finished grade is in excess of two feet six inches (2'6?) above the lower level, shall require a building permit and be designed in accordance with accepted engineering practice. Such walls built to retain or support the lateral pressure of earth, water or other superimposed loads, shall be designed and constructed of approved masonry, reinforced concrete, steel sheet piling or other approved materials. 
  Section 874.1 Steel Frame. Exterior steel columns and girders shall be protected as required in Section 914.1. 
  Section 874.2 Chases. The backs and sides of chases in exterior walls with less than eight (8) inches of approved masonry to the exterior surface shall be waterproofed. 
  Section 874.3 Foundations. Exterior walls below grade and the cellar floors of all buildings shall be made watertight and when necessary shall be reinforced to withstand water pressure as prescribed in Sections 710 and 871. The outside surface of below grade basement walls of buildings shall be protected with a one-half (1/2) inch parging coat of portland cement mortar and a one coat application of approved waterproofing paint. 
  Section 874.5 Cellar, Basement and Crawl Space Floors. Floors shall be constructed on earth to provide waterproof enclosures for all crawl spaces, cellars, and basements. Crawl space floors shall be constructed of not less than three (3) inch thick concrete slab throughout. Basement floors shall be constructed of not less than four (4) inch thick concrete slab throughout. Joints between all slabs and enclosure walls shall be made watertight by approved materials and construction. 
  Section 876.3 Sills. All sills which rest on concrete or masonry exterior walls and are less than four (4) feet from exposed earth shall be provided with approved metal termite shields and when such sills are less than six (6) inches from exposed earth they shall be protected from moisture by approved means. 
  Section 876.32 Posts or Columns. Bearing wood posts, columns and partitions in cellars and basements shall be supported by masonry piers or sills projecting not less than four (4) inches above the finished floor and separated therefrom by an approved impervious barrier. 
  Section 877.3 Flues and Chimneys. Combustible framing shall be trimmed not less than four (4) inches away from all chimneys and fireplaces, and six (6) inches away from flue openings. 
  Section 877.5 Concealed Roof Spaces. Concealed roof spaces enclosed by combustible ceiling and roof construction shall be subdivided into areas of not more than fifteen hundred (1500) square feet as provided in Section 219.0. 
  Section 900.23 Wood Structural Members. Wood in any form shall not be used as a structural member of any assembly in Type 1 and 2 construction required to have a fire resistance rating. 
  Section 902.1 Unclassified Uses. The Building Official shall determine the fire hazard classification of a building or structure designed for a use not specifically provided in Table 16 in accordance with the fire characteristics and potential fire hazard of the use group which it most nearly resembles; or its designation shall be fixed by the approved rules.

  Section 903.5 Classification of Roof Coverings. Roofing materials shall be classified in accordance with the severity of exposure to exterior fire and ability to resist the spread of fire to surrounding buildings and structures as provided by accepted engineering practice and the provisions of Section 929 and as per fire resistance ratings in Table 5. 
  Section 903.8 Fire Retardant Treated Wood. Wood that has been pressure-treated with fire retardant chemicals in accordance with the standards for pressure treatment of lumber or plywood in buildings listed in Appendix C may not be used in Type 1 and 2 construction for partitions, structural elements, and roof framing and sheathing. Such material shall not be used on the exterior of buildings where it will be exposed directly to the weather. Where used as a structural element, such material shall meet the requirements of Section 903.72. Where used as interior finish such material shall meet the requirements of Section 904.1. 
  Section 904.31 Acceptance Criteria. In all buildings except one- and two-family dwellings, all materials specified or required for artistic enhancement or use for decorations, draperies, curtains, scenery, and hangings, shall comply with this section for noncombustible or fire-retardant materials; or if treated to be flame-resistant, shall not generate smoke or gases more than those given off by untreated wood or paper burning under comparable conditions when tested in the vertical flame test listed in Appendix G. The test criteria for acceptance of flame-resistant materials shall be as follows: 
 For materials which weigh eight (8) ounces or more per square yard, the length of char shall not exceed four and one-half (41/2) inches; 
 For materials which weigh five (5) ounces or more but less than eight (8) ounces per square yard, the length of char shall not exceed five (5) inches; 
 For materials which weigh less than five (5) ounces per square yard, the length of char shall not exceed five and one-half (51/2) inches. 
 In no case shall the specimen continue flaming for more than two (2) seconds after removal of the test flame. 
  Section 905.1 Public Garages. All existing buildings and structures altered or converted for use to a garage, motor vehicle repair shop or gasoline station, more than one (1) story in height, unless of fireproof (Type 1) construction, shall have the partitions, columns, and girders and all floor and roof construction protected and insulated with noncombustible materials or assemblies of component materials having a fire resistance rating of not less than three-quarter (3/4) hours; except that existing roof trusses shall be exempt from all fireproofing requirements. 
  Section 905.2 Parking Structures. Parking structures shall be erected without enclosure walls or with partial enclosure walls. The total clear openings in said walls shall be not less than fifty (50) percent of the total wall area with said openings located in at least three (3) different sides, two (2) of which are opposite each other. The structure must meet these requirements to be classified as a parking structure. In addition, an enclosure wall with not less than two (2) hour fire resistance rating, without openings therein, shall be provided when located within six (6) feet of interior lot lines and where said structures' walls are located within six (6) feet of interior lot lines to the extent that the wall openings required herein cannot be made, the structure shall not be classified as a parking structure. A continuous wall or protective guard rail not less than three and one-half (31/2) feet in height of sufficient strength and design to restrain the vehicle shall be provided around the outside perimeter of the structure on each parking level and a wheel guard not less than six (6) inches in height shall be located so as to prevent any vehicle from striking the wall or guard rail. 
HEIGHT AND AREA LIMITATIONS FOR PARKING STRUCTURES 
Type of Construction Height Area in Square Feet 1-A and 1-B Unlimited Unlimited 2-A 7 stories 30,000 2-B 5 stories 30,000 2A, 2B 2 stories Unlimited  
Note:   The above limits of height permit parking on top level of structure. 
  Section 905.21 Below Grade. If a parking structure extends below the grade, that portion of the building below the ground floor shall not be classified as a parking structure unless it complies with the wall openings required in Section 905.2. If said portion of the building below the ground floor is used for parking of motor vehicles, it shall be classified as a public garage and shall comply with the requirements of Section 415. 
  Section 905.24 Electrical Wiring. All electrical wiring, equipment and appliances in such structures shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the Middle Department Association of Fire Underwriters. 
  Section 905.71 Non-Fireproof Construction. In all buildings other than one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3) and other than fireproof (Types 1-A and 1-B) construction with habitable or occupiable stories or basements below grade, the ceilings, partitions and supports below the grade floor shall be protected with noncombustible materials or assemblies of component materials having a fire resistance rating of not less than three-quarter (3/4) hours or shall be equipped with automatic sprinklers; but in no case less than the required fire resistance of the use group and type of construction required by Tables 5 and 6. 
  Section 905.74 Basement Assembly Uses. No dance hall, skating rink, or similar place of public assembly for amusement, entertainment, instruction, or service of food or refreshment shall be located in stories or rooms below grade unless the floor construction above and below grade is of not less than one and one-half (11/2) hour fire resistance; but in no case less than the required fire resistance of the use group and type of construction required by Tables 5 and 6. 
  Section 907.3 Frame Dwellings. In one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3), of frame (Type 4) construction, party walls shall be not less than 2-hour fire-resistive construction and shall extend through intersecting walls of frame construction to the outside of all combustible wall and roof sheathing. 
  Section 908.3 Opening Protectives. Every opening in a fire wall shall be protected on both sides with an approved automatic protective assembly having a three (3) hour fire resistance each side or the approved labeled equivalent, except when approved as a horizontal exit. 
  Section 908.4 Horizontal Exit. Door openings in a fire wall serving as a horizontal means of egress shall be protected with an approved 3-hour self-closing swinging fire door and frame or its labeled equivalent when designed as an exit from one side. When serving as a dual exitway there shall be adjacent openings with the same type swinging fire doors opening in opposite directions. Signs shall be provided indicating as an exit, the door which swings in the direction of the travel from that side. The size of the openings shall comply with Section 616. 
  Section 909.5 Combustible Stair Enclosures. See Section 618.94. 
  Section 910.42 Fireproof Construction. In all buildings and structures of other than institutional (Use Group H) and residential (Use Groups L-1 and L-2) of fireproof (Type 1) or of protected noncombustible (Type 2) constructions, partitions of a single thickness of wood or approved composite panels, and glass or other approved materials of similar combustible characteristics, may be used to subdivide rooms or spaces into offices, entries, or other similar compartments, provided they do not establish a public corridor or a private corridor serving an occupant load of fifty (50) or more in areas occupied by a single tenant and not exceeding twenty-five hundred (2500) square feet between fire-resistive or fire partitions, fire walls and fire-resistive floors. 
  Section 911.2 Covered Shaft Enclosures. The enclosing walls and the top of interior covered shafts shall be constructed of approved masonry, reinforced concrete or other approved construction with a fire resistance rating of not less than two (2) hours. 
  Section 911.4 Top Enclosure. The following sections shall not apply to one- and two-family dwellings. 
  Section 911.6 Existing Shaftways. In all existing shaftways of buildings of assembly (Use Groups F-1, F-2, F-3 and F-4) institutional (Use Groups H-1 and H-2) and residential (Use Groups L-1 and L-2) classifications, which are not already enclosed as herein required, the Building Official shall direct such construction as he may deem necessary to insure the safety of the occupants, subject to review by the Board of Appeals as provided in Section 128. 
  Section 912.1 Fire Protection. Unless supported or suspended from structural wall girders protected with insulating materials of the required fire resistance, or when the opening is spanned by a masonry arch of the required strength, all lintels more than eight (8) feet in length over openings in masonry walls shall be protected as required for all girders of the specified type of construction. 
  Section 913.2 Installation of Ceiling Fixtures. Fire-resistive ceilings which constitute an essential part of a floor or roof assembly to meet a required fire resistance rating may have openings to accommodate noncombustible piping, ducts or electric outlets. The aggregate area of such openings in the ceiling shall be not greater than one hundred (100) square inches in any one hundred (100) square feet of ceiling area except an aggregate opening area in excess of one hundred (100) square inches may be permitted where a floor or roof assembly with identical openings has been tested by an approved testing laboratory and given the fire resistance rating required for the type of construction. The fixtures and attachments shall be installed so as not to decrease the fire resistance of the assembly. All duct openings shall be protected with approved noncombustible fire dampers. 
  Section 913.3 Firestopping of Ceiling Space. Floor and roof construction in which the secondary structural members are not individually encased in fire-resistive material or assemblies of component materials, shall be firestopped in areas of not more than fifteen hundred (1500) square feet with noncombustible materials. Such firestopping shall comply with Section 921, or solid web structural members may be substituted for such firestops. Where floor and roof construction with accompanying ceilings is made entirely of noncombustible or fireproof construction, subdivision may be omitted, as provided in Section 219.0. 
  Section 914.1 Exterior Columns. Columns located in exterior walls or along the outer lines of a building or structure shall be fireproofed as required for the type of construction as regulated by Table 5; and shall be protected against corrosion by cement parging, waterproofing, or other approved methods. The interior faces of exterior columns shall be protected and insulated with coverings of the required fire resistance rating specified for interior columns in Table 5. 
  Section 915.1 Individual Encasement. Where trusses are required to be protected in Table 5, the individual truss members shall be entirely encased in materials or assemblies having the specified fire resistance ratings; except that individual protective coverings may be omitted, including the protection of roof beams and purlins, when a continuous ceiling of the specified fire resistance rating is provided below the lower chord of the truss. The enclosed truss space shall have an access doorway with maximum dimensions of three (3) by three (3) feet, equipped with an opening protective of the same fire resistance rating as the required truss protection. When the trusses or roof decking are permitted to be constructed of combustible materials, the space above the required fire-resistive ceiling shall be subdivided into maximum areas of fifteen hundred (1500) square feet as required for attic spaces in 219. 
  Section 915.3 Roofs Less Than 20 Feet High. In multi-story buildings of types of construction in which fire protected coverings of the structural frame-work are required by Table 5 and the provisions of the Basic Code, the fire protection of individual members of the roof truss may be omitted when the clear height of the lower chord of the truss is more than fifteen (15) and less than twenty (20) feet above the floor gallery or balcony immediately below and a continuous ceiling, having a fire resistance rating not less than that required for the type of construction, is installed. 
  Section 915.5 Roof Slabs and Arches. Where the omission of fire protection from roof trusses and purlins is permitted, the horizontal or sloping roofs in fireproof (Type 1) and noncombustible (Type 2) constructions, immediately above such trusses shall be constructed of noncombustible materials of the required strength without a specified fire resistance rating. 
  Section 916.0 Exterior Opening Protectives. Where specified herein, the exterior openings of all buildings and structures, other than churches, (Use Group F-4) residential buildings (Use Groups L-2 and L-3) and buildings of frame (Type 4) construction, shall have approved fire windows, shutters, curtains, doors or other approved opening protectives meeting the requirements of the Basic Code and the provisions of Article 4 for special use and occupancy. 
  Section 916.1 Horizontal Exposure. Approved protectives shall be provided in every opening facing a street thirty (30) feet or less in width, or within thirty (30) feet horizontally in a direct line not in the same plane of any unprotected frame (Type 4-B) structure or within thirty (30) feet horizontally of any opening in another building of any type of construction. 
  Section 917.1 Fire Door Assemblies. Approved fire door assemblies as defined in the Basic Code shall be constructed of any material meeting the fire-resistive requirements of Sections 903 and 904. All such doors shall meet the fire resistance of the table herein for the type of construction involved. 
Location Fire Resistance Rating in Hours Fire Walls and fire divisions of 3 or more hour construction ..... 3 Fire Walls and fire divisions of 2-hour construction ..... 11/2 Shaft enclosures and elevator hoistways of 2-hour construction ..... 11/2 Stairway and exitway enclosures except fire towers and grade passageways ..... 3/4  
 Doors in exitways of residential and business use buildings not more than three (3) stories or forty (40) feet in height with an occupancy load of not more than forty (40) below or seventy-five (75) above grade and doors from hotel rooms (Use Group L-1) from hospital rooms (Use Group H-2) and from schoolrooms (Use Group F-4) to public corridors may be of noncombustible construction or of one and three-quarter (11/4) inch solid-core wood doors. Plywood face veneers not more than one-twenty-eighth ( 1/28 ) inch thick shall be permitted on such doors. 
  Section 920.4 Double Reinforcement. Except in solid plaster partitions or when otherwise determined by the prescribed fire tests, plaster projections more than one (1) inch in thickness shall be reinforced with an additional layer of approved lath imbedded at least three-quarter (3/4) inch from the outer surface and fixed securely in place. 
  Section 923.5 Noncombustible Backing. Noncombustible backing for interior finish materials shall be a continuous surface with permanently tight joints, equal in area to the area of the finish, and extending completely behind such finish in all directions; and may be of any materials meeting the requirements of the Basic Code for noncombustible classification of material under Section 903.71. When the noncombustible backing does not constitute an integral part of the structural elements or system, it shall be attached directly to the structural elements or to furring strips as required for the application of finish according to Section 923.1, or may be suspended from the structural members at any distance provided concealed spaces created thereby shall be firestopped in accordance with the applicable requirements of the Basic Code. Where Class 3 interior finish is applied to a continuous noncombustible backing beneath wood joist construction, the allowable area for firestopping required in section 913.4 may be increased to fifteen hundred (1500) square feet. 
  Section 927.11 Size. Unless provided with other approved means of access to the roof, every building and structure more than three (3) stories in height, except dwellings with peak roofs, and all other buildings having roofs with a pitch greater than twenty (20) degrees, shall have an access trap door not less than two (2) by three (3) feet in area, securely attached or anchored to the roof framing, with a noncombustible ladder leading thereto from the top story. 
  Section 927.71 Supports. Water tanks having a capacity of more than five hundred (500) gallons placed in or on a building for the storage of potable water supplies and for use in the building services including air conditioning and fire prevention purposes, shall be supported on masonry, reinforced concrete, steel or other approved noncombustible framing; provided that when such supports are located within the building, they shall be fire protected as required for fireproof (Type 1-A) construction. 
  Section 927.72 Emergency Discharge. A pipe or outlet shall be located in the bottom or in the side close to the bottom, or the tank shall be fitted with a quick-opening valve to enable the contents to be discharged in an emergency. 
  Section 927.81 Within the Fire Limits. Within the fire limits, cooling towers erected on the roofs of buildings shall be constructed of noncombustible materials, except that drip bars may be of wood. 
  Section 927.82 Outside the Fire Limits. Outside the fire limits cooling towers may be constructed of wood or other approved materials of similar combustible characteristics; except that when the base of the tower is more than fifty-five (55) feet above grade and the tower is located on a building, the drip bars only may be fabricated of combustible materials as herein provided. 
  Section 927.9 Miscellaneous Roof Structures. Except as herein specifically provided, all towers, spires, dormers or cupolas shall be erected of the type of construction and fire resistance rating required for the building to which they are accessory as regulated by Tables 5 and 6. Radio and television towers and antennas shall be constructed to comply with Sections 427 and 428. 
  Section 928.1 Existing Roofs. A maximum of three (3) roof coverings, including a new roof, will be permitted unless the Building Official shall determine said number is not safe. In cases where there are three (3) or more coverings, the excess coverings must be removed before applying the new roof. Slate roofing must always be removed before applying a new roof. 
  Section 928.2 Within the Fire Limits. Within the fire limits all roof coverings shall be of asbestos, brick, concrete, metal, slate, tile, prepared asphalt, asbestos felt or laminated felt roofing finished with asphalt, slag, gravel, or similar noncombustible moisture-resistant materials or approved combinations of materials, complying with the requirements of Section 903.5 
  Section 928.3 Outside Fire Limits. Roof coverings which are classified as Class "C" under Section 903.5 shall be deemed to meet the requirements for use on all one- and two-family dwellings of frame (Type 4) construction, not exceeding two (2) stories and attic or thirty-five (35) feet in height and four thousand (4000) square feet in area when the distance of the building from any other building is not less than eight (8) feet; and on private garages and structures for similar accessory uses outside the fire limits located on the same lot with a dwelling, not exceeding one (1) story or twenty-five (25) feet in height and one thousand (1000) square feet in area and with a fire separation of not less than six (6) feet. 
  Section 928.41 Combustible Decking. Unless attached directly to noncombustible framework, all roof coverings shall be applied to a closely fitted deck. 
  Section 1005.0 Appliances Requiring Chimneys. All heating appliances, except electric and gas fired appliances specifically exempted by the provisions of Section 1011 shall be connected to chimneys which conform to the provisions of this Article. Chimneys shall be used for venting the following types of appliances: 
 1. Incinerators; 
 2. Appliances which may be converted readily to use solid or liquid fuels; 
 3. Combination gas-oil-burning appliances; 
 4. Appliances listed for use with chimneys only. 
 5. Oil-fired appliances and equipment except as exempted in Section 1011. 
  Section 1008.21 Masonry Chimneys. Masonry chimneys for solid and liquid fuel-fired equipment and appliances shall be constructed of masonry, reinforced concrete, or other approved noncombustible materials, and may be erected as freestanding or as constituting an integral part of a wall, or may be enclosed within a structure without constituting a component part thereof. In every case a chimney shall be wholly supported on noncombustible construction or on approved foundations complying with Article 7. 
  Section 1008.33 Dwellings. In one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3), the walls of a chimney in which the area of the flue is not more than two hundred (200) square inches, may be of solid masonry or reinforced concrete not less than four (4) inches thick when provided with a fireclay lining. 
  Section 1008.34 Lining. Low-temperature masonry chimneys with less than eight (8) inch walls shall be lined with an approved flue lining that conforms to the requirements of this Section and the outside face of interior walls shall be smoothly parged or stuccoed so as to be gastight, or the flue walls within the building shall be eight (8) inch thick solid masonry. 
  Section 1008.36 Flue Lining Construction. Flue linings shall be constructed in advance of the chimney and shall start from a point not less than eighteen (18) inches below the inlet of the smokepipe, or at the apex of the smoke chamber of a fireplace and the unlined brickwork of the throat shall be plastered on the outside so as to be gastight. The lining shall be constructed as nearly vertical as possible and shall extend not less than one (1) inch above the top or cap of the flue. 
  Section 1008.63 Chimney Supports. All masonry chimneys shall rest on a foundation located on permanently undisturbed soil or shall be supported on noncombustible construction; and no such chimney shall rest on or be hung or otherwise supported from combustible floor or wall construction. Chimneys may be corbeled three inches to a foot of height but not to exceed 1/4 of the outside width of the chimney in the direction of corbel providing the chimney about the flue lining is constructed of solid masonry, except where there is a question of stability the Building Official may require a structural analysis prepared by a licensed professional engineer experienced in structural design. Masonry chimneys erected outside of frame dwellings shall be anchored to the stud walls at each floor level or at vertical intervals not more than ten (10) feet apart. 
  Section 1008.64 Clearances. Combustible framing shall be not less than two (2) inches away from all chimneys and no combustible materials shall be placed within one (1) inch of any chimney, nor within six (6) inches of any inlet opening to such chimney. 
  Section 1008.66 Shape. No change in the size or shape of a chimney shall be made within six (6) inches of the roof framing through which it passes. 
  Section 1009.8 Interior Metal Chimney Enclosures. Every interior metal chimney or part thereof, erected within a multi-story building shall be enclosed with walls of not less than three (3) hours fire resistance in all stories above that in which the appliance served thereby is located. Where the metal chimney passes through a combustible roof, it shall be guarded by a galvanized metal or other approved noncombustible, ventilating thimble that extends at least nine (9) inches below and above the roof construction. The thimbles shall be of a size to provide clearance on all sides of the metal chimney of not less than six (6) inches for low heat appliances and not less than eighteen (18) inches for medium and high heat appliances as defined in Article II, unless the metal chimney is insulated and protected to prevent a temperature of more than one hundred and sixty (160) degrees F. on the exterior surface. 
  Section 1013.2 Hearth. Every fireplace shall be constructed with a hearth of brick, stone, tile or other noncombustible material. For fireplaces with an opening of less than six (6) square feet, the hearth shall extend not less than eighteen (18) inches in front. For fireplaces with an opening of six (6) square feet or more the hearth shall extend not less than twenty (20) inches in front. All hearths shall extend not less than four (4) inches on each side of the fireplace opening. Such hearths shall be supported on trimmer arches of brick, stone, tile or concrete not less than four (4) inches thick, or other equally strong and fire-resistive materials. All combustible forms or centering shall be removed after completion of the supporting construction. 
  Section 1013.41 Floor Framing. All header and trimmer beams of combustible floor construction shall be located at least two (2) inches from the face of chimneys and backs of fireplaces and the spaces shall be firestopped with approved noncombustible materials. 
  Section 1013.42 Combustible Trim. Wood or other combustible material shall not be installed on or about a fireplace less than four (4) inches from the fireplace opening; and combustible materials located within the twelve (12) inch boundary of the opening shall not project more than one-quarter (1/4) inch from the face of the masonry for each one (1) inch distance from the opening. 
  Section 1016.0 Fuel-Fired Incinerator Chimneys. Chimneys for fuel-fired incinerators shall be constructed of at least four (4) inches of clay or shale brick masonry which is lined with not less than four and one-half (41/2) inches of fire brick for at least forty (40) feet above the roof of the combustion chamber and beyond the forty (40) foot level shall be enclosed with not less than eight (8) inches of clay or brick masonry with a standard fire clay flue liner not less than 5/8 ? in thickness extending from the top of the fire brick lining to the top of the chimney. 
  Section 1019.1 Material. Ducts and vents shall be constructed of aluminum, copper, Monel Metal, galvanized steel, cement asbestos or other approved noncombustible corrosion-resistive materials of adequate strength, durability and for the temperatures involved; and the seams shall be securely welded, riveted or fastened and made substantially air- and gas-tight. 
  Section 1019.42 Exception. When sufficiently insulated to prevent more than one hundred and sixty (160) degrees F. temperature on the exterior, the clearances herein specified shall not be required. 
  Section 1100.4 Clearance from Combustible Construction. All heating and cooking appliances shall be installed with adequate clearances from combustible construction or shall be provided with integral insulation of the appliance or fire protection of the structural members so that continued or intermittent operation shall not raise the temperature on the surface of combustible floors, walls or partitions above one hundred and sixty (160) degrees F. 
  Section 1103.1 Periodic Inspection of Heating Equipment. All boilers exceeding 345,000 B.T.U. input rating and unfired pressure vessels subject to the provisions of this Article shall be inspected at least once annually by a recognized national inspection agency listed in Appendix A or acceptable to the Building Official and a report filed with the Building Official. These inspections and tests are to be made at the owner's expense. 
  Section 1105.1 Boiler Operator Cer-tificate of Fitness. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a steam boiler of more than 345,000 BTU input rating or a boiler designed to carry a steam pressure of more than fifteen (15) pounds per square inch, without a certificate of fitness from the Building Official or other authorized municipal agency. 
  Section 1105.4 Safety Valves. All steam boilers exceeding 345,000 BTU rating shall be required to have double safety valves set at not more than designed boiler working pressure unless otherwise required for high pressure boilers. 
  Section 1107.1 Low Heat Appliances. A steam boiler which operates at fifty (50) pounds per square inch or less gage pressure; or a steam boiler of less than 345,000 BTU input rating, regardless of operating pressure; or any equipment otherwise classified as a medium heat appliance, but not larger than one hundred (100) cubic feet in size, in which the products of combustion at the point of entrance to the flue under normal operating conditions have a temperature of six hundred (600) degrees F. or less, shall be classified as a low-heat appliance. 
  Section 1107.2 Medium Heat Appliances. A steam boiler which operates at fifty (50) pounds or more per square inch gage pressure; or a steam boiler of over 345,000 B.T.U. input rating regardless of operating pressure; or any heat appliance, in which the products of combustion at the point of entrance to the flue have a temperature of between six hundred (600) degrees and one thousand (1000) degrees under normal operating conditions, shall be classified as a medium heat appliance. 
  Section 1110.0 Mounting Exceptions for House Heating Appliances. Boilers and furnaces used for heating buildings and structures, including low pressure steam and hot water boilers, warm air furnaces and floor mounted direct-fired unit heaters shall be installed in accordance with accepted engineering standards listed in Appendix B within the limitations of the Basic Code governing fire protection and fire safety. Mounting of such heating equipment shall conform with Section 1108 for low heat appliances except the mounting and clearances may be modified for heating installations in one- and two-family dwellings as required under the specific provisions in the Basic Code for gas boilers, warm air furnaces, floor furnaces, unit and space heaters. 
  Section 1114.5 Basement Ceiling Protection. In all wood joist construction, basement ceilings over all heating equipment for which a permit is required for the installation or alteration thereof, shall be protected for a distance of not less than four (4) feet beyond the sides and back and not less than eight (8) feet from the front with not less than one (1) hour fire-resistant construction. 
  Section 1115.41 Solid and Liquid Fuels. See NBFU (NFPA) No. 31 for oil burning equipment and the requirements of the appendix standards. 
  Section 1115.42 Gas-Fired Equipment. See Appendix Standards. 
  Section 1121.1 Air Supply. A central fan heating system of the recirculating type for use in structures with large open areas such as garages, shall provide a positive air recirculation of at least one (1) cubic foot per square foot of floor area per minute when the average ceiling height is fifteen (15) or less feet; and with greater heights, the air recirculation shall be increased proportionately; but in no case shall less than five (5) percent of the air moved by the fan be taken directly from outside the building. 
  Section 1122.3 Transmission of Power. The motive power for fans located within the room from which flammable vapors are removed shall be transmitted from an outside source through a shaft operating in a bushed shaft hole, unless otherwise installed in accordance with accepted engineering practice. 
  Section 1123.3 Wall Heaters. A wall heater shall not be located in a wall of combustible construction unless the unit has been approved and is installed in accordance with accepted engineering practice. 
  Section 1124.0 Floor Furnaces. Floor furnaces as herein defined shall not be installed. 
  Section 1128.7 Prohibited Uses. No solid or liquid fuel or gas-fired water heaters shall be installed in bathrooms, bedrooms, or other habitable spaces or in any enclosed space with a volume of less than three hundred (300) cubic feet; nor shall vent pipes designed for use with gas appliances be used with solid or liquid fuel-fired equipment. 
  Section 1129.4 Electric Connections and Wiring. All electric wiring shall comply with Article 15. 
  Section 1131.5 Vent Discharge Outlet.
