The vent pipe from fuel oil tanks shall terminate outside the building with the discharge end located not less than three (3) feet vertically and horizontally from any window, skylight or roof structure opening in the same or any adjoining building, and not more than twelve (12) feet above the fill pipe terminal. The tops of such vents shall be protected with a weatherproof hood. 
  Section 1133.0 Exterior Storage Tanks. Oil storage tanks which are located outside a building or other structure shall be erected underground and shall comply with all the pertinent requirements of Sections 1130, 1131 and 1132. 
  Section 1133.4 Location. The capacity of individual tanks shall be determined by the location in respect to property lines as specified in Table 21. No tank regardless of capacity, shall be located closer to any lot line or building or structure than five (5) feet. All existing buildings or structures or buildings or structures to be constructed shall be protected from undermining same when tank is being installed and said tanks shall be protected from building or structure surcharge loads. 
 Table 21. No change. 
  Section 1135.0 Non-Fuel-Fired Incinerators. Non-fuel fired incinerators shall not be installed or constructed within the Borough of Glen Ridge. 
  Section 1136.0 Fuel-Fired Incinerators. All fuel-fired incinerators shall conform to the requirements of this Section. 
  Section 1200.0 Scope. The provisions of this Article shall control the installation of fire alarm and fire communication systems and fire extinguishing service equipment in all buildings and structures when specified or required by the Basic Code. All electrical equipment and the details of wiring for fire-extinguishing installations shall comply with the provisions of the National Electric Code and the applicable standards listed in Appendices B and I. 
  Section 1203.11 Pressure Test. All new systems including yard piping shall be tested hydrostatically at not less than two hundred (200) pounds per square inch pressure for two (2) hours, or at fifty (50) pounds per square inch in excess of the normal pressure when the normal pressure is in excess of one hundred fifty (150) pounds per square inch. 
  Section 1203.21 Wet Pipe System. Automatic wet pipe systems shall be subjected to a hydrostatic pressure test for two (2) hours duration of not less than two hundred (200) pounds per square inch in every part of the installation exclusive of water supply tanks. 
  Section 1203.23 Pressure Tanks. Pressure tanks shall be tested to a pressure of two (2) times the working pressure. 
  Section 1204.51 Periodic Check. All automatic sprinkler systems shall be inspected every two (2) years to observe whether all rooms and spaces are equipped with required sprinklers and that all sprinklers are unobstructed by storage of the contents or by the erection of partitions or other structural features which prevent free operation of the system. 
  Section 1206.2 Existing Sprinklers. Sprinkler systems and devices heretofore approved shall not be required to conform to the provisions of this Article except when the fire hazard due to construction and use of the building is increased, or when additions are made to the building or when additional protection is deemed necessary for the safety of the occupants. 
  Section 1206.21 Voluntary Protection. Existing sprinkler systems not required by the Basic Code which have been installed voluntarily must conform to the provisions of this Article and the siamese hose connection shall be maintained as directed by the Fire Official. 
  Section 1206.23 Water Supply. The service supply of existing systems shall be sufficient to operate the entire system as originally designed and installed. 
  Section 1207.0 Wet Standpipe Requirement. Except as herein required, all buildings and structures hereafter erected, other than one- and two-family dwellings (Use Group L-3), shall comply with the provisions of this Article. 
  Section 1207.83 Standpipe Feeder. The pipe connecting the siamese to the standpipe shall be at least four (4) inches in diameter. When the automatic supply is from a Borough main or a yard hydrant system, a two and one-half (21/2) inch valved and threaded hose outlet shall be provided to enable the system to be drained. 
  Section 1208.0 Standpipe Water Supplies. The source of water supply to standpipes shall be adequate to maintain a flow of two hundred and fifty (250) gallons per minute with not less than fifty (50) pounds per square inch residual pressure at the topmost outlet of the building or structure and shall conform to the minimum requirements of this Section. 
  Section 1208.4 Fire Pump Standpipe Supply. When supplied by an automatic fire pump, the combined pump capacity shall be sufficient to maintain a flow of two hundred and fifty (250) gallons per minute for one standpipe and five hundred (500) gallons per minute where two or more standpipes are required and the residual pressure at the topmost outlet shall remain at fifty (50) pounds per square inch while water is being discharged through an approved hose with a one and one-eighth (1 1/8 ) inch nozzle. All fire flows shall meet with the approval of the Glen Ridge Fire Department. When pumps are not supplied from the street main, the source shall furnish sufficient water for full operation of the system for not less than one hour. 
  Section 1209.1 Size and Capacity of Dry Standpipes. Dry standpipes shall be of a size and capacity not less than that required for wet standpipes and shall be capable of delivering not less than two hundred and fifty (250) gallons of water per minute per standpipe when the topmost outlet in each standpipe riser is open simultaneously. These minimum flows shall be provided under the operation of one (1) fire engine or pumper; except that in existing installations, the administrative official may accept a lesser flow when deemed adequate by him. 
  Section 1213.11 Partial Protection. A one-source system shall be provided in all portions of residential (Use Group L-1 and L-2), institutional (Use Groups H-1 and H-2) and assembly buildings (Use Groups F-1, F-2, F-3 and F-4) occupied for storage or workshop purposes which involve combustible and flammable materials. A one-source system shall be provided in all boiler rooms located within buildings having a basement area exceeding twenty-five hundred (2500) square feet when the buildings are used for residential (all Groups L-1 and L-2), institutional (Use Groups H-1 and H-2) and assembly buildings (Use Groups F-1, F-2, F-3 and F-4). 
  Section 1213.13 Public Garages. All public garages, as defined in Section 415, located in buildings of which their upper stories are designed for other uses, shall be provided with a one-source system. 
  Section 1213.16 Mercantile and Industrial Buildings. Except as provided herein, a one-source system shall be provided on all floors of mercantile and industrial buildings (Use Groups C and D) of more than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet in area on any floor above or below the grade floor when of types 1-A, 1-B or 2-A construction; of more than ten thousand (10,000) square feet when of type 2-B construction; of more than seven thousand five hundred (7,500) square feet when of types 3-B and 3-C construction; and of more than six thousand (6,000) square feet when of Type 4-A construction. 
  Section 1217.8 Yard Systems. All oil storage plants, lumber yards, amusement or exhibition parks and similar occupancies and uses involving high fire and life hazards, when required by the provisions of Article 4 or when deemed necessary by the Building Official shall be provided with an installation of properly placed fire hydrants, piped to an adequate water supply and equipped with sufficient hose housed in accordance with the approved rules. 
  Section 1308.21 Deep Excavations. Whenever an excavation is made to a depth of more than three and one-half (31/2) feet below the average level of the existing ground along the wall of a building, the person who causes such excavation to be made, if afforded the necessary license to enter the adjoining premises, shall preserve and protect from injury at all times and at his own expense such adjoining structure or premises which may be affected by the excavation. If the necessary license is not afforded, it shall then be the duty of the owner of the adjoining premises to make his building or structure, safe by installing proper underpinning or foundations or otherwise; and such owner, if it be necessary for the protection of his work, shall be granted the necessary license to enter the premises where the excavation or demolition is contemplated. 
  Section 1308.22 Shallow Excavations. Whenever an excavation is made to a depth of three and one-half (31/2) feet or less below the average level of the existing ground along the wall of a building, the owner of a neighboring building or structure, the safety of which may be affected by the proposed excavation, shall preserve and protect from injury and shall support his building or structure by the necessary underpinning or foundations. If necessary for that purpose, he shall be afforded a license to enter the premises where the excavation is contemplated. 
  Section 1308.23 Unused Excavations. No excavation shall be maintained except those necessary for the foundations of structures, or in connection with the installation of facilities for permitted uses, and such excavation shall be used for the intended purpose within ninety (90) days from the issuance of a permit or shall be refilled to the average surrounding ground elevation in such manner as to prevent the collection of water, erosion of earth or collapse or sliding of steep banks. 
  Section 1309.1 Grading of Lot. When a building has been demolished and no building operation has been projected or approved, the vacant lot shall be filled, graded and maintained in conformity to the established street grades at curb level and adjacent property. The lot shall be maintained free from the accumulation of rubbish and all other unsafe or hazardous conditions which endanger the life or health of the public; and provision shall be made to prevent the accumulation of water or damage to any foundations on the premises or the adjoining property. 
  Section 1311.4 Obstructions. Material and equipment shall not be placed or stored so as to obstruct access to fire hydrants, standpipes, fire or police alarm boxes, utility boxes, catch basins, or manholes; nor shall they be located within twenty (20) feet of a street intersection, or so placed as to obstruct normal observations of traffic control lights or signs, or to interfere with the use of public conveyance loading areas. 
  Section 1406.1 Removing or Reconstructing Signs. No sign heretofore approved and erected shall be repaired, altered or moved, nor shall any sign or part thereof, which is blown down, destroyed or removed, be re-erected, reconstructed, rebuilt or relocated where said incident or work shall constitute 50% or more of the value of the structure, unless it is made to comply with all applicable requirements of this Article. 
  Section 1408.1 Filing Bond. No person shall erect, install, remove or rehang any sign for which a permit is required under the provisions of the Basic Code, until an approved bond shall have been filed in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
  Section 1408.2 Amount of Bond. Such bond shall be conditioned on the construction, erection and maintenance of the sign in accordance with the provisions of the Basic Code and shall protect and save the Borough of Glen Ridge harmless from any and all claims or demands for damages by reason of any negligence of the sign hanger, contractor, his agents, or by reason of defects in the construction, or damages resulting from the collapse or failure of any sign or part thereof. 
  Section 1410.41 Within the Fire Limits. Within the fire limits, no ground sign shall be constructed of combustible materials, except as provided in Section 1409.5. 
  Section 1411.0 Roof Signs. Roof signs shall not be permitted within the Borough of Glen Ridge. 
  Section 1412.3 Extension. Wall signs shall not be erected to extend above the top of the wall, nor extend beyond the ends of the wall to which they are attached. 
  Section 1413.0 Projecting Signs. Projecting signs shall not be permitted within the Borough of Glen Ridge. 
  Section 1414.0 Marquee Signs. Marquee signs shall not be permitted within the Borough of Glen Ridge. 
  Section 1416.1 Certificates. All electrically illuminated signs shall be certified as to electric wiring and devices by the Middle Department Association of Fire Underwriters and all wiring and accessory electrical equipment shall conform to the requirements of the National Electric Code. 
  ARTICLE 15. Electrical Wiring and Equipment. No electric wiring system consisting of electrical conductors, fittings, devices or fixtures for light, heat, power, communications or any other service shall be installed within or on any building, structure or premises nor shall any alteration be made in any existing installation without first filing an application for inspection with the Middle Department Association of Fire Underwriters. Evidence of such filing shall be available for inspection on the premises at any time work is in progress; however, when emergency repairs are necessary in order to maintain service on an electrical system, the necessary repairs may be made before filing an application for inspection. Except where the Administrative Official has given temporary permission for a reasonable time to supply and use current in part of an electric installation before such installation has been fully completed; provided that the part covered by the temporary permission complied with all the requirements of the Middle Department Association of Fire Underwriters, it shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of electric wiring for light, heat, power, communications, or any other service in or on any building, structure or premises, or to use or permit the use of any alteration to such electric wiring, unless the required certificate of approval has been issued by the Middle Department Association of Fire Underwriters. The Building Official shall not issue a permanent Certificate of Use and Occupancy until proof of said electric approval has been made available to him. 
 (See amendment to ARTICLE 15 page 53) 
  Section 1600.3 Where Required. All new buildings which are designed to be occupied for any use other than residential 1- and 2-family (L-3) and which exceed two (2) stories in height shall have not less than one elevator serving said floors. The elevator and its enclosure shall conform to all the requirements of Article 16. 
  Section 1603.31 Periodic Inspection Intervals. Periodic inspections shall hereafter be made at intervals of not more than six (6) months for all elevators, manlifts and moving stairways; at intervals of not more than twelve (12) months for power dumbwaiters with a capacity of one hundred (100) pounds and over. Miscellaneous hoisting and elevating equipment, conveyors and amusement devices shall be inspected at such intervals as may be deemed necessary by the Building Official to insure safety of operation. 
  Section 1603.43 Manlifts. All equipment and machinery of manlifts shall be inspected and tested to insure safety of operation and shall include tests of the brake, terminal stopping device, belt tension and emergency stopping device. Acceptance tests shall also include a load capacity test as provided in the accepted standard listed in Appendix B. 
  Section 1604.21 Tests and Minimum Safeguards Required. A limited certificate shall not be issued for an elevator until such elevator has satisfactorily passed the following tests: rated load, car and counterweight safety and terminal stopping devices. Permanent or temporary guards and enclosures shall be installed on the car, around the hoistway, and at the landing entrances. Equipment other than elevators shall be tested and protectives provided as deemed necessary by the Building Official to insure safe operation for the limited service specified. 
  Section 1605.41 Power to Seal Equipment. The Building Official in addition to any other penalties herein provided shall have the power to seal out of service any device or equipment covered by this Article for the following reasons: When in case of emergency in the opinion of the Building Official, any such device is in a condition to render it unsafe for operation; or for wilful failure to comply with recommendations and orders issued by the Building Official. 
  Section 1610.12 Dumbwaiter Enclosure. Shaft enclosures of dumbwaiters which travel through more than one (1) story and serve more than two (2) adjacent floors shall be of two (2) hour fire-resistive construction with approved one and one half (11/2) hour opening protectives or the approved labeled equivalent complying with Article 9, except as permitted in Section 1610.13. 
  Section 1610.13 Special Dumbwaiter Enclosures. In frame Type 4 construction, the enclosure of dumbwaiters not more than three (3) square feet in area with a load capacity of not more than twenty-five (25) pounds and serving not more than two (2) adjacent floors, shall be enclosed with approved noncombustible materials. 
  Section 1614.1 Fire Doors. Door openings of elevator hoistway enclosures shall be equipped with protective assemblies having a fire resistance rating of not less than one and one-half (11/2) hours or their approved labeled equivalent. 
  ARTICLE 17. Plumbing, Drainage and Gas Piping. The design, installation, alteration, addition, maintenance, repair and/or replacement of plumbing and drainage systems including sanitary sewer piping within five (5) feet of a building, water piping, gutters and rain leaders, house drains, sanitary facilities, vents, fixtures and gas piping within a building or structure shall comply with the requirements of the Glen Ridge Plumbing Code and shall be administered by the Glen Ridge Board of Health Official. 
  Section 1802.2 Permits. A permit shall be required for all new installations and for all major replacements in existing installations which may result in violation of the Basic Code; or where required for the remedy of existing defective installations. All systems connected to the public water supply of Glen Ridge shall require permits except that permits will not be required for the following systems unless they are connected to said public water supply. 
  Section 1810.2 Soldered Joints on Copper Tubing. Soldered joints on copper tubing used in all refrigerating systems in buildings for institutional and assembly uses (Use Groups F and H) and in refrigerating systems containing more than twenty (20) pounds of refrigerant gas in buildings of other use groups shall be fabricated solders of alloys having melting points of not less than one thousand (1,000) degrees F. (Commonly known as silver solder). 
  Section 1900.4 Conflicting Laws. Nothing herein contained shall be deemed to nullify any provisions of the Zoning laws or any other statute or legally adopted rule pertaining to building construction of the Borough of Glen Ridge in respect to the location, use, height, area of building, and type of construction, nor have the effect of increasing working stresses or reducing exit facilities and health provisions as prescribed in the Basic Code. 
  Section 1917.0 Plumbing, Piping and Sanitary Equipment. All installations of plumbing, drainage and gas piping systems shall comply with the provisions of Article 17. 
  Section 2003.3 Transparent Roof Sheathing. Outside of the fire limits, approved plastics may be used as transparent roof sheathing over non-habitable rooms or spaces as follows: 
  Section 2003.5 Dormer Windows. Where Class C roof coverings are permitted under the provisions of Section 929, dormer windows may be glazed with approved plastics. 
  Section 2004.21 Outside the Fire Limits. A continuous run of thermosetting plastics shall be permitted provided this material shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the wall area. The glazing of openings in masonry-enclosed (Type 3) and in wood frame (Type 4) construction shall not exceed the limits prescribed in Section 2004.24 and shall be in compliance with the required fire separations of the Basic Code. 
  Section 2004.24 Within the Fire Limits. Wall panel units of reinforced thermosetting plastics shall be limited to the covering of individual window openings as provided in Section 2004.1 and shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total wall area of the story on that side. 
(Ord. 1231, 1993: Ord. 977 § 1, 1975: Ord. 966 §§ 1, 2, 1974: Ord. 872 § 2(b), 1967) 
Chapter 15.08 - BUILDING INSPECTION DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

15.08.010 - Established-Personnel. 
    There is established in the borough of Glen Ridge a State Uniform Construction Code Enforcing Agency to be known as the building inspection department, consisting of a construction official, building subcode official, plumbing subcode official, fire protection subcode official and such other subcode officials for such additional subcodes as the Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, state of New Jersey, shall hereafter adopt as part of the State Uniform Construction Code. The construction official shall be the chief administrator of the enforcing agency. 
(Ord. 994 § 1(a), 1977) 
15.08.020 - Filling positions. 
    Each official position created in Section 15.08.010 shall be filled by a person qualified for such position pursuant to P.L. 1975, c. 217, as amended, and N.J.A.C. 5:23; provided that, in lieu of any particular subcode official an on-site inspection agency may be retained by contract pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:23. More than one such official position may be held by the same person; provided that such person is qualified pursuant to P.L. 1975, c. 217 and N.J.A.C. 5:23 to hold each such position. 
(Ord. 994 § 1(b), 1977) 
15.08.030 - Location. 
    The public shall have the right to do business with the enforcing agency at one office location except for emergencies, and unforeseen or unavoidable circumstances. 
(Ord. 994 § 1(c), 1977) 
15.08.040 - Fees. 
    The fee for a construction permit shall be the sum of the subcode fees listed in subsections A through D and shall be paid before the permit is issued. 
A.	The building subcode fee shall be: 
1.	For new construction, $0.025 per cubic foot of building or structure volume; provided that the minimum fee shall be twenty dollars. 
2.	For renovations, alterations and repairs, fifteen dollars per one thousand dollars of the estimated cost of the work up to fifty thousand dollars and twelve dollars per one thousand dollars of the estimated cost in excess of fifty thousand dollars; provided that the minimum fee shall be ten dollars. 
3.	For additions, $0.025 per cubic foot of building or structure volume for the added portion; provided that the minimum fee shall be twenty dollars. 
4.	For combinations of renovations and additions, the sum of the fees computed separately as renovations and additions. 
B.	The plumbing subcode fee shall be as established by the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs. 
C.	The electrical subcode fee shall be as established by the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs. 
D.	The fire subcode permit fees established herein apply to all commercial buildings and multifamily dwellings. The aforesaid permit fees apply to fire protection equipment and include: sprinklers, standpipes, automatic fire alarm systems and manual fire alarms. The subcode fees are as follows: 
1.	For the installation of sprinkler systems: 
a.	For the first twenty heads, the fee shall be fifty dollars; 
b.	For twenty-one to one hundred heads, the fee shall be one hundred dollars; 
c.	For one hundred one to two hundred heads, the fee shall be one hundred ninety-five dollars; 
d.	For two hundred one to four hundred heads, the fee shall be four hundred seventy-five dollars; 
e.	For more than four hundred heads, the fee shall be eight hundred fifty dollars. 
2.	For the installation of standpipes, the fee shall be fifty dollars. 
3.	For the installation of automatic fire alarms, smoke and heat detectors: 
a.	For the first twenty units, the fee shall be fifty dollars; 
b.	For twenty-one to one hundred units, the fee shall be one hundred dollars; 
c.	For one hundred one to two hundred units, the fee shall be one hundred ninety-five dollars; 
d.	For two hundred one to four hundred units, the fee shall be four hundred seventy-five dollars; 
e.	For more than four hundred units, the fee shall be eight hundred fifty dollars. 
4.	For the installation of commercial cooking suppression systems, the fee shall be thirty dollars. 
5.	For the installation of manual fire alarms, the fee for each manual fire alarm pull station shall be ten dollars; provided that the minimum fee shall be thirty dollars. 
E.	The elevator inspection fee shall be as established by the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs. 
F.	The fee for plan review shall be twenty percent of the amount to be charged for the construction permit and shall be paid before the plans are reviewed. The amount paid for this fee shall be credited toward the amount of the fee to be charged for the construction permit. 
G.	The fee for a permit for demolition of a building or structure shall be fifty dollars. 
H.	The fee for a permit for the removal of a building or structure from one lot to another or to a new location on the same lot shall be ten dollars per one thousand dollars of the sum of established costs of moving, for new foundations and for placement in a completed condition in the new location; provided that the minimum fee shall be fifty dollars per structure or seventy-five dollars for a one or two unit home. 
I.	The fee for a permit to construct a sign as permitted by the zoning ordinance shall be thirty dollars. 
J.	The fee for a certificate of continued occupancy shall be fifty dollars. 
K.	The fee for a certificate of occupancy granted pursuant to a new use or change of use shall be seventy-five dollars. 
L.	The fee for a permit for installation of an elevator shall be fifty dollars, plus third party fees. 
M.	The fee for a permit for an oil burner system including tank or part of the system shall be thirty dollars. 
N.	The fee for a permit for reroofing shall be fifteen dollars/one thousand dollars value. 
O.	The fee for a permit for fences and retaining walls shall be thirty dollars. 
P.	The fee for oil tank abandonment shall be thirty-five dollars. 
Q.	The fee for asbestos removal shall be eighty-five dollars plus fifteen dollars CO. 
(Ord. 1300 § 1, 1998; Ord. 1200 § 2, 1991; Ord. 1153 § 1, 1988: Ord. 1006 § 1, 1977: Ord. 994 § 3 (part), 1977) 
15.08.050 - Fee schedule-Establishment and collection. 
A.	The construction official shall, with the advice of the subcode officials, prepare and submit to the mayor and council biannually, a report recommending a fee schedule based on the operating expenses of the agency, and any other expenses of the borough fairly attributable to the enforcement of the State Uniform Construction Code Act. 
B.	In order to provide for the training, certification, and technical support programs required by the Uniform Construction Code Act and the regulations, the enforcing agency shall collect, in addition to the fees specified above, a surcharge fee of $0.0006 per cubic foot of volume of new construction. Said surcharge fee shall be remitted to the Bureau of Housing Inspection, Department of Community Affairs, on a quarterly basis for the fiscal quarter ending September 30th, December 31st, March 31st and June 30th, and not later than one month next succeeding the end of the quarter for which it is due. In the fiscal year in which the regulations first become effective, said fee shall be collected and remitted for the third and four quarters only. 
C.	The enforcing agency shall report annually, at the end of each fiscal year, to the Bureau of Housing Inspection, and not later than July 31st, the total amount of the surcharge fee collected in the fiscal year. In the fiscal year in which the regulations first become effective, said report shall be for the third and fourth quarters only. 
(Ord. 994 § 3 (part), 1977) 
Chapter 15.12 - ZONING COMPLIANCE CERTIFICATION 
Sections: 

15.12.010 - Certificate required. 
A.	A certificate of zoning compliance must be obtained from the building inspector for any of the following: 
1.	The construction of any building or part of a building, which increases the area of the building, if construction requires the issuance of a building permit; 
2.	Occupancy and use of vacant land; 
3.	Occupancy and use or change in the occupancy, ownership or use of any building (whether due to a transfer of title or a rental or re-rental of a building or any portion thereof); 
4.	Change in the use of land or part of a lot; 
5.	Where in the judgment of the building inspector it is deemed necessary. 
B.	No such construction, occupancy, use or change of occupancy, ownership or use shall commence until an application for a certificate of zoning compliance shall have been made to the building inspector and a certificate of zoning compliance therefor shall have been issued by the building inspector. 
(Ord. 1105 §§ 1, 2, 1985) 
15.12.020 - Application for certificate. 
    Every application for a certificate of zoning compliance shall be made, in writing, in the form of a letter, by the owner or his or her authorized agent or a prospective purchaser of a property under contract or a prospective tenant and shall include a statement of the present use and the intended use of the structure or vacant land and, in the case of new construction, shall be accompanied by a plan drawn to lot and street lines. The building inspector shall inspect the premises for which a certificate of zoning compliance is sought within seven business days after his or her receipt of the application and shall issue or refuse to issue a certificate of zoning compliance within seven business days after such inspection, except when site plan approval is required, in which case the building inspector shall issue or refuse to issue the certificate upon receipt of notice of final action on the site plan by the planning board. If the building inspector refuses to issue a certificate hereunder, he or she shall state, in writing, the grounds for such refusal. Refusal shall be based solely upon existing use of a building or land which is in violation of applicable zoning ordinances or an intended use of a building or land which is in violation of zoning ordinances. 
(Ord. 1105 § 3, 1985) 
15.12.030 - Resubmittal of application. 
    If the building inspector refuses to issue a certificate of zoning compliance, a new application for a certificate of zoning compliance can be submitted at any time that the basis for the refusal has been corrected. 
(Ord. 1105 § 4, 1985) 
15.12.040 - Expiration of certificate-Extension. 
    If the occupancy and use of a building or of land for which a certificate of zoning compliance has been issued are not commenced within six months after the date of such issuance or such longer period as the building inspector may authorize in writing because of the occurrence of conditions unforeseen at the time of issuance, such certificate of zoning compliance shall expire and a new certificate of zoning compliance shall be obtained before such occupancy and use are commenced. No such extension of time for a longer period than ninety days shall be authorized. 
(Ord. 1105 § 5, 1985) 
15.12.050 - Issuance of certificate. 
    In addition to the above, upon written request by an owner or the owner's authorized agent, the building inspector shall, after inspection and determination of compliance with the zoning ordinance of the borough, issue a certificate of zoning compliance. 
(Ord. 1105 § 6, 1985) 
15.12.060 - Building inspector-Duties and compensation. 
    The building inspector shall perform the services required by this chapter with no extra compensation. 
(Ord. 1105 § 7, 1985) 
15.12.070 - Fees. 
    A fee of twenty-five dollars shall be paid to the borough as a service charge for the processing of the application and the issuance of a certificate of zoning compliance or a denial of such certificate. 
(Ord. 1105 § 8, 1985) 
15.12.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Every person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall for each and every violation be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars. Each and every day that such violation continues shall be considered a separate and specific violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1105 § 9, 1985) 
Chapter 15.16 - HOUSING CODE 
Sections: 

15.16.010 - Code adopted. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 21, P.L. 1946 (N.J.S.A. 40:49-5.1), the New Jersey State Housing Code as approved by the departments of Health and Conservation and Economic Development and filed in the Secretary of State's office is accepted, adopted and established as a standard to be used as a guide in determining the fitness of a building for human habitation or occupancy or use. A copy of the New Jersey State Housing Code is annexed to this chapter and three copies of the same have been placed on file in the office of the borough clerk and are available to all persons desiring to use and examine the same. 
(Ord. 1011 § 3, 1977) 
15.16.020 - Officer designated. 
    The building inspector and fire official of the borough are designated as the officers to exercise the powers prescribed by this chapter and he or she shall serve in such capacity without any additional salary. 
(Ord. 1011 § 1, 1977) 
(Ord. No. 1629, 5-11-2015) 
15.16.030 - Building inspector-Powers and duties. 
    The building inspector and fire official are authorized and empowered to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this chapter, including the following in addition to others herein granted: 
A.	To investigate the dwelling conditions in the borough in order to determine which dwellings therein are unfit for human habitation; 
B.	To administer oaths, affirmations, examine witnesses and receive evidence; 
C.	To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examination; provided, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
D.	To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents and employees as he or she deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter; and 
E.	To delegate any of the agents as he or she may designate. 
(Ord. 1011 § 7, 1977) 
(Ord. No. 1629, 5-11-2015) 
15.16.040 - Unfit dwellings. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the building inspector may determine that a dwelling is unfit for human habitation if the building inspector finds that conditions exist in such dwelling which are dangerous or injurious to the health or safety of the occupants of such dwelling, the occupants of neighboring dwellings or other residents of the borough. Such conditions may include the following (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accident, or other calamities; lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; dilapidation; disrepair; structural defects; or uncleanliness. 
(Ord. 1011 § 2, 1977) 
15.16.050 - Violation-Complaint issuance and hearing. 
    Whenever a petition is filed with the building inspector by a public authority as defined in N.J.S.A. 40:48-2.4, or by at least five residents of the municipality charging that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter and if the preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, or whenever it appears to the building inspector (on his or her own motion) that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, then he or she shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and parties in interest in such dwelling a complaint stating the charges and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the building inspector (or designated agent) at a place therein fixed not less than ten days nor more than thirty days after the serving of said complaint. At the hearing the owner and parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint, to appear in person, or otherwise, and to give testimony. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the building inspector. 
(Ord. 1011 § 4, 1977) 
15.16.060 - Violations-Repairs and fees required. 
    If, after such notice and hearing, the building inspector determines that the dwelling under consideration does violate a provision of this chapter, as herein defined, the building inspector shall serve upon the owner thereof and parties in interest the findings of fact in writing, together with an order requiring: 
A.	The repair, alteration or improvement of the said building to be made by the owner, within a reasonable time, which time shall be set forth in the order or at the option of the owner to vacate or to have said building vacated and closed within the time set forth in the order; and 
B.	If the building is in such a condition as to make it dangerous to the health and safety of persons on or near the premises and the owner fails to repair, alter or improve the said building within the time specified in the order, that the owner remove or demolish the said building within a reasonable time as specified in the said order of removal; 
C.	That, if the owner fails to comply with an order to repair, alter or improve or, at the option of the owner, to vacate and close the building, the building inspector may cause such building to be repaired, altered or improved, or to be vacated and closed; the building inspector may cause to be posted on the main entrance of any building so closed, a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or occupancy or use; the use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful."; 
D.	That, if the owner fails to comply with an order to repair, remove or demolish the building, the building inspector may cause such building to be repaired, removed or demolished or may contract for the repair, removal or demolition thereof; 
E.	That the amount of: 
1.	The cost of the filing of legal papers, expert witnesses' fees, search fees, and advertising charges, incurred in the course of any proceeding taken under this chapter, is determined in favor of the municipality, and 
2.	Such cost of such repairs, alternations or improvements, or vacating and closing, or removal or demolition, if any, or the amount of the balance thereof remaining after deduction of the sum, if any, realized from the sale of materials derived from such building or from any contract for repair, removal or demolition thereof, shall be a municipal lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. If the building is removed or demolished by the building inspector, he or she shall sell the materials of such building. There shall be credited against the cost of the removal or demolition thereof, the proceeds of any sale of such materials or any sum derived from any contract for the removal or demolition of the building. If there are no such credits or if the sum total of such costs exceeds the total of such credits, a detailed statement of the aforesaid costs and the amount so due shall be filed with the municipal tax assessor or other custodian of the records of tax liens and a copy thereof shall be forthwith forwarded to the owner by registered mail. If the total of the credits exceeds such costs, the balance remaining shall be deposited in the superior court by the building inspector, shall be secured in such manner as may be directed by such court and shall be disbursed according to the order or judgment of the court to the persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or judgment of such court; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the municipality to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. Any owner or party in interest may, within sixty days from the date of the filing of the lien certificate, proceed in a summary manner in the superior court to contest the reasonableness of the amount or the accuracy of the costs set forth in the municipal lien certificate. 
(Ord. 1011 § 5, 1977) 
15.16.070 - Complaints or orders-Delivery. 
    Complaints or orders issued by the building inspector pursuant to this chapter shall be served upon persons either personally or by registered mail, but if the whereabouts of such persons is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by said building inspector in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the building inspector shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the serving of such complaint or order upon such persons may be made by publishing the same once each week for two successive weeks in a newspaper circulated in the borough. A copy of such complaint or order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order, and a copy of such complaint or order shall be duly recorded or lodged for record with the county recording officer of the county in which the dwelling is located. 
(Ord. 1011 § 6, 1977) 
Chapter 15.20 - ABATEMENT OF DANGEROUS BUILDINGS 
Sections: 

15.20.010 - Definitions. 
    The following terms whenever used or referred to in this chapter shall have the following respective meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    "Building" means any manmade structure including, without limitation, each of the following: 
1.	Any manmade structure or part thereof (i) used for human habitation or occupancy, or (ii) intended to be so used, or (iii) whose last use was for human habitation or occupancy; or 
2.	Any garages, sheds or other accessory buildings or fences belonging thereto. 
    "Dangerous building" means and includes: 
1.	Any building which is dangerous to the public health because of its condition, or which may cause or aid in the spread of disease, or injury to the health of the occupants of such building or the occupants of neighboring buildings or other residents of the borough; 
2.	Any building which, because of faulty construction, disrepair or any other cause, is especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard; 
3.	Any building which, by reason of faulty construction or disrepair or any other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage by a collapse or fall of all or any part of such building; 
4.	Any building which is dangerous or injurious to the health or safety of the occupants of such building or the occupants of neighboring buildings or other residents of the borough because of (i) conditions which increase the hazards of fire, accident, or other calamities, (ii) lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities, (iii) dilapidation, (iv) disrepair, (v) structural defects, or (vi) uncleanliness; 
5.	Any building which because of its condition or because of lack of doors or windows is available to and frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of such building; or 
6.	Any building which because of its condition or because of lack of doors or windows might attract malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of such building. 
    "Demolish," "demolished," "demolishing" and "demolition" mean not only to destroy a building but also to remove all debris and waste materials from the lot on which the building stood. 
    "Owner" means the holder of fee simple title. 
    "Party having an interest" means any individual, association, or corporation who has a mortgage or other interest of record in a building or who is in habitation, occupancy or possession of any portion thereof. 
    "Unfit building" means any building (i) used for human habitation and/or occupancy, or (ii) intended to be so used, or (iii) whose last use was for human habitation and/or occupancy but which, in each of the foregoing cases, is unfit for human habitation or occupancy because it has any or all of the following defects: 
1.	Any building whose walls or vertical members list, lean, or buckle to such an extent that they are unable to safely support the loads normally applied to buildings or normally applied for the purpose such walls or vertical supports are used; 
2.	Any building which has a support member or members which have deteriorated to such an extent as to be unable to safely support the loads normally applied to buildings or normally applied for the purpose such member or members are used; 
3.	Any building which has improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs or in which the floors or roofs are overloaded or in which the floors or roofs have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used; 
4.	Any building which has been damaged by fire, wind, rain or other causes so as to have become (i) dangerous to life, safety, or the general health and welfare of any occupant of such building or any occupant of neighboring buildings or other residents of the borough, or (ii) no longer fit for human habitation or occupancy; 
5.	Any building which has parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall and injure persons or property; 
6.	Any building which does not have an unobstructed means of egress leading to an open space at ground level; 
7.	Any building which has wiring that is dangerous due to lack of insulation, improper fuses, inadequate grounding, lack of capacity of wires or other dangerous condition; 
8.	Any building which does not have an installed kitchen sink properly connected to and adequately supplied by the hot and cold water supply pipes and the sewer system; 
9.	Any building which does not have an installed tub or shower and lavatory properly connected to and adequately supplied by hot and cold water supply pipes and sewer system; 
10.	Any building which does not have a flush type water closet located in a room affording privacy and properly connected to and adequately supplied by the water supply pipes and sewer system; 
11.	Any building which does not have either central heating, fireproof flues or fireproof vents or which does not have heating equipment which is vented and maintained in good order and repair; 
12.	Any building which is maintained in a manner which violates Chapter 15.16, as amended from time to time; 
13.	Any building whose last use was for human habitation or occupancy but, because of (i) damage caused by fire, accident, wind, rain or other calamity, (ii) lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities, (iii) dilapidation, (iv) disrepair, (v) structural defects, (vi) uncleanliness, or (vii) actions by the owner or any party having an interest, can no longer be used and/or is not being used for human habitation or occupancy; 
14.	Any building which has been damaged by fire, decay or other causes to the extent of at least twenty-five percent of its value before such damage and for which a permit to rebuild or to demolish in accordance with applicable law has not been issued within four months from the date of such damage or, if a permit to rebuild or to demolish in accordance with applicable law has been issued, repair or demolition is not being diligently pursued so as to complete repair or demolition within the time allowed by the permit; or 
15.	Any building which, for a period of six consecutive months, has not been occupied or used for the purposes for which such building was intended and the windows and/or doors of such building have been sealed and/or covered with wood, metal or other material to an extent which indicates that the building is no longer being used or occupied. 
(Ord. 1211 § 1, 1992) 
15.20.020 - Declaration of a nuisance. 
A.	The presence and existence of any dangerous building in the borough is declared to be a nuisance. 
B.	The presence and existence of any unfit building in the borough is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. 1211 § 2, 1992) 
15.20.030 - Prohibition of nuisance. 
A.	It is unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building in the borough. 
B.	It is unlawful for the owner of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. 
C.	It is unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any unfit building in the borough. 
D.	It is unlawful for the owner of any unfit building to permit the same to remain in an unfit condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains in an unfit condition. 
(Ord. 1211 § 3, 1992) 
15.20.040 - Construction code official-Duties. 
A.	The construction code official of the borough of Glen Ridge is designated as the public officer to exercise the powers prescribed in this chapter and shall serve in such capacity without any additional salary. 
B.	The construction code official is authorized and empowered to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this chapter, including the following in addition to others herein granted: 
1.	To investigate the conditions of buildings in the borough in order to determine which buildings are dangerous buildings and/or unfit buildings; 
2.	To administer oaths, affirmations, examine witnesses and receive evidence; 
3.	To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examination, provided that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
4.	To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents and employees as said official deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter; and 
5.	To delegate any of his or her functions and powers under this chapter to such officers and agents as said official may designate. 
(Ord. 1211 § 4, 1992) 
15.20.050 - Abatement of nuisance. 
    Any building which is a dangerous building or an unfit building shall be repaired or demolished as hereinbefore and hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 1211 § 5, 1992) 
15.20.060 - Notification-Hearing. 
A.	Whenever a petition is filed with the construction code official by a public authority as defined in N.J.S.A. 40:48-2.4, or by at least five residents of the borough charging that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter and if the preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, or whenever it appears to the construction code official (on his or her own motion) that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, then said official shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and any party having an interest in the alleged dangerous building and/or unfit building a complaint stating the charges and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the construction code official (or designated agent) at a place therein fixed not less than ten days nor more than thirty days after the serving of said complaint. 
B.	Complaints or orders issued by the construction code official, pursuant to this chapter, shall be served upon persons either personally or by registered mail, but if the whereabouts of such persons are unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by said construction code official in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the said construction code official shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the serving of such complaint or order upon such persons may be made by publishing the same once each week for two successive weeks in a newspaper circulated in the borough. A copy of such complaint or order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order. 
C.	At the hearing, the owner and the parties having an interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint, to appear in person, or otherwise, and to give testimony. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law of equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the construction code official. 
(Ord. 1211 § 6, 1992) 
15.20.070 - Determination-Remedies. 
A.	If, after such notice and hearing, the construction code official determines that the building under consideration is a dangerous building and/or an unfit building in violation of this chapter, the construction code official shall have the power to do each of the following: 
1.	Declare the building to be a dangerous and/or unfit building, as applicable; 
2.	Set forth the findings of fact in support of the determination that the building exists as a dangerous building and/or an unfit building in violation of this chapter; 
3.	Require that, if the building can be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter or other ordinances of the borough, the owner repair it within a reasonable time (which time shall be set forth in the order) and in keeping with any other requirements of applicable law; 
4.	Allow the owner, in lieu of the repair described above, to demolish the building within the time specified for repair in the order and in keeping with any other requirements of applicable law or, if the building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter or other ordinances of the borough, require that the owner demolish the building within a reasonable time (which time shall be set forth in the order) and in keeping with any other requirements of applicable law; 
5.	Do any or all of the following if the owner does not comply with the determination of the construction code official within the time specified in his or her order: 
a.	Repair, alter or improve the building, or cause or contract for the repair, alteration or improvement thereof, 
b.	Cause the building to be vacated or closed, 
c.	Cause to be posted on a main entrance of the building a plaque with the following words, as applicable: "This building is [unfit for human habitation] [or] [a dangerous building]. The use or occupation of this building for human habitation or otherwise is prohibited and unlawful," 
d.	Demolish the building or cause or contract for its demolition, or 
e.	Fine the owner one hundred dollars per day for each and every day, commencing on the first day after the date by which repair and/or demolition was to be completed, that the owner is not in compliance with the aforesaid order; 
6.	Assess the cost of the filing of legal papers, expert witnesses' fees, search fees, and advertising charges incurred in the course of any proceeding taken under this chapter and determined in favor of the borough as a municipal lien against the building which was the subject of the aforesaid proceeding; 
7.	Do each of the following: 
a.	If the repair, alteration, improvement, vacating, closing or demolishing of the building was performed by or at the direction of the construction code official, assess the cost thereof or the amount of the balance thereof remaining after deduction of the sum, if any, realized from the sale of materials derived from such building or from any contract for repair or demolition thereof, as a municipal lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred, 
b.	If the building is demolished by or at the direction of the construction code official, sell the materials thereof and credit against the cost of the demolition the proceeds derived from any such sale or the proceeds paid under any contract for the demolition of the building, 
c.	If there are no such credits or if the sum total of such costs exceeds the total of such credits, file a statement of the aforesaid costs and the amount so due with the owner and the parties having an interest by personal service or by registered mail, 
d.	If the total of the credits exceeds such costs, use the balance remaining to pay any unpaid taxes due on the property and forward the balance, if any, to the owner by personal delivery or by registered mail. 
B.	If deemed necessary by the construction code official for the actual and immediate protection of the life, safety, or the general health and welfare of any occupant of such building or any occupant of neighboring buildings or other residents of the borough and regardless whether the owner elects to repair or to demolish the building, the construction code official may (1) require that the owner and all other parties having an interest vacate and close the building or have said building vacated and closed within the time set forth in the order; and/or (2) proceed in a summary manner in the superior court for the demolition of the building. 
(Ord. 1211 § 7, 1992) 
15.20.080 - Contents of notice. 
    After the notice and hearing described in Section 15.20.070 above, the construction code official shall serve upon the owner and the parties having an interest an order by personal service or registered mail in substantially the following form: 
 To ____________ [here list the owner and the parties having an interest] of the premises commonly known and described as ____________ and also known as Tax Block ____________ Lot ____________ in the borough of Glen Ridge, New Jersey: 
 You are hereby notified that ____________ [describe building] on the premises above mentioned has been determined to be a [dangerous] [and/or] [unfit] building and a nuisance after a hearing conducted by the construction code official of the borough of Glen Ridge pursuant to Ordinance No. ____________ . 
 The causes for this decision are as follows: 
 [Here insert the facts as to the condition making the building a (dangerous) (and/or) (unfit) building] 
 [If the building can be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter or other ordinances of the borough, insert the following:] 
 You or any one of the parties to whom this order is addressed must remedy this condition by repairing the building immediately. You or any one of the parties to whom this order is addressed must apply for permits for repair no later than ____________ , commence to repair no later than ____________ , and complete repair no later than ____________ . Should you choose to do so and in lieu of the repair described above, you may demolish the said building. If you elect to do this, you must apply for a permit for demolition no later than ____________ , commence to demolish no later than ____________ , and complete demolition by the removal of all debris from the premises no later than ____________ . 
or 
 [If the building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter or other ordinances of the borough, insert the following:] 
 You or any one of the parties to whom this order is addressed must remedy this condition by causing the demolition of the building within a reasonable time (which time shall be set forth in the order) and in keeping with any other requirements of applicable law. You must apply for a permit for demolition no later than ____________ , commence to demolish no later than ____________ , and complete demolition by the removal of all debris from the premises no later than ____________ . 
 [Add the following provision if applicable:] 
 Because of the location of the building within the Glen Ridge historic district, all plans for repair or demolition must be approved by the Glen Ridge historic commission. 
 The cost of the filing of legal papers, expert witnesses' fees, search fees, and advertising charges incurred in the course of the proceeding out of which this order arises is $ ____________ . This amount shall be a municipal lien against the real property described above. 
 Should you not comply with this order within the time specified in this order, the borough may do any or all of the following: 
 (1) Repair, alter or improve the building, or cause or contract for its repair, alteration or improvement; or 
 (2) Cause the building to be vacated or closed; 
 (3) Cause to be posted on a main entrance of the building so closed a plaque with the following words, as applicable: 
 "This building is (unfit for human habitation) (or) (a dangerous building). The use or occupation of this building for human habitation or otherwise is prohibited and unlawful"; 
 (4) Demolish the building or cause it to be demolished; 
 (5) Commencing on the first day after the date by which repairs and/or demolition is to be completed, fine you one hundred dollars per day for each and every day that you are not in compliance with this order; 
 (6) Assess additional costs as follows: 
 (i) If the repair, alteration, improvements, vacating, closing or demolishing of the building is performed by or at the direction of the construction code official of the borough, assess the cost thereof or the amount of the balance thereof remaining after deduction of the sum, if any, realized from the sale of materials derived from such building or from any contract for repair or demolition thereof, as a municipal lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred; 
 (ii) If the building is demolished by the construction code official of the borough, the materials of such building will be sold. There shall be credited against the cost of the removal or demolition thereof, the proceeds derived from any such sale or the proceeds paid under any contract for the removal or demolition of the building; 
 (iii) If there are no such credits or if the sum total of such costs exceeds the total of such credits, there shall be filed with the municipal tax assessor a statement of the aforesaid costs and the amount due thereon and a copy thereof shall be forthwith forwarded to you by personal service or by registered mail. 
 (iv) If the total of the credits exceeds such costs, the balance remaining shall be used to pay any unpaid taxes due on the property and the balance, if any, shall be forwarded to you by personal service or by registered mail. 
 [Add the following provision if applicable:] 
 For the actual and immediate protection of the life, safety, or the general health and welfare of the occupants of such building (or any occupant of neighboring buildings or other residents of the borough) and regardless whether you elect to repair or to demolish the said building, the building must be vacated and closed no later than ____________ . 
(Ord. 1211 § 8, 1992) 
15.20.090 - Violation-Penalty. 
    In addition to the powers of the construction code official set forth above, if the owner fails to comply with an order issued pursuant to Section 15.20.070 above, the owner shall be liable in any judicial proceeding for a fine of up to one hundred dollars per day for each and every day that the owner is not in compliance with the aforesaid order and each day the same is violated shall be deemed and taken to be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 1211 § 9, 1992) 
15.20.100 - Appeals. 
A.	Any owner or any party having an interest may, within forty-five days from the date of the filing of any lien certificate entered pursuant to this chapter, proceed in a summary manner in the Superior Court of the state of New Jersey to contest the reasonableness of the amount or the accuracy of the costs set forth in the aforesaid certificate. 
B.	Any owner or any party having an interest shall have any and all other rights of appeal afforded at law and in equity. 
(Ord. 1211 § 10, 1992) 
15.20.110 - Applicability. 
A.	Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way any other power of the borough to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
B.	Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the power of the borough or any officer or department to enforce any provisions of its charter, or its ordinances or regulations, nor to prevent or punish violations thereof, and the powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the borough by any other law or ordinance. 
(Ord. 1211 § 11, 1992) 
Chapter 15.21 - ABATEMENT OF PROPERTY IN DISREPAIR OR UNCLEAN CONDITION 
Sections: 

15.21.010 - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall govern the responsibilities of an owner of a building and any other party having an interest therein for the maintenance of such building, its exterior and the underlying land on which such building is situated. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
15.21.020 - Definitions. 
    The following terms whenever used or referred to in this chapter shall have the following respective meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    "Building" means any manmade structure including, without limitation, each of the following: 
1.	Any manmade structure or part thereof (i) used for human habitation; or occupancy; or (ii) intended to be so used; or (iii) whose last use was for human habitation or occupancy; and/or 
2.	Any garages, sheds or other accessory carriage house, playhouse, treehouse, pool, children's play set, fence or other building belonging or appurtenant thereto. 
    "Owner" means the holder or holders of fee simple title to any Building or any underlying land. 
    "Party having an interest" means an owner and each other individual, association, corporation, limited liability company, partnership or other entity who has a mortgage or other interest of record in any building or who is in habitation, occupancy, possession or control of any portion thereof. 
    "Underlying land" means (1) the land underlying or surrounding any building, together with all other land extending up to, and including, the record legal boundaries of the lot or parcel on which any such building is situated; and (2) in the case of any land on which no building is situated, all land extending up to, and including, the record legal boundaries of the lot or parcel in question. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
15.21.030 - Responsibility. 
A.	The owner of, and every party having an interest in, a building or any underlying land shall maintain such building, its exterior and such underlying land in compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
B.	An owner shall not inhabit, occupy, possess or control as owner-occupied, and shall not permit any other party having an interest to inhabit, occupy, possess or control, any building or any underlying land which is in disrepair or is not in a clean, sanitary, safe and secure condition or which does not otherwise comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
C.	1.	Every owner of, and every other party having an interest in, a building or underlying land is responsible for keeping in a clean, sanitary, safe and sure condition that part of any such building or underlying land which he, she or it owns, inhabits, occupies, possesses or controls. 
2.	An owner of, and any other party having an interest in, any building or underlying land shall not inhabit, occupy, possess or control such building or such underlying land if such building or underlying land is not in a clean, sanitary, safe and secure condition or does not otherwise comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
15.21.040 - Vacant buildings and underlying land. 
    The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any vacant or unoccupied building and/or any underlying land shall maintain such building and such underlying land in a clean, sanitary, safe and secure condition and not to cause or allow to exist a condition of disrepair, blight or neglect or otherwise adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
15.21.050 - Buildings, their exteriors and underlying land. 
A.	Good Repair. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building and/or any underlying land shall at all times maintain such building, its exterior and such underlying land in good repair and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition and not pose a threat to the public health, safety or welfare. 
B.	Sanitation. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building and/or any underlying land shall at all times maintain such building, its exterior and such underlying land in a clean, safe and sanitary condition and not pose a threat to the public health, safety or welfare. 
C.	Grading and Drainage. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any underlying land shall at all times maintain such underlying land graded and maintained to prevent the erosion of soil and to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon or on any other property within or outside the borough or within or against any building located thereon or on any other property within or outside the borough; provided, however, that the foregoing shall not apply to any approved pools, retention areas and reservoirs. 
D.	Sidewalks and Driveways: The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building and/or any underlying land shall at all times keep and maintain all sidewalks, walkways, stairs, driveways, parking spaces and similar areas appurtenant to any such building or underlying land in good repair and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition and free from obstructions, unevenness, settling, cracking and hazardous conditions. 
E.	Rodent Harborage. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building and/or underlying land shall at all times maintain such building, its exterior and such underlying land free from rodent harborage and infestation. Where rodents are found, they shall be promptly exterminated by approved processes which will not be injurious to human health. After extermination, proper precautions shall be taken to eliminate rodent harborage and prevent reinfestation. 
F.	Exhaust Vents. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building and/or underlying land shall at all times maintain such building, its exterior and such underlying land so that all pipes, ducts, conductors, fans or blowers appurtenant to any such building or underlying land shall not discharge gases, steam, vapor, hot air, grease, smoke, odors or other gaseous or particular wastes directly upon abutting or adjacent public or private property or that of any other party having an interest. 
G.	Defacement of Property. No person (whether or not a party having an interest) shall wilfully or wantonly damage, mutilate or deface any exterior surface of any building, whether private or public, or mark any underlying land by placing thereon any marking, carving or graffiti. It shall be the responsibility of each party having an interest to restore the exterior surface of any building or underlying land in which he, she or it has such an interest to an approved state of maintenance and repair within ten days after notice by the borough. 
H.	Protective Treatment. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain the exterior surfaces of such building, including but not limited to, its doors and window frames, cornices, porches and trim, in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition and not pose a threat to the public health, safety or welfare. Exterior wood surfaces, other than decay-resistant woods, shall be protected from the elements and decay, deterioration and rust by painting or other protective covering or treatment uniformly applied and uniformly covering such surfaces without excessive peeling, flaking or blistering. All siding and masonry joints as well as those between building envelope and the perimeter of windows, doors and skylights shall be maintained weather resistant and water tight. 
I.	Structural Members. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain all structural members of such building in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition and free from deterioration and capable of safely supporting the imposed dead and live loads. 
J.	Foundation Walls. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain the foundation walls of such building plumb and free from open cracks and breaks and in such condition so as to prevent the entry of rodents. 
K.	Exterior Walls. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain the exterior walls of such building free from holes, breaks, loose or rotting materials, and weatherproof and protected from the elements and against decay, deterioration or rust by periodic application of weather-coating materials, such as paint or similar surface treatment, uniformly applied and uniformly covering such surfaces without excessive peeling or blistering. 
L.	Roofs and Drainage. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain the roof and flashing of such building sound, tight and free of defects that allow the entry of rain. Roof drainage of each building shall be adequate to prevent dampness or deterioration in the walls or interior portion of such building. Roof drains, gutters and downspouts shall be maintained in good repair and free from obstructions. Roof water shall not be discharged in a manner that creates a public nuisance. 
M.	Decorative Features. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain all cornices, belt courses, corbels, terra cotta trim, wall facings and similar decorative features of each building in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition. 
N.	Overhang Extensions. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain all canopies, marquees, signs, metal awnings, fire escapes, standpipes, exhaust ducts and similar overhang extensions of such building in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition. To the extent required, all exposed surfaces of metal or wood shall be protected from the elements and against decay, deterioration or rust by periodic application of weather-coating materials, such as paint or similar surface treatment, uniformly applied and uniformly covering such surfaces without excessive peeling or blistering. 
O.	Stairways, Decks, Porches and Balconies. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain the exterior stairway, deck, porch and balcony of such building, and all appurtenances attached to any of the foregoing, in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition and capable of supporting the imposed loads. 
P.	Chimneys and Towers. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain all chimneys, cooling towers, smoke stacks, and similar appurtenances in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition. All exposed surface of metal or wood shall be protected from the elements and against decay, deterioration or rust by periodic application of weather-coating materials, such as paint or similar surface treatment, uniformly applied and uniformly covering such surfaces without excessive peeling, flaking or blistering. 
Q.	Handrails and Guards. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times keep every handrail and guard firmly fastened and capable of supporting normally imposed loads and in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition. 
R.	Window, Skylight and Door Frames. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain every window, skylight, door and frame weather tight, in good repair, properly anchored and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition. 
S.	Glazing. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain all glazing materials free from cracks and holes. 
T.	Openable Windows. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times keep every window, other than a fixed window, easily openable and capable of being held in position by window hardware. 
U.	Doors. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain all exterior doors, door assemblies and hardware weather tight, in good repair and in a structurally sound, safe and secure condition. Locks at all entrances to dwelling units, rooming units and guest rooms shall tightly secure each such entrance. 
V.	Basement Hatchways. The owner of, and every other party having an interest in, any building shall at all times maintain every basement hatchway to prevent the entrance of rodents, rain and surface drainage water. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
15.21.060 - Violations. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof in any judicial proceeding be punished by imprisonment in the county jail for a term not exceeding thirty days or by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars per day for each and every day that such person is not in compliance with any order of conviction or both. Each day any such order is violated shall be deemed and taken to be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
15.21.070 - Applicability of other laws. 
A.	Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to impair or limit in any way any other power of the borough of Glen Ridge to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
B.	Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the power of the borough of Glen Ridge or any officer or department to enforce any provisions of its charter, or any other provisions of its code or regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to prevent or punish violations thereof, and the powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the borough by any other law or provision of the Glen Ridge Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 1323 § 2 (part), 1999) 
Chapter 15.24 - CONSTRUCTION AND REGULATION OF PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS 
Sections: 

15.24.010 - Definitions. 
    "Lot" means all contiguous property of the same ownership. 
    "Permanent private swimming pool" means and includes any private swimming pool which is not a "portable private swimming pool" as defined in this section. 
    "Portable private swimming pool" means any swimming pool which is not designed to be permanently fixed in one place, but which is intended to be capable of being removed and stored.
